question: Question 1 Using shunt capacitors, the power factor of a 3-phase, 4 kV induction motor (drawing 390 kVA at 0.77 pf lag ) is to be corrected to 0.85 pf lag. The line current of the capacitor bank, in A, is ___________ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: Given: Line voltage of motor: [latex] V_L = 4000\ \text{V} [/latex] Apparent power: [latex] S = 390\ \text{kVA} [/latex] Initial power factor: [latex] \cos\phi_1 = 0.77\ (\text{lagging}) [/latex] Target power factor: [latex] \cos\phi_2 = 0.85\ (\text{lagging}) [/latex] Step 1: Compute the active power (real power) [latex] P = S \cdot \cos\phi_1 = 390 \cdot 0.77 = 300.3\ \text{kW} [/latex] Step 2: Compute reactive power before correction [latex] Q_1 = \sqrt{S^2 - P^2} = \sqrt{390^2 - 300.3^2} = \sqrt{152100 - 90180.09} = \sqrt{61919.91} \approx 248.8\ \text{kVAR} [/latex] Step 3: Compute reactive power after correction New apparent power [latex] S_2 = \frac{P}{\cos\phi_2} = \frac{300.3}{0.85} \approx 353.3\ \text{kVA} [/latex] [latex] Q_2 = \sqrt{S_2^2 - P^2} = \sqrt{353.3^2 - 300.3^2} = \sqrt{124821.89 - 90180.09} = \sqrt{34641.8} \approx 186.0\ \text{kVAR} [/latex] Step 4: Required reactive power by capacitor bank [latex] Q_c = Q_1 - Q_2 = 248.8 - 186.0 = 62.8\ \text{kVAR} [/latex] Step 5: Convert to line current In a 3-phase system, reactive power is: [latex] Q = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L \Rightarrow I_L = \frac{Q}{\sqrt{3} V_L} [/latex] [latex] I_L = \frac{62.8 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \cdot 4000} = \frac{62800}{6928.2} \approx 9.1\ \text{A} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{9.1\ \text{A}} [/latex]

Question 3 A DC series motor with negligible series resistance is running at a certain speed driving a load, where the load torque varies as cube of the speed. The motor is fed from a 400 V DC source and draws 40 A armature current. Assume linear magnetic circuit. The external resistance, in [latex]\Omega[/latex], that must be connected in series with the armature to reduce the speed of the motor by half, is closest to
solution: [latex]T_{e m} \propto I_{a}{ }^{2}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}} \propto \mathrm{N}^{3}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a}}{ }^{2} \propto \mathrm{~N}^{3}[/latex] [latex]\left(\frac{\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 2}}{\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 1}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{\mathrm{N}_{2}}{\mathrm{~N}_{1}}\right)^{3}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 2}^{2}=40^{2} \times \frac{1}{8}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{a} 2}=14.142 \mathrm{~A}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{b} 2}=400-14.14\left(\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{ex}}\right)[/latex] [latex]\therefore \frac{N_{2}}{N_{1}}=\frac{E_{b 2}}{E_{b 1}} \times \frac{\phi_{1}}{\phi_{2}}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}=\frac{400-14.14\left(R_{\text {ex }}\right)}{400} \times \frac{40}{14.142}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{ex}}=23.28 \Omega[/latex]

question: Question 4 The induced emf in a [latex]3.3 \mathrm{kV}, 4[/latex] pole, 3-phase star connected synchronous motor is considered to be equal and in phase with the terminal voltage under no load condition. On application of a mechanical load, the induced emf phasor is deflected by an angle of [latex]2^{\circ}[/latex] mechanical with respect to the terminal voltage phasor. If the synchronous reactance is [latex]2 \Omega[/latex], and stator resistance is negligible, then the motor armature current magnitude, in ampere, during loaded condition is closest to, ___________ (round off to two decimal places).
Question 5 Instrument(s) required to synchronize an alternator to the grid is/are
solution:
To synchronize an alternator with the grid, the following conditions must be satisfied: The terminal voltage of the alternator should match the grid voltage. The frequency of the alternator must be equal to the grid frequency. The phase sequence should be identical. The phase angle difference should be nearly zero at the instant of synchronization. Instruments used to verify these conditions are: (A) Voltmeter:
Used to ensure the voltage of the alternator matches the grid voltage. (B) Wattmeter:
Measures power; not used for synchronization. (C) Synchroscope:
Used to indicate the phase angle and frequency difference between the alternator and the grid. It shows whether the alternator is running fast or slow and when to close the circuit breaker. (D) Stroboscope:
Used to measure rotational speed visually; not used in electrical synchronization.

question: Question 6 The operating region of the developed torque [latex]\left(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{em}}\right)[/latex] and speed [latex](\omega)[/latex] of an induction motor drive is given by the shaded region OQRE in the figure. The load torque [latex]\left(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}\right)[/latex] characteristic is also shown. The motor drive moves from the initial operating point O to the final operating point S. Which one of the following trajectories will take the shortest time?
solution: The shortest time to reach the final operating point happens when the motor accelerates with the maximum possible torque. In the torque speed plane, the maximum developed torque corresponds to the uppermost boundary of the shaded region, the line QR So the fastest trajectory will follow: O-Q-R-S

R_{s}=3 \Omega,  X_{s}=2 \Omega, X_{r}^{\prime}=2 \Omega,  R_{r}^{\prime}=2.5 \Omega,

The magnetizing reactance and core loss of the motor can be neglected. To have maximum torque at starting, the value of the extra resistance in ohms (referred to the rotor side) to be connected in series with each phase of the rotor winding is _____ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Condition for the maximum torque [latex]
\frac{R_{2}^{\prime}}{s}=\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}=5
 [/latex] Substituting, s=1 As maximum torque at starting [latex]
\begin{aligned}
R_{2}^{\prime}+R_{e x t}^{\prime} & =5 \\
R_{e x t}^{\prime} & =5-2.5=2.5 \Omega \\
\frac{2.5}{3^{2}} & =0.277 \Omega
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question: Question 10 A 3-phase. [latex] 11 \mathrm{kV} .10 [/latex] MVA synchronous generator is connected to an inductive load of power factor [latex] (\sqrt{3} / 2) [/latex] via a lossless line with a per-phase inductive reactance of [latex] 5 \Omega [/latex]. The per-phase synchronous reactance of the generator is [latex] 30 \Omega [/latex] with negligible armature resistance. If the generator is producing the rated current at the rated voltage, then the power factor at the terminal of the generator is
solution:
[latex] \mathrm{pF}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=30^{\circ} \text { lagging } [/latex] [latex] 
\begin{aligned}
E & =\sqrt{(V \cos 30+I R)^2+\left(V \sin 30^{\circ}+I X\right)^2} \\
E & =\sqrt{(V \cos +I R)^2+(V \sin +I X)} \\
\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}} & =\sqrt{\left(V \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2+\left(\frac{V}{2}+524.86(5)\right)^2} \\
\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^2 & =V^2 \cdot \frac{3}{4}+\left(\frac{V}{2}+2624.319\right)^2 \\
\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^2 & =\frac{3}{4} V^2+\frac{V^2}{4}+2624.319 \mathrm{~V}+2624.319^2 \\
V_t & =4618.105 \mathrm{~V} \\
(I Z)^2 & =E^2+V^2-2 E V \cos \delta \\
(2624.319)^2 & =\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^2+(4618.105)^2-2\left(\frac{11 \mathrm{~K}}{\sqrt{3}}\right)(4618.105) \cos \delta \\
\delta & =20.96 \\
\mathrm{pF} & =\cos (20.96+30)=0.629 \text { lagging }
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 20 A 3-phase, 415 V, 4-pole, 50 Hz induction motor draws 5 times the rated current at
rated voltage at starting. It is required to bring down the starting current from the
supply to 2 times of the rated current using a 3-phase autotransformer. If the
magnetizing impedance of the induction motor and no load current of the
autotransformer is neglected, then the transformation ratio of the autotransformer is
given by _______. (round off to two decimal places).
solution:
We have [latex] I_L=x^2I_{sc}[/latex] Here, 
[latex] I_L=2I_f[/latex] and 
[latex]I_{sc}=5I_f [/latex] From the above eqiations. [latex]2I_f=x^25I_f\Rightarrow x=\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}}=0.6324 [/latex]

question:
Question 21 A star-connected 3-phase, 400 V, 50 kVA, 50 Hz synchronous motor has a
synchronous reactance of 1 ohm per phase with negligible armature resistance. The
shaft load on the motor is 10 kW while the power factor is 0.8 leading. The loss in
the motor is 2 kW. The magnitude of the per phase excitation emf of the motor, in
volts, is __________. (round off to nearest integer).
solution:
Power input[latex] = 10 + 2 = 12 kW[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
P&=\sqrt{3}VI \cos\phi \\
I_a&=\frac{10 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times 400 \times 0.8}\\
&=21.65\angle 36.86^{\circ}A
\end{aligned}[/latex] We have, Emf equation for motor [latex]\begin{aligned}
\bar{E_{ph}}&=\bar{V_{ph}}-\bar{I_{a}}\bar{Z_{s}}\\
&=\frac{400}{\sqrt{3}}-21.65\angle 36.83^{\circ}\times 1\angle 90^{\circ}\\
&=244.542\angle -4.062^{\circ}V
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 22 A 4-pole induction motor with inertia of 0.1 [latex]kg-m^2[/latex] drives a constant load torque of
2 Nm. The speed of the motor is increased linearly from 1000 rpm to 1500 rpm in
4 seconds as shown in the figure below. Neglect losses in the motor. The energy, in
joules, consumed by the motor during the speed change is ____________. (round
off to nearest integer)
solution:
We have [latex]\begin{aligned}
J\frac{d\omega }{dt}&=\tau _e-\tau _L\\
J\omega \frac{d\omega }{dt}&=P_e-P_L \;\;(\because P=\tau \omega )\\
\therefore P_e&=J\omega \frac{d\omega }{dt}+P_L\\
E&=\int P_edt\\
R&=J\int_{1000}^{1500}\omega d\omega +\int_{1000}^{1500}P_Ldt\\
&=\frac{J}{2}\left ( \frac{2 \pi}{60} \right )^2[1500^2-1000^2]+\frac{2 \pi \tau }{60}\int_{1000}^{1500}Ndt\\
&=\frac{0.1}{2}\left ( \frac{2 \pi}{60} \right )^2\times 125 \times 10^4+\frac{2 \pi}{60} \times 2\times [1000 \times 4+\frac{1}{2} \times 500 \times 4]\\
&=1732.586J
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 A 280 V, separately excited DC motor with armature resistance of [latex]1\Omega  [/latex] and constant
field excitation drives a load. The load torque is proportional to the speed. The
motor draws a current of 30 A when running at a speed of 1000 rpm. Neglect
frictional losses in the motor. The speed, in rpm, at which the motor will run, if an
additional resistance of value [latex]10\Omega  [/latex] is connected in series with the armature, is
_______. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
Back emf, [latex]E_{b1}=280-30 \times 1 =250V [/latex] When additional [latex] 10\Omega[/latex] resistance connected in
series with armature. [latex]E_{b2}=280-(10+1) I_{a_2} =280-11I_{a_2} [/latex] Given:
[latex] \tau \propto N[/latex] We know, 
[latex] \tau \propto \phi I_a \text{ (Here, }\phi \rightarrow constant)[/latex] So, [latex]\begin{aligned}
\tau &\propto I_a \\
\therefore \; N &\propto I_a \\
or \; \frac{N_2}{N_1}&=\frac{I_{a_2}}{I_{a_1}}\\
I_{a_2}&=N_2 \times \frac{30}{1000}\\
\therefore \; E_{b_2}&=280-\left ( 11 \times \frac{30}{1000} \right )N_2\\
&\text{We also have,}\\
E_b &\propto\phi \omega \\
\therefore \frac{E_{b_2}}{E_{b_1}}&=\frac{N_2}{N_1}\\
&\frac{280-\left ( 11 \times \frac{30}{1000} \right )N_2}{250}=\frac{N_2}{1000}\\
\Rightarrow N_2&=482.758rpm
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 26 An 8-pole, [latex]50 \:Hz[/latex], three-phase, slip-ring induction motor has an effective rotor resistance of [latex]0.08\:\Omega[/latex] per phase. Its speed at maximum torque is [latex]650 \text{ RPM}[/latex]. The additional resistance per phase that must be inserted in the rotor to achieve maximum torque at start is _____________ [latex]\Omega[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.) Neglect magnetizing current and stator leakage impedance. Consider equivalent circuit parameters referred to stator.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_{\max } &=650 \mathrm{rpm}, P=8,50 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ s_{m} &=\frac{750-650}{750}=0.1333 \\ s_{m} &=\frac{R_{2}}{X_{2}} \\ \therefore\qquad \qquad X_{2} &=\frac{R_{2}}{s_{m}}=\frac{0.08}{0.133}=0.601 \Omega \\ R_{2} &=0.08 \Omega, X_{2}=0.601 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] Condition for maximum [latex]T_{\mathrm{s}}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad R_{2} & =X_{2} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad R_{2}+ R_{\text {ext }} & =X_{2} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad R_{\text {ext }} & =0.601-0.08=0.521 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 27 A belt-driven [latex]\text{DC}[/latex]
 shunt generator running at [latex]300\: \text{RPM}[/latex]
 delivers [latex]100 \:\text{kW}[/latex]
 to a [latex]200 \:V\: \text{DC}[/latex]
 grid. It continues to run as a motor when the belt breaks, taking [latex]10 \:\text{kW}[/latex]
 from the [latex]\text{DC}[/latex]
 grid. The armature resistance is [latex]0.025 \Omega[/latex], field resistance is [latex]50\:\Omega[/latex], and brush drop is [latex]2 \:V[/latex]. Ignoring armature reaction, the speed of the motor is _____  [latex]\text{RPM}[/latex]. (Round off to 2 decimal places.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{L} &=\frac{100 \times 10^{3}}{200}=500 \mathrm{~A} \\ I_{S h} &=\frac{200}{50}=4 \mathrm{~A} \\ I_{a} &=504 \mathrm{~A} \\ E_{q} &=V+I_{a} R_{a}+\text { Brush drop } \\ &=200+504(0.025)+2 \mathrm{~V} \\ &=214.6 \mathrm{~V}\\ \text{In motoring case:} V I&=10 \mathrm{~kW}, V=200 \mathrm{~V}\\ \therefore \qquad \qquad I &=\frac{10000}{200}=50 A \\ I_{f} &=4 \mathrm{~A}, I_{a}=I_{L}-I_{f} \\ &=46 \mathrm{~A} \\ E_{b} &=V-I_{a} R_{a}-\text { Brush Drop } \\ &=200-46(0.025)-2=196.85 \mathrm{~V} \\ \frac{N_{m}}{N_{g}} &=\frac{E_{b}}{E_{g}} \\ N_{m} &=\frac{E_{b}}{E_{g}} \times N_{g} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad N_{m} &=\frac{196.85}{214.6} \times 300=275.18 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 28 In a single-phase transformer, the total iron loss is [latex]2500\:W[/latex]
 at nominal voltage of [latex]440\:V[/latex] and frequency [latex]50\:Hz[/latex]. The total iron loss is [latex]850\:W[/latex] at [latex]220\:V[/latex] and [latex]25\:Hz[/latex]. Then, at nominal voltage and frequency, the hysteresis loss and eddy current loss respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W_{i 1} &=2500 \mathrm{~W} \text { at } 440 \mathrm{~V}, 50 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ W_{i 2} &=850 \mathrm{~W} \text { at } 220 \mathrm{~V}, 25 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ W_{i 3} &=R_{e_{3}}+P_{H_{3}} \text { at } 440 \mathrm{~V}, 50 \mathrm{~Hz} \\ R_{\theta_{3}} &=?, \quad P_{h_{3}}=?, \quad \frac{v}{f}=\mathrm{constant} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad\quad 2500 &=A f+B f^{2} &\left\{\frac{400}{50}=\frac{220}{25}=\text { Constant }\right\} \\ \text { or, }\qquad \qquad \quad \frac{2500}{f} &=A+B f \\ \text{or},\qquad \qquad \frac{2500}{50}&=A+B(50) &\ldots(i)\\ \text{and}\qquad \qquad \frac{850}{25}&=\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B}(25)&\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving (i) and (ii), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} 25 B &=\frac{2500}{50}-\frac{850}{25}=\frac{2500-1700}{50} \\ &=\frac{800}{50}=16 \\ B &=\frac{16}{25} \\ \text{and from (i)},\qquad A &=50-\frac{16}{25} \times 50=50-32=18\\ \text{So, at} 50 \mathrm{~Hz}\\ P_{h}&=A f=18 \times 50=900 \mathrm{~W} \\ P_{e}&=B f=\left(\frac{16}{25}\right) \times(50)^{2}=1600 \mathrm{~W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 29 An alternator with internal voltage of [latex]1\angle \delta _{1}\text{p.u}[/latex]
 and synchronous reactance of [latex]\text{0.4 p.u}[/latex] is connected by a transmission line of reactance [latex]\text{0.1 p.u}[/latex] to a synchronous motor having synchronous reactance [latex]\text{0.35 p.u}[/latex] and internal voltage of [latex]0.85\angle \delta _{2}\text{p.u}[/latex]. If the real power supplied by the alternator is [latex]\text{0.866 p.u}[/latex], then [latex]\left( \delta _{1} -\delta _{2}\right)[/latex] is _________ degrees. (Round off to 2 decimal places.) (Machines are of non-salient type. Neglect resistances.)
solution: Given real power in (p.u.), [latex]P=0.866[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\frac{E V \sin \left(\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\right)}{X_{\mathrm{eq}}}=\left|\frac{1 \times 0.85}{0.4+0.1+0.35}\right| \sin \left(\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\right) \\ \left(\delta_{1}-\delta_{2}\right) &=60^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 30 The power input to a [latex]\text{500 V, 50 Hz, 6-pole, 3-phase}[/latex]
 induction motor running at [latex]975 \text{ RPM}[/latex]
 is [latex]40 \text{ kW}[/latex] . The total stator losses are [latex]1 \text{ kW}[/latex]. If the total friction and windage losses are [latex]2.025\text{~ kW}[/latex], then the efficiency is _____________%.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{i / p} &=40 \mathrm{~kW}, \quad \text { stator loss }=1 \mathrm{~kW}, \quad \mathrm{~F} \text { and } W=2.025 \mathrm{~kW} \\ \text { Stator } \mathrm{o} / \mathrm{p} &=40-1=39 \mathrm{~kW} \\ \qquad \text { Slip } &=\frac{1000-975}{1000}=0.025 \\ \text { Rotor } \mathrm{o} / \mathrm{p} &=\text { Rotor } \mathrm{i} / \mathrm{p} \times(1-\mathrm{s}) \\ &=39(1-0.025)=38.025 \mathrm{~kW} \\ \text { Motor } \mathrm{o} / \mathrm{p} &=38.025-2.025=36 \mathrm{~kW}\\ \eta&=\frac{\text { Motor output }}{\text { Motor input }}=\frac{36}{40} \times 100=90 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 Consider the table given: [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Constructional feature} & \text{Machine type} & \text{Mitigation} \\ \hline \text{P. Damper bars} & \text{S. Induction motor} & \text{X. Hunting} \\ \hline \text{Q. Skewed rotor slots} & \text{T. Transformer} & \text{Y. Magnetic locking} \\ \hline \text{R. Compensating winding} & \text{U. Synchronous machine} & \text{Z. Armature reaction} \\ \hline \text{} & \text{V. DC machine} & \text{} \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex] The correct combination that relates the constructional feature, machine type and mitigation is
solution: P: Damper bars used in synchronous machine (U) to prevent hunting (X) Q: Skewed rotor slots used in induction motor (S) t avoid magnetic locking (Y) R: Compensating winding used in DC machine (V) to neutralize cross magnetizing effects of armature reaction (Z) under main poles (polar zone).

question:
Question 35 A cylindrical rotor synchronous generator with constant real power output and constant
terminal voltage is supplying 100 A current to a 0.9 lagging power factor load. An ideal
reactor is now connected in parallel with the load, as a result of which the total lagging
reactive power requirement of the load is twice the previous value while the real power
remains unchanged. The armature current is now _______ A (rounded off to 2 decimal
places).
solution: At [latex]P_{constant},[/latex] [latex] I_{a1}\cos \phi _{1}=I_{a2}\cos \phi _{2}[/latex] [latex] \cos \phi _{1}=0.9 [/latex] [latex]\tan \phi _{1}=0.484=\frac{Q}{P} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \, \, \frac{2Q}{P}=0.9686=\tan \phi _{2} [/latex] [latex]\cos \phi _{2}=0.7182 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \, 100\times 0.9=I_{a2}\times 0.7182 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \, \, I_{a2}=125.29\: A[/latex]

question:
Question 36 The figure below shows the per-phase Open Circuit Characteristics (measured in V) and
Short Circuit Characteristics (measured in A) of a 14 kVA, 400 V, 50 Hz, 4-pole, 3-phase,
delta connected alternator, driven at 1500 rpm. The field current, [latex]I_f[/latex] is measured in A.
Readings taken are marked as respective (x,y) coordinates in the figure. Ratio of the
unsaturated and saturated synchronous impedances ([latex]Z_{s(unsat)}/Z_{s(sat)}[/latex]) of the alternator is
closest to
solution:
For unsaturated synchronous impedance
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\text{At } I_f&=2A, \; V_{OC}=210V \\
\text{From SCC}\\
\text{at } I_f&=4A, \; I_{SC}=20A \\
\therefore \;  I_f&=2A, \; I_{SC}=10A \\
Z_s, \text{unsaturated }&=\left.\begin{matrix}
\frac{V_{OC}}{I_{SC}}
\end{matrix}\right|_{I_f=const.} \\
&= \frac{210}{10}=21 \Omega \\
\text{For } Z_s, \text{ saurated}:\\
\text{when, } V_{OC}&=V_{rated}=400V\\
I_f&=8A \\
\text{From SCC, }
 I_f&=8A, \; I_{SC}=40A \\
 Z_s, \text{saturated }&=\frac{400}{40}=10\Omega \\
 \text{Hence,}\\
 \frac{Z_s, \text{unsaturated }}{Z_s, \text{ saturated }}&=\frac{21}{10}=2.1\Omega 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 39 A single 50 Hz synchronous generator on droop control was delivering 100 MW power
to a system. Due to increase in load, generator power had to be increased by 10 MW.
as a result of which, system frequency dropped to 49.75 Hz. Further increase in load
in the system resulted in a frequency of 49.25 Hz. At this condition, the power in MW
supplied by the generator is ________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places)
solution: Assumed full load frequency is 50 Hz [latex]\begin{aligned}\tan \theta &=\frac{50-49.75}{110-100} \\ &=\frac{49.75-49.25}{(x-(110))} \\ \frac{0.25}{10}&=\frac{0.5}{(x-150)} \\ x-110&=\frac{0.5\times 10}{0.25} \\ x&=110+20=130\, MW\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 41 A three-phase, 50 Hz, 4-pole induction motor runs at no-load with a slip of 1%. With
full load, the slip increases to 5 %. The % speed regulation of the motor (rounded off
to 2 decimal places) is _________ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Synchronous speed, }\\ N_s&=\frac{120f}{P}\\ N_s&=\frac{120 \times 50}{4}rpm\\ N_s&=1500 \; rpm\\ \text{Speed at no-load,}\\ &=N_s(1-S_{nL})\\ &=1500(1-0.01)\\ &=1485 \; rpm\\ \text{Speed at full-load,}\\ &=N_s(1-S_{fL})\\ &=1500(1-0.05)\\ &=1425 \; rpm\\ \% \text{ speed regulation}&=\frac{N_{NL}-N_{FL}}{N_{FL}} \times 100\\ &=\frac{1485-1425}{1425} \times 100\\ &=4.21\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 42 A three-phase cylindrical rotor synchronous generator has a synchronous reactance [latex]X_s[/latex]
and a negligible armature resistance. The magnitude of per phase terminal voltage is
[latex]V_A[/latex] and the magnitude of per phase induced emf is [latex]E_A[/latex]. Considering the following two
statements, P and Q. P : For any three-phase balanced leading load connected across the terminals of this
synchronous generator, [latex]V_A[/latex] is always more than [latex]E_A[/latex]. Q : For any three-phase balanced lagging load connected across the terminals of this
synchronous generator, [latex]V_A[/latex] is always less than [latex]E_A[/latex]. Which of the following options is correct?
solution: For lagging p.f. load : For all lagging power factor loads: [latex]E_A \gt V_A[/latex] For unity p.f. load: Still we can see : [latex]E_A \gt V_A[/latex] For 'slighlty' load, phasor diagram will be quite similar to that of unity p.f. load, thus [latex]E_A [/latex] will be greater than [latex]V_A[/latex]. Thus P is false.

options.A: P is false and Q is true.
options.B: P is true and Q is false.
options.C: P is false and Q is false.
options.D: P is true and Q is true.

question: Question 43 A 220 V (line), three-phase, Y-connected, synchronous motor has a synchronous impedance of (0.25+j2.5)[latex]\Omega[/latex]/phase. The motor draws the rated current of 10 A at 0.8 pf leading. The rms  value  of line-to-line internal voltage  in  volts (round  off  to  two  decimal  places) is __________.
solution: For synchronous motor, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_g &=V_t-IZ \\ V_t &=\frac{220}{\sqrt{3}} \; \text{V (phase)} \\ Z &=(0.25+j2.5) \Omega \\ I &= 10\angle \cos ^{-1} 0.8A\\ E_g&= \frac{220}{\sqrt{3}}-(0.25+j2.5) \times 10\angle \cos ^{-1} 0.8\\ E_g&= 141.658 \angle -8.728^{\circ} \; \text{V (phase)}\\ E_g &= 245.36 \; \text{V(line)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 A delta-connected, 3.7 kW, 400 V(line), three-phase, 4-pole, 50-Hz squirrel-cage induction motor  has  the  following  equivalent circuit  parameters  per  phase  referred  to  the  stator: [latex]R_1=5.39\Omega,R_2=5.72\Omega,X_1=X_2=8.22\Omega[/latex]. Neglect  shunt  branch  in  the  equivalent circuit.  The  starting  line  current  in  amperes (round  off  to  two  decimal  places) when  it  is connected to a 100 V (line), 10 Hz, three-phase AC source is ______

Question 45 A 220 V DC shunt motor takes 3 A at no-load. It draws 25 A when running at full-load at 1500 rpm. The armature and shunt resistances are 0.5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and 220 [latex]\Omega[/latex],respectively. The no-load speed in rpm (round off to two decimal places) is ________
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
&\text{At full load condition,}\\
 N_1&=1500 \; \text{rpm} \\ 
I_1 &=25A \\ 
 I_f&= \frac{220V}{200\Omega }=1A\\ 
 I_{a1}&=I_1-I_f=24A \\ 
 E_{g1}&=V-I_{a1}R_a \\ 
 &=220-24 \times 0.5=208V \\ 
&\text{At no-load condition,}\\
 I_2&= 3A\\ 
 I_f&= 1A\\ 
I_{a2}&=I_2-I_f=2A \\ 
 E_{g2}&=220-2 \times 0.5=219V \\ 
 E_g&\propto \phi N \\ 
& \text{Flux id constant,}\\
 E_g&\propto N \\ 
 \frac{E_{g2}}{E_{g1}}&=\frac{N_2}{N_1} \\ 
 \frac{219}{208}&=\frac{N_2}{1500} \\ 
 N_2&= 1579.33 \;\text{rpm}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 A single-phase transformer of rating 25 kVA, supplies a 12 kW load at power factor of 0.6 lagging. The additional load at unity power factor in kW (round off to two decimal places) that may be added before this transformer exceeds its rated kVA is __________.
solution: For a 12 kW, 0.6 pf lagging load, [latex]\begin{aligned} P_L &= 12kW\\ Q_L&= \frac{12}{0.6} \times \sin (cos^{-1} 0.6)\\ &= 16kVAR \end{aligned} [/latex] Trasformer rating , S=25kVA Let us assume load thet can be added is P kW then, [latex]\begin{aligned} S^2 &=(P+P_L)^2+Q_L^2 \\ 25^2&= (P+12)^2+16^2\\ P &= 7.21kW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 The magnetic circuit shown below has uniform cross-sectional area and air gap of 0.2 cm. The  mean  path  length  of  the  core  is  40  cm. Assume  that  leakage  and  fringing fluxes are negligible. When the core relative permeability is assumed to be infinite, the magnetic flux density  computed  in  the  air  gap  is  1  tesla.  With  same  Ampere-turns,  if  the  core  relative permeability  is  assumed  to  be  1000  (linear),  the  flux  density in  tesla(round  off  to  three decimal places) calculated in the air gap is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} l_{ag} &=0.2 cm \\ l_m&= 40cm\\ B_0 &= 1 \text{Tesla}\\ \phi &= \frac{mmf}{\Re }\\ &\text{For the same mmf,} \\ \phi &\propto \frac{1}{\Re } \\ \text{In case-1:} &\\ \Re _1&=\frac{l_m}{\mu _0A} \\ &= \frac{l_{ag}}{\mu _0 A}+\frac{l_m}{\mu _0 \mu _r A}\\ \text{as} \;\;\mu _0=0& \\ \therefore \;\;\Re _1&= \frac{0.2 \times 10^{-2}}{\mu _0 A}\\ \text{In case-2:} &\\ \Re _2&= \frac{l_{ag}}{\mu _0 A}+\frac{l_m}{\mu _0 \mu _r A}\\ &=\frac{0.2 \times 10^{-2}}{\mu _0 A}+\frac{40 \times 10^{-2}}{1000\mu _0 A}\\ &=\frac{0.24\times 10^{-2}}{\mu _0 A} \end{aligned} [/latex] As flux [latex]\phi \propto B[/latex] for uniform cross section area. [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; B_2&=\frac{B_1 \times \Re _1}{\Re _2} \\ B_2&= \frac{1 \times 0.2 \times 10^{-2}/\mu _0 A}{0.24 \times 10^{-2}/\mu _0A}\\ &= 0.833T \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 A three-phase synchronous motor draws 200 A from the line at unity power factor at rated load. Considering the same line voltage and load, the line current at a power factor of 0.5 leading is
solution: [latex]P=VI \cos \phi [/latex] For the same voltage and load, [latex]I \cos \phi =constant [/latex] [latex]I_1 \cos \phi _1=I_2 \cos \phi _2 [/latex] at unity power factor, [latex] \begin{aligned} I_1&=200A \\ 200 \times 1 &=I_2 \times 0.5 \\ I_2&=400A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 The parameter of an equivalent circuit of a three-phase induction motor affected by reducing the rms value of the supply voltage at the rated frequency is
Question 50 A 5 kVA, 50 V/100 V, single-phase transformer has a secondary terminal voltage of 95 V when loaded. The regulation of the transformer is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Voltage regulation } &=\frac{V_{NL}-V_{FL}}{V_{NL}} \times 100 \\ &= \frac{100-95}{100} \times 100=5\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 51 The equivalent circuit of a single phase induction motor is shown in the figure, where the
parameters are [latex]R_{1}=R'_{2}=X_{i1}=X'_{i2}=12\Omega [/latex], [latex]X_{M}=240\Omega[/latex] and s is the slip. At no-load, the motor speed can be approximated to be the synchronous speed. The no-load lagging power factor of the motor is___________ (up to 3 decimal places).
solution: Simplifying the above circuit into a simple R-L circuit, [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{eq} &=\frac{(3+j6)(j120)}{(3+j126)}+(12+j32) \\ &=138.563\angle \\ &\text{Current drawn by motor is } \\ I&= \frac{V\angle 0}{Z\angle \theta } \end{aligned} [/latex] ([latex]\therefore \; \theta :[/latex]  impedance angle will be p.f. angle) [latex] \therefore[/latex] No laod lagging p.f. of motor is [latex](\cos\theta ),[/latex] [latex] \cos(83.9)=0.106[/latex] lagging power factor

question:
Question 52 A 200 V DC series motor, when operating from rated voltage while driving a certain load,
draws 10 A current and runs at 1000 r.p.m. The total series resistance is 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The magnetic
circuit is assumed to be linear. At the same supply voltage, the load torque is increased by
44%. The speed of the motor in r.p.m. (rounded to the nearest integer) is ________ .
solution:
Form circuit diagram, [latex]\begin{aligned}
E_{b1} &=V-I_a(R_a+R_{se}) \\ 
 &= 200-10(1)=190V\\ 
 N_1&= 1000rpm
\end{aligned}[/latex] Load torque increased by 44%  [latex](T\propto I_a^2)[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \; \frac{T_2}{T_1} &=\left ( \frac{I_{a2}}{I_{a1}} \right )^2 \\ 
\Rightarrow \;\; \frac{1.44T_1}{T_1} &=\left ( \frac{I_{a2}}{10} \right )^2  \\ 
 \therefore \;\; I_{a2}^2&= 144\\ 
 I_{a2}&= 12A\\ 
&\text{At same voltage,}\\
 E_{b2}&=V-I_{a2}(R_a+R_{se}) \\ 
\therefore \;\; E_{b2} &= 200-12(1)=188V\\ 
 &\text{For series motor,}\\ 
 N&\propto \frac{E_b}{\phi }\;\;(\phi \propto I_a) \\ 
 \frac{N_2}{N_1}&=\frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}} \times \frac{I_{a1}}{I_{a2}}\\ 
\frac{N_2}{1000} &=\frac{188}{190}\times \frac{10}{12} \\
N_2&=824.56\; \text{rpm}\\ 
&\simeq 825\; \text{rpm}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A 3-phase 900kVA, [latex]3kV/\sqrt{3}kV(\Delta /Y)[/latex], 50Hz transformer has primary (high voltage side) resistance per phase of 0.3 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and secondary (low voltage side) resistance per phase of 0.02 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. Iron loss of the transformer is 10 kW. The full load % efficiency of the transformer operated at unity power factor is _______ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]900kVA, \Delta /Y, 3-[/latex]phase transformer [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}\;\; R_1 &=300W/ph \\ R_2&= 0.02 W/ph\\ \text{Iron loss}&=10kW \end{aligned}[/latex] Primary line current, [latex]I_{l_1}=\frac{900 \times 1000}{\sqrt{3} \times 3000}=173.2A [/latex] Primary phase current, [latex]I_{ph_1}=100A[/latex] Secondary line current, [latex]I_{l_2}=\frac{900 \times 1000}{\sqrt{3} \times 1732}=300A[/latex] Secondary phase current [latex]I_{ph_2}=300A [/latex] Cu loss of H.V. side [latex]=3 \times I_1^2 R_1=3(100)^2 (0.3) =9000 Watts[/latex] Cu loss of L.V. side [latex]= 3 \times _2^2 \times R_2 =3(300)^2(0.02)=5400Watts [/latex] Full load efficiency at u.p.f. [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=\frac{1 \times 900 \times 1000 \times 1}{1 \times 900 \times 1000+9000+5400+10000} \\ &= \frac{900000}{924400}\\ \therefore \;\;\eta &=\eta 0.9736 \; \text{or} \; 97.36\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A transformer with toroidal core of permeability [latex]\mu[/latex]  is shown in the figure. Assuming uniform flux density across the circular core cross-section of radius [latex]r\lt \lt R[/latex], and neglecting any leakage flux, the best estimate for the mean radius R is
solution:
Since we know reluctance of core: [latex]\Re =\frac{l_c}{\mu a}[/latex] Here, [latex] l_c= [/latex] mean core length, a= area of core reluctance, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\Re &=\frac{2 \pi R}{\mu  \times \pi r^2}\\
&=\frac{2R}{\mu r^2}\\
[\text{where} R &= \text{mean radius of core}] \\ 
\text{or}\;\; R&=\frac{\Re \mu r^2}{2} \\ 

\text{and}\;\; \Re &= \frac{mmf}{flux}=\frac{N_pI_p}{\phi }\\ 
\text{Here,}\;\; \phi &=-\frac{1}{N_p}\int_{0}^{t}e\;dt \\ 
[\text{where}\; e &\text{is primary generated voltage}] \\ 
\text{or}\;\;  \phi  &=-\frac{1}{N_p}\int_{0}^{t}-(V_p)\;dt \\ 
 \phi &= \frac{1}{N_p}\int_{0}^{t}V \cos \omega t \;dt\\ 
 &= \frac{V}{\omega N_p}\sin \omega t\\ 
 &\text{Now reluctance} \\ 
 \Re &= \frac{N_p I \sin \omega t}{\frac{V}{\omega N_p} \sin \omega t}\\ 
 &= \frac{N_p^2\omega I}{V}\\
& \text{So mean radius,}\\
R&=\frac{N_p^2 \times \omega I \times \mu r^2}{2V}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 A separately excited dc motor has an armature resistance [latex]R_{a}= 0.05\Omega[/latex]. The field excitation is kept constant. At an armature voltage of 100 V, the motor produces a torque of 500 Nm at zero speed. Neglecting all mechanical losses, the no-load speed of the motor (in radian/s) for an armature voltage of 150 V is _____ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Given separately initiated DC motor, Field excitaion is constant, Producing a torque of 500 N-m [latex]\begin{aligned}
&\text{At zero speed,}\\
 \because \; N&= 0,\; E_b=0\\ 
E_b &= V-I_aR_a\\ 
 0&= 100-I_a(0.05)\\ 
\therefore \; I_{a1} &=\frac{100}{0.05} =2000A\\ 
T &= \frac{60}{2 \pi N}E_bI_a\\ 
 &= \frac{60}{2 \pi N}\frac{\phi ZNP}{60A}\cdot I_a\\ 
\text{Let,}\;\; T_1&=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\frac{ZP}{A}\phi I_{a1}\;\text{N-m} \\ 
\text{Let,}\;\; T_1 &=kI_{a1} \\ 
\text{where,}\;\; k &= \frac{1}{2 \pi}\frac{ZP \phi}{A}\\ 
T_1 &= 500 \text{N-m}, \\
I_{a1}&=2000A\\
k&=\frac{500}{2000}=0.25
\end{aligned}[/latex] When motor runs on no-load given all mechanical losses neglected. No-load current is negligible and the voltage drop at no-load can be negligible. [latex]\begin{aligned}
\therefore \;\;E_b &\simeq V=150V \\ 
 E_b&= \frac{\phi ZNP}{60A}\\ 
\text{Already solved,}\\
 k&=\frac{1}{2\pi} \frac{ZP \phi }{A}\\ 
 \therefore \;\;\frac{ZP \phi }{A} &=2 \pi (k) \\ 
 \therefore \;\; E_b &= 2 \pi (k) \cdot \frac{N}{60}\\ 
\therefore \;\; E_b&= k \times \omega \\ 
(\omega : & \text{No-load speed in rad/sec})\\
\therefore \;\;\omega  &= \frac{E_b}{k}\\ 
\therefore \;\;\omega  &= \frac{150}{0.25}\\ 
\omega &= 600 \text{rad/sec}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 In a salient pole synchronous motor, the developed reluctance torque attains the maximum value when the load angle in electrical degrees is
solution: Salient pole synchronous motor power and torque relations per phase: [latex]P=\frac{E_bV}{X_t}\sin \delta +\frac{V^2}{2}\left ( \frac{X_d-X_q}{X_dX_q} \right ) \sin (2\delta ) \;Watts [/latex] [latex]T=\frac{60}{2 \pi N_S}\left [ \frac{E_bV}{X_d} \sin \delta + \frac{V^2}{2}\left ( \frac{X_d-X_q}{X_dX_q} \right ) \sin (2\delta ) \right ]\; N-m[/latex] The second term is reluctance power or reluctance torque, which is directly proportional to [latex]\sin 2\delta[/latex]. Therefore, reluctance torque will be maximum. When,  [latex]\delta =45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]\because \;\;\sin2 (45^{\circ})\Rightarrow \sin 90^{\circ}=1[/latex] (Maximum)

question: Question 57 A single-phase 100 kVA, 1000 V / 100 V, 50 Hz transformer has a voltage drop of 5% across its series impedance at full load. Of this, 3% is due to resistance.  The percentage regulation of the transformer at full load with 0.8 lagging power factor is
solution: Percent voltage regulation [latex]=\left ( \frac{I_2R_{02}}{E_2} \times 100 \right )\cos \phi _2\pm \left ( \frac{I_2X_{02}}{E_2} \times 100 \right ) \sin \phi _2 [/latex] [latex]\% \; VR.=V_r \cos \phi _2\pm V_x \sin \phi _2 [/latex] (where, '+' lag p.f. and '-' lead p.f.) At full load: Given,  [latex]V_r=3\% [/latex] Impedance drop, [latex]V_z=5\% [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Reluctance drop, [latex]V_x=\sqrt{5^2-3^2}=4\% [/latex] Voltage regulation at full load at 0.8 p.f. lagging [latex]V.R.=3(0.8)+4(0.6)=4.8\%[/latex]

question:
Question 58 A 3-phase 50 Hz generator supplies power of 3MW at 17.32 kV to a balanced 3-phase inductive
load through an overhead line. The per phase line resistance and reactance are
0.25[latex]\Omega[/latex] and 3.925[latex]\Omega[/latex] respectively. If the voltage at the generator terminal is 17.87 kV, the power factor of the load is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_S-V_R&=I(R \cos \phi +X_L \sin \phi) \\I &=\frac{P_R}{V_R \cos \phi } \\ V_S-V_R&= \frac{P_R}{V_R \cos \phi } (R \cos \phi +X_L \sin \phi )\\ \tan \phi &= \left ( \frac{V_SV_R-V_R^2-RP_R}{X_LP_R} \right )\\ \phi &=\tan ^{-1} \left [\frac{V_SV_R-V_R^2-RP_R}{X_LP_R} \right ]\\ &\;\Rightarrow \;\text{substitute all values} \\ \text{power factor} &= \cos \phi =0.8 \; \text{lag} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 59 A 120 V DC shunt motor takes 2 A at no load. It takes 7 A on full load while running at 1200
rpm. The armature resistance is 0.8 [latex]\Omega[/latex] , and the shunt field resistance is 240[latex]\Omega[/latex] . The no load speed, in rpm, is _______________.
solution: Shunt motor take 7A  on full load and runs at 1200 rpm. [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; E_{b1} &=120-65(0.8) \\ E_{b1} &= 114.8V\\ N_1&=1200\;\text{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Shunt motor takes 2A at no load [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{b2} &=120-1.5(0.8)=118.8 \\ & \text{For shunt motor,}\\ \frac{N_2}{N_1} &= \frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}}\\ \therefore \; N_2&=\frac{118.8}{114.8}\times 1200\\ &=1241.81 \text{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 If the primary line voltage rating is 3.3 kV (Y side) of a 25 kVA. Y-[latex]\Delta[/latex] transformer (the per phase turns ratio is 5:1), then the line current rating of the secondary side (in Ampere) is_____.
solution: From turn ratio, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_2 &=381 V/phase \\ V_{2 \; line}&= 381 V\\ \sqrt{3} V_2I_2&= 25000\\ \therefore \;\; I_2&=\frac{25000}{\sqrt{3} \times 381}=37.88A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 61 A 25 kVA, 400 V, [latex]\Delta[/latex]-connected, 3-phase, cylindrical rotor synchronous generator requires a field current of 5A to maintain the rated armature current under short-circuit condition. For the same field current, the open-circuit voltage is 360 V. Neglecting the armature resistance and
magnetic saturation, its voltage regulation (in % with respect to terminal voltage), when the
generator delivers the rated load at 0.8 pf leading, at rated terminal voltage is _________.
solution: 25 kVA, 400 V, [latex]\Delta -[/latex]synchronous generator [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \;\; I_{rated} &=\frac{25000}{\sqrt{3}\times 400}=36.085A \\ I_{phase}&=\frac{36.085}{\sqrt{3}}=20.83A \\ X_3 &=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{V_{OC}}{I_{a_{rated}}} \end{matrix}\right|_{I_{f_{same}}} \\ \therefore \;\;X_s &= \frac{360}{20.83}=17.28\Omega /phase\\ E &=\sqrt{(V \cos \phi +I_aR_a)^2+(V \sin \phi -I_aX_s)^2} \\ &=\sqrt{(400 \times 0.8)^2 +(400 \times 0.6 - 20.83(17.28))^2} \\ &=\sqrt{(102400)+(240-360)^2} \\ &= 341.76V\\ \therefore \;\; \% V.R. &= \frac{E-V}{V} \times 100\\ &=\frac{341.76-400}{400} \times 100=-14.56\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 62 A star-connected, 12.5 kW, 208 V (line), 3-phase, 60 Hz squirrel cage induction motor has
following equivalent circuit parameters per phase referred to the stator: [latex]R_{1}=0.3\Omega ,R_{2}=0.3\Omega ,X_{1}=0.41\Omega ,X_{2}=0.41\Omega[/latex]. Neglect shunt branch in the equivalent circuit. The starting current (in Ampere) for this motor when connected to an 80 V (line), 20 Hz, 3-phase AC source is __________.
solution: Equivalent circuit representation during starting -according to question Total resistance to stator [latex]=0.6\Omega[/latex] Total reactance reference to stator [latex]=0.82\Omega[/latex] Reactance for [latex]60Hz \;\rightarrow \;0.82\Omega[/latex] Reactance for [latex]60Hz \;\rightarrow ?[/latex] [latex]\because \;\; X_e\propto F [/latex] Reactance for [latex]20Hz\;\Rightarrow \; \frac{20}{60} \times 0.82 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;[/latex] X for 20 Hz frequency[latex] =0.273\Omega[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\;[/latex] Starting current [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; I_{st}=\frac{80\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{(0.6)^2+(0.273)^2}}=70.05A[/latex]

question:
Question 63 A 220 V, 10 kW, 900 rpm separately excited DC motor has an armature resistance [latex]R_a=0.02\Omega[/latex].
When the motor operates at rated speed and with rated terminal voltage, the electromagnetic
torque developed by the motor is 70 Nm. Neglecting the rotational losses of the machine, the
current drawn by the motor from the 220 V supply is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\text{Neglecting rotor loss,}&\\
E_bI_a &= 10kW\\ 
(V-I_aR_a)I_a &= 10kW\\ 
(220-I_a(0.02))I_a &= 10000\\ 
220I_a-0.02I_a^2-10000 &=0 \\ 
 0.02I_a^2-220I_a+10000&=0\\
\text{By sloving,}\;\; & I_a=45.75A\\
\text{Torque corrosponding,}&\\ 
T&=\frac{60}{2\pi N}E_bI_a\\
\therefore \; T&=\frac{60}{2 \pi (900)}10000\\
&=106.15N-m
\end{aligned}[/latex] Separately excited motor, [latex]\therefore \;\;T \propto I_a[/latex] For a torque 106.15 N-m [latex]I_a=45.75A[/latex] For a torque 70 N-m, New  [latex]I_a=\frac{70 \times 45.75}{106.15}=30.16A[/latex]

question: Question 64 If a synchronous motor is running at a leading power factor, its excitation induced voltage ([latex]E_f[/latex]) is
solution: Synchonnous motor-leading p.f. over excited. [latex]\therefore \;\;E_f \gt V_t[/latex]

question:
Question 65 A 3-phase, 4-pole, 400 V, 50 Hz squirrel-cage induction motor is operating at a slip of 0.02. The
speed of the rotor flux in mechanical rad/sec, sensed by a stationary observer, is closest to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_s &= \frac{120 \times 50}{4}=1500\; \text{rpm}\\ s &=0.02 \\ N&=N_s(1-s) \\ &=1500(1-0.02) \\ &=1470 \; \text{rpm} \end{aligned} [/latex] As it was specified rotor rmf with respect to stationary part/sector. Rotor rmf w.r.t. stator is always at [latex]N_s.[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;[/latex]  Speed of rotor flux in mechanical radian/sec. [latex] =\frac{2 \times 3.14 \times 1500}{60}=157 \; rad/sec[/latex]

question: Question 66 A three-phase, three winding [latex]\Delta / \Delta / Y[/latex]  (1.1kV/6.6kV/400 V) transformer is energized from AC mains at the 1.1 kV side. It supplies 900 kVA load at 0.8 power factor lag from the 6.6 kV winding and 300 kVA load at 0.6 power factor lag from the 400 V winding. The RMS line current in ampere drawn by the 1.1 kV winding from the mains is _______.
solution: Load on 6.6 kV winding = 900 kVA @0.8 pf lag [latex]\therefore \;\; I_2=\frac{900 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times 6.6 \times 10^3}[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\;=78.73\angle -36.86^{\circ} A [/latex] Transforamtion Ratio [latex]\begin{aligned} k &=\frac{1.1}{6.6}=\frac{1}{6} \\ \therefore \;\; I'_2&=\frac{I_2}{k}=472.4\angle -36.86^{\circ} A \end{aligned}[/latex] Load on 400 V winding = 300 kVA at 0.6 p.f. [latex]\therefore \;\; I_3=\frac{300 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times 400}[/latex]  [latex]=433.025\angle -53.13^{\circ}A [/latex] Transformation ratio [latex]= \frac{1.1 \times 1000}{\frac{400}{\sqrt{3}}}=4.76 [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} I'_3 &=\frac{I_3}{k}=\frac{4333.025}{4.76} \\ &= 90.97\angle -53.13^{\circ}A \end{aligned}[/latex] So, line value of current [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\sqrt{3} \times 90.97\angle -53.13^{\circ} \\ &= 157.56 \angle -53.13^{\circ} \end{aligned} [/latex] Current drawn by 1.1 kV winding will be [latex]\begin{aligned} I_1&=I'_2+I'_3 \\ &=472.4\angle -36.86 +157.56\angle -53.13^{\circ} \\ &=377.96 -j283.37 +94.53 -126.04 \\ &= 472.49 -j409.41\\ &= 625.19\angle -40.9^{\circ}A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 67 Two parallel connected, three-phase, 50Hz, 11kV, star-connected synchronous machines A and
B, are operating as synchronous condensers. They together supply 50 MVAR to a 11 kV grid.
Current supplied by both the machines are equal. Synchronous reactances of machine A and
machine B are 1[latex]\Omega[/latex] and 3[latex]\Omega[/latex] respectively. Assuming the magnetic circuit to be linear, the ratio of excitation current of machine A to that of machine B is ________.
solution: Synchronous machine A: 11 kV, 50 Hz, Y connected, [latex]X_s=1\Omega[/latex] Synchronous machine B: 11 kV, 50 Hz, Y connected, [latex]X_s=3\Omega[/latex] Given both supplying only reactive power 50MVAR tp 11 kV grid equally [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; Q_A &=\sqrt{3}VI_A \sin \phi =25mVAR \\ Q_B &= \sqrt{3}VI_B \sin \phi =25mVAR\\ \therefore \;\;I_A &=\frac{25 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3} \times 11 \times 10^3}=1312.2A \\ \therefore \;\; I_B&= 1312.2A\\ E_A &= V-jI_AX_s\\ &=\frac{11 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3}}-j1312.2\angle 90 \times 1 \\ E_B &=V_jI_BX_s \\ &= =\frac{11 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3}}-j1312.2\angle 90 \times 3 \end{aligned} [/latex] Given magnetic circuit to be linear, [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \;\; E &\propto I_f \\ \therefore \;\; \frac{I_{f_A}}{I_{f_B}}&=\frac{E_A}{E_B} \\ E_A&=7663.05V \\ E_B &= 10287.45V \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, ratio of excitation current of machine A to machine B [latex] \frac{E_A}{E_B}=0.745[/latex]

question:
Question 68 A 375W, 230 V, 50 Hz capacitor start single-phase induction motor has the following constants
for the main and auxiliary windings (at starting): [latex]Z_{m}=(24.50+j12.75)\Omega[/latex] (main winding), [latex]Z_{n}=(24.50+j12.75)\Omega[/latex] (auxiliary winding).  Neglecting the magnetizing branch the value of the capacitance (in [latex]\mu[/latex]F ) to be added in series with the auxiliary winding to obtain maximum torque at starting is _______.
solution:
Auxiliary winding impedance [latex]=(24.5+j12.75)\Omega[/latex] Let [latex]X_c[/latex] be the reactance of the capacitor connected in auxiliary winding [latex]
\begin{aligned}
Z_a &= (24.5+j12.75-jX_c)\Omega \\ 
X_a &=(X_c-12.75),\; R_a=24.5\Omega  \\ 
\therefore \;\; \phi _a &=\tan^{-1}\frac{X_c-12.75}{24.5}\;...(i) \\ 
 Z_m&= 12.5+j15.75\\ 
 &= 20.10\angle 51.56^{\circ}\Omega \\ 
 \phi _m&= 51.56^{\circ}
\end{aligned}[/latex] For maximum torque at starting, condition on [latex] \phi _a[/latex] and [latex]\phi _m[/latex] is given by [latex]\left [ \phi _a=\frac{90^{\circ}-\phi _m}{2} \right ][/latex] [latex]
\phi _a=\frac{90-51.56}{2}=19.22^{\circ}}\;...(ii)
[/latex] Comparing equation (i) and (ii), [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\tan(19.22^{\circ}) &=\frac{X_c-12.75}{24.5} \\ 
0.3486 &= \frac{X_c-12.75}{24.5}\\ 
X_c &=8.541+12.75 \\ 
 \text{Capacitive reactance,}& \\ 
X_c &= 21.291\Omega \\ 
 \frac{1}{2 \pi fc}&= 21.291\\ 
 \Rightarrow \;C&= \frac{1}{2\pi \times 50 \times 21.291}\\ 
 &= 149.51\mu F
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 69 A separately excited DC generator supplies 150 A to a 145 V DC grid. The generator is running
at 800 RPM. The armature resistance of the generator is 0.1 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. If the speed of the generator is increased to 1000 RPM, the current in amperes supplied by the generator to the DC grid is _______.
solution: Given, [latex]R_a=0.1\Omega[/latex] As, DC generator is connected with DC grid, the output voltage will be constant. When generator is running at 800 rpm, Generator emf, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{a1} &=V+I_{a1}R-a \\ &= 145+150 \times 0.1\\ &= 160V \end{aligned}[/latex] When generator is running at 1000 rpm, Generator emf, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{a2} &=E_{a1} \times \frac{N_2}{N_1}\\ &= 160 \times \frac{1000}{800}\\ &= 200V \end{aligned}[/latex] So, new armature currrent will be, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{a2} &=\frac{E_{a2}-V}{R_a}\\ &= \frac{200-145}{0.1}\\ &= 550A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 70 A 220 V DC series motor runs drawing a current of 30 A from the supply. Armature and field
circuit resistances are 0.4 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and 0.1 [latex]\Omega[/latex] respectively. The load torque varies as the square of the speed. The flux in the motor may be taken as being proportional to the armature current. To reduce the speed of the motor by 50% the resistance in ohms that should be added in series with the armature is _________.
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
T &\propto N^2 \\ 
 \phi &\propto I_a \\ 
T &\propto I_a^2\\ 
\therefore \; N^2 &\propto I_a^2 \\ 
 \therefore \; \frac{N_2}{N_1}&= \frac{I_{a2}}{I_{a1}}\\ 
 \therefore \; 0.5&= \frac{I_{a2}}{30}\\ 
 \Rightarrow \; I_{a2}&=15A \\ 
&\text{For series motor,}\\
\frac{N_2}{N_1} &= \frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}}\times \frac{I_{a1}}{I_{a2}}\\ 
 \therefore \; 0.5 &= \frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}} \times \frac{30}{15}\\ 
 \therefore \; \frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}}&= 0.25\\ 
E_{b1} &=220-30(0.4+0.1) \\ 
E_{b1} &=205V \\ 
\therefore \; E_{b2}&=51.25V \\ 
\therefore \; E_{b2} &= V-I_{a2}(R_a+R_{se}+R_{ext})\\ 
51.25 &= 220-15(0.4+0.1+R_{ext})\\
\therefore \;R_{ext}&=10.75\Omega 
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question:
Question 71 A 4 pole induction machine is working as an induction generator. The generator supply
frequency is 60 Hz. The rotor current frequency is 5 Hz. The mechanical speed of the rotor in
RPM is
solution: Induction Generator Mode: [latex]\begin{aligned} N & \gt N_s \;\;\text{i.e.(s is negative)} \\ \because \;\; P &=4,\; f=60Hz \\ N_s&=1800 \; \text{rpm} \end{aligned} [/latex] Rotor frequency given [latex]= 5Hz \Rightarrow (s \times f) [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \because \;\; f &=60Hz \\ \therefore \;\; s &=\frac{5}{60}=0.0833 \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\because[/latex]   It is induction generator slip will be -0.0833. [latex]\begin{aligned} s &=\frac{1800-N}{1800}=-0.0833 \\ N &=1950 \; \text{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 72 A three-phase, 50Hz, star-connected cylindrical-rotor synchronous machine is running as a
motor. The machine is operated from a 6.6 kV grid and draws current at unity power factor
(UPF). The synchronous reactance of the motor is 30 [latex]\Omega[/latex] per phase. The load angle is [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex]. The power delivered to the motor in kW is _______.
solution: For synchronous motor, [latex]\bar{V_t}=\bar{E_f}+j\bar{I_a}X_s [/latex] As currrent is drawn at unity power factors. Therefore, [latex] \begin{aligned} E_f \cos \delta &=V_t \\ E_f&= \frac{V_t}{\cos \delta }=\frac{6.6kV}{\sqrt{3}} \times \frac{1}{\cos 30^{\circ}}\\ E_f&= \frac{6.6 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times \sqrt{3}} \times 2V\\ V_t &=\frac{6.6 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \therefore \;\;P_e &=\frac{3V_{ph}E_{ph}}{X_s} \sin \delta \\ &= \frac{3 \times \frac{6.6 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3}} \times \frac{6.6 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times \sqrt{3}} \times 2 }{30} \times \sin 30^{\circ}\\ &=838.3kW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 Three single-phase transformers are connected to form a delta-star three-phase transformer of 110 kV/ 11 kV. The transformer supplies at 11 kV a load of 8 MW at 0.8 p.f. lagging to a nearby plant. Neglect the transformer losses. The ratio of phase currents in delta side to star side is
solution: At, 100 kV, load is 8 MW, 0.8 p.f. lagging [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \;\; \frac{(V_{ph})_{\Delta }}{(V_{ph})_{Y}} &= \frac{(I_{ph})_{Y}}{(I_{ph})_{\Delta }}\\ \Rightarrow \;\; (I_{ph})_{\Delta } &= (I_{ph})_Y \times \frac{(V_{ph})_{Y}}{(V_{ph})_{\Delta }} \\ \frac{(I_{ph})_{\Delta }}{(V_{ph})_{Y}}&=\frac{11\sqrt{3}}{110}=1:10\sqrt{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 74 A single-phase, 2 kVA, 100/200 V transformer is reconnected as an auto-transformer such that its kVA rating is maximum. The new rating, in kVA, is ______.
solution: 2 kVA, 100/200 V transformer, [latex]\begin{aligned} A_{2 winding} &=\frac{200}{100}=2 \\ [(kVA)_{auto}]_{max} &= (a_{2winding}+1)(kVA)_{2winding} \\ &=(2+1) \times 2 =6 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 75 The starting line current of a 415 V, 3-phase, delta connected induction motor is 120 A, when the rated voltage is applied to its stator winding. The starting line current at a reduced voltage of 110 V,
in ampere, is _________.
solution: 415V, 3-phase,  [latex]\Delta[/latex] connected induction motor [latex](I_{st})_{line}=120A[/latex] at rated voltage. at, V=110V, i.e. reduced voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{st} &=x(I_{st})_{rated} \\ \text{where}\;\; x&= \frac{V_{reduced}}{V_{rated}}\\ &=\frac{110}{415} \\ (I_{st})_{at \; 110V} &= \left ( \frac{110}{415} \right )\times 120\\ &=31.807A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 The flux linkage ([latex]\lambda[/latex]) and current (i) relation for an electromagnetic system is [latex]\lambda = (\sqrt{i})/g[/latex]. When i=2A and g (air-gap length)=10cm, the magnitude of mechanical force on the moving part, in N, is ________.
solution: Energy in magnetic system, [latex]\begin{aligned} W_f &= \int_{0}^{\lambda } i(\lambda )\; d\lambda \\ \because \;\; i &=\lambda ^2g^2 \\ W_f &= \int_{0}^{\lambda } \lambda ^2g^2 \; d\lambda \\ &=g^2\frac{\lambda ^3}{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] Now, mechanical force, [latex]\begin{aligned} F_F &=-\frac{\partial W_f (\lambda ,g)}{\partial g} \\ &=-\frac{\partial }{\partial g} \left ( \frac{g^2\lambda ^3}{3} \right )\\ &= -\frac{2}{3}\lambda ^3 g\\ \because \;\; i=2, \;g&=10cm ,\; \lambda =10\sqrt{2} \\ \text{Hence,}\;\;|F_F|&=\frac{2}{3} \times (10\sqrt{2})^3 \times 0.1\\ &=188.56N \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 The power consumption of an industry is 500 kVA, at 0.8 p.f. lagging. A synchronous motor is added to raise the power factor of the industry to unity. If the power intake of the motor is 100 kW, the p.f. of the motor is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_1 &= 500 \times 0.8=400kW\\ Q_1&= 500 \times 0.6=300kVAR \end{aligned}[/latex] The power factor is to be raised to unity The motor has to supply 300kVAR The motor rating is 100 kW, 300kVAR [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi _m &=\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{Q}{P} \right ) \\ \phi _m&= \tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{300}{100} \right ) =71.56 \end{aligned} [/latex] Power factor of motor [latex]= \cos \phi _m=\cos 71.56=0.316[/latex]

question: Question 79 A single-phase, 22 kVA, 2200 V/ 220 V, 50 Hz, distribution transformer is to be connected as an auto-transformer to get an output voltage of 2420 V. Its maximum kVA rating as an autotransformer is
solution: 22 KVA, 2200 V/220 V, 50Hz Distribution transformer is to be connected as on auto transformer to get an output voltage of 2420V. [latex](kVA)_{maximum}[/latex] as an auto transformer=? as voltage rating is 2420 i.e. (2200+220)V additive polarity, [latex]\begin{aligned} (kVA)_{auto} &= (a_{2winding}+1) \times (kVA)_{2 winding}\\ \text{where, } \;\; a_{2winding}&=\frac{2200}{220}=10 \\ (kVA)_{auto} &= (10+1) \times 22 =242 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 A three-phase, 50 Hz salient-pole synchronous motor has a per-phase direct-axis reactance ([latex]X_{d}[/latex]) of 0.8 pu and a per-phase quadrature-axis reactance ([latex]X_{q}[/latex]) of 0.6 pu. Resistance of the machine is negligible. It is drawing full-load current at 0.8 pf (leading). When the terminal voltage is 1 pu, per-phase induced voltage, in pu, is _________.
solution: Synchronous motor at leading p.f. [latex]\begin{aligned} X_d &=0.8 \\ \phi &= 36.86\\ X_q&= 0.6\\ R_q&= 0\\ \tan \psi &=\frac{V \sin \phi +I_aX_a}{V \cos \phi }\\ \psi &=56.30 \end{aligned} [/latex] For synchronous motor at leading p.f. [latex]\begin{aligned} \psi &=\phi +\delta \\ \delta &=19.70^{\circ} \\ E&=V \cos \delta +I_dX_d \\ I_d&=I_a \sin f=0.831 \\ E&=(1)\cos (19.7)+(0.831)(0.8) \\ &=1.606 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 81 A DC shunt generator delivers 45 A at a terminal voltage of 220 V. The armature and the shunt
field resistances are 0.01 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and 44 [latex]\Omega[/latex] respectively. The stray losses are 375 W. The percentage efficiency of the DC generator is ____________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Stay losses} &= 375 \; \text{Watt}\\ & \text{Total copper losses}\\ &= I_a^2R_a+I_{sh}^2R_{sh}\\ &= 50^2 \times (0.01)+(5^2)\times 44\\ &= 1125\; \text{Watt}\\ h &=\frac{\text{Output}}{\text{Output}+\text{losses}} \\ &= \frac{220 \times 45}{220 \times 45+(1125)+375}\\ &= 0.86842 \;\text{or} \; 86.84\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 A single-phase 400 V, 50 Hz transformer has an iron loss of 5000 W at the rated condition. When operated at 200 V, 25 Hz, the iron loss is 2000 W. When operated at 416 V, 52 Hz, the value of the hysteresis loss divided by the eddy current loss is ______.
solution: 400V, 50Hz transformer, [latex]P_i=5000Watt[/latex] When, 200V, 25Hz, [latex]P_i=2000 Watt[/latex] 416V, 52Hz,  [latex]\frac{P_h}{P_e}=? [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} P_i &=P_h+P_e \\ P_h & \propto f B_m^x \\ P_e& \propto f^2B_m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] as in the problem [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V}{f}&=\frac{400}{50}=\frac{416}{52}=8 \\ P_h&=Af \\ P_e&=Bf^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] From given data, [latex]\begin{aligned} 2000 &=(P_{25hZ})){i} \\ &= A(25)+B(25)^2\;\;...(i)\\ 5000 &=(P_{50Hz})_i \\ &= A(50)+B(50)^2\;\;...(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=60,\;\; B=0.8 \\ (P_h)_{52Hz}&=Af=60 \times 52 \\ &= 3120 Watt\\ (P_e)_{52Hz}&=Bf^2=0.8 \times (52)^2 \\ &= 2163.2 Watt\\ \frac{(P_h)_{52Hz}}{(P_e)_{52Hz}}&=\frac{3120}{2163.2}=1.4423 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 Consider a system consisting of a synchronous generator working at a lagging power factor, a synchronous motor working at an overexcited condition and a directly grid-connected induction generator. Consider capacitive VAr to be a source and inductive VAr to be a sink of reactive power. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: Synchronous generator working at a lagging power factor, will supply active power and lagging reactive power, so this is source. Synchronous motor working at an overexcited condition i.e. leading p.f. operation so it will take active power and leading reactve power in other words taking active power and supplying lagging reactive power. Induction generates active power but as there is no dc excitation in rotor so it takes lagging reactive power.

options.A: Synchronous motor and synchronous generator are sources and induction generator is a sink of reactive power
options.B: Synchronous motor and induction generator are sources and synchronous generator is a sink of reactive power
options.C: Synchronous motor is a source and induction generator and synchronous generator are sinks of reactive power.
options.D: All are sources of reactive power.

If the same armature coils are reconnected to form a lap winding, what is the rated voltage (in volts) and power (in kW) respectively at 1200 rpm of the reconnected machine if the field circuit is left unchanged ?
solution: A=2, separately excited dc machine [latex]R_a\approx 0, 230V, 5kW, [/latex]  [latex]N=1200 \text{rpm} [/latex] For wave winding, [latex]230=\frac{\phi \times 4 \times 1200 \times Z_1}{60 \times 2}\;...(i) [/latex] For lap winding, [latex]V=\frac{\phi \times 4 \times 1200 \times Z_1}{60 \times 4}\;...(ii) [/latex] Dividing equation (i) by equation (ii), [latex]\frac{230}{V}=\frac{4}{2} \Rightarrow \; V=115V [/latex] For Power: Wave: Total conductor in single path [latex]=\frac{Z}{2}[/latex] Let, resistance of [latex]=\frac{Z}{2}[/latex] conductor =R Total resistance, [latex]P_1=\frac{V_1^2}{R_1}=\frac{V_1^2}{R/2}\;...(i)[/latex] Total conductor in single path [latex]=\frac{Z}{4}[/latex] Let, resistance of single path [latex]=\frac{R}{2}[/latex] Total resistance [latex]=\frac{R/2}{4}=\frac{R}{8}[/latex] [latex]P_2=\frac{V_2^2}{R_2}=\frac{V_2^2}{R/8}\;...(ii)[/latex] By equation (i) and (ii), [latex]\frac{P_1}{P_2}=\frac{V_1^2/(R/2)}{V_2^2(R/8)}[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{(230)^2}{R/2}\times \frac{R/8}{(715)^2}=1[/latex]

question: Question 94 The figure shows the per-phase equivalent circuit of a two-pole three-phase induction motor operating at 50 Hz. The "air-gap" voltage, [latex]V_{g}[/latex] across the magnetizing inductance, is 210 V rms, and the slip, s, is 0.05. The torque (in Nm) produced by the motor is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i &=\frac{210}{1+j0.22} \\ &=205.09\angle -12.40^{\circ} \\ \text{Active power} &= (205.09)^2 \times 1=P_g\\ P_m &= (1-0.05) \times P_g \\ P_m &= 39958.81 \; \text{Watt}\\ \text{Torque} &= \frac{39958.81 \times 60}{2 \pi \times 2850} \times 3\\ &= 133.88 \times 3=401.64 N-m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 97 A DC motor has the following specifications: 10 hp, 37.5 A, 230 V; flux/pole = 0.01 Wb, number of poles = 4, number of conductors = 666, number of parallel paths = 2. Armature resistance = 0.267 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The armature reaction is negligible and rotational losses are 600 W. The motor operates from a 230 V DC supply. solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E_b &=\frac{\phi ZNP}{60A} =222V\\ I_a&= \frac{V-E_b}{P_a}\\ &= \frac{230-222}{0.267}\\ &=29.9625A \\ T &=\frac{60}{2\pi (1000)}[222 \times 29.96-600] \\ &= 57.8 N-m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 A separately excited DC motor runs at 1000 rpm on no load when its armature terminals are connected to a 200V DC source and the rated voltage is applied to the field winding. The armature resistance of this motor is 1[latex]\Omega[/latex]. The no-load armature current is negligible. With the motor developing its full load torque, the armature voltage is set so that the rotor speed is 500 rpm. When the load torque is reduced to 50% of the full load value under the same armature voltage conditions, the speed rises to 520 rpm. Neglecting the rotational losses, the full load armature current (in Ampere) is _______.
solution: [latex]V_t=200V, N=1000 \text{rpm}, I_{a0}=0A\;...(1) [/latex] [latex]V_t=V(say), N=500\text{rpm}, T_d=T_{fL}\;...(2)[/latex] [latex] V_t=V(said),N=520\text{rpm}, [/latex] [latex]T'_L=\frac{T_L}{2}=\frac{T_{FL}}{2}\;\;...(3)[/latex] [latex] P_{lossws}=0 [/latex] [latex]R_a=1\Omega[/latex] From condition (1), [latex]E_b=V_t-I_aR_a [/latex] [latex]E_{b_1}=200V, N=1000\text{rpm} [/latex] Since from (2), [latex]\begin{aligned} N_2 &=500\text{rpm} \\ E_{b_2} &=\frac{500 \times 200}{1000}=100V \\ E_{b_2} &= V-I_{fL}R_a\\ 100 &= V-I_{fL}R_a\\ 100 &= V-I_{fL}\;...(4)\\ & \text{Again (3)},\\ N_3 &= 520 \text{rpm}\\ E_{b_3}&= \frac{520 \times 200}{1000}=104V\\ & \text{as we know}\\ 104&=V-\frac{I_{fL}}{2}\times R \\ &= V-\frac{I_{fL}}{2}\;...(5)\\ &\text{From equation (4) and (5),}\\ 100 + I_{fL}&= 104+\frac{I_{fL}}{2}\\ \text{on solving,} I_{fL}&=8A \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 101 The self inductance of the primary winding of a single phase, 50 Hz, transformer is 800 mH, and that of the secondary winding is 600 mH. The mutual inductance between these two windings is 480 mH. The secondary winding of this transformer is short circuited and the primary winding is connected to a 50 Hz, single phase, sinusoidal voltage source. The current flowing in both the windings is less than their respective rated currents. The resistance of both windings can be neglected. In this condition, what is the effective inductance (in mH) seen by the source?
solution: Self inductance of primary coil is 500 mH. Self inductance of secondary coil is 600 mH. Mutual inductance is 480 mH. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{So,} \;\; L_1&=800mH \\ L_2&=600 mH \\ M &=480mH \end{aligned}[/latex] The voltage source [latex]V_1[/latex] is sinusoidal with frequency 50 Hz. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{So,} \;\; V_2&=L_2 \frac{dI_2}{dt}+\frac{MdI_1}{dt} \\ V_2&=0 \\ \text{So,} \;\; j\omega L_2I_2 &=-j\omega MI_1 \\ \text{So,} \;\; I_2&=-I_1 \frac{M}{L_2}=-\frac{4}{5}I_1 \\ \text{Now,} \;\; V_1&= L_1 \frac{dI_1}{dt}+\frac{MdI_2}{dt} \\ V_1 &=j\omega L_1I_1+j\omega MI_2 \\ V_1&=j\omega [L_1I_1+MI_2] \\ V_1&=j\omega [800mH-384mH]I_1 \\ \frac{V_1}{I_1}&=j\omega [416mH] \end{aligned}[/latex] So, equivalent inductance is [latex]416 mH.[/latex]

question: Question 102 A separately excited DC generator has an armature resistance of 0.1[latex]\Omega[/latex] and negligible armature inductance. At rated field current and rated rotor speed, its open-circuit voltage is 200 V. When this generator is operated at half the rated speed, with half the rated field current, an un-charged 1000 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor is suddenly connected across the armature terminals. Assume that the speed remains unchanged during the transient. At what time (in microsecond) after the capacitor is connected will the voltage across it reach 25 V?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R_a &= 0.1\Omega \\ V_{OC}&= 200V\\ I'_{f}&= \frac{I_f}{2}\\ \omega '&= \frac{\omega _{rated}}{2}\\ E_g&= k\phi \omega \\ E'_g&= k\frac{\phi }{2} \times \frac{\omega }{2}\\ &= \frac{200}{4}=50V\\ V&=V(\infty )-[V(\infty )-V(0)]e^{-t/T} \\ &= 50-[50-0]e^{-t/T} \\ 25&= 50[1-e^{-t/RC} ]\\ \frac{1}{2}&= 1-e^{-t/100 \times 10^{-6}}\\ e^{-t/10^{-4}}&= \frac{1}{2}\\ t&=0.693 \times 10^{-4}\\ &=69.3\mu s \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 103 The parameters measured for a 220 V/110 V, 50 Hz, single phase transformer are : Self inductance of primary winding = 45mH Self inductance of secondary winding = 30 mH Mutual inductance between primary and secondary windings = 20 mH Using the above parameters, the leakage ([latex]L_{l1},L_{l2}[/latex]) and magnetizing ([latex]L_{m}[/latex]) inductance
as referred to primary side in the equivalent circuit respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_1 &=45mH \\ L_2 &=30mH \\ M&= 20 mH\\ a &= 2(220/110V)\\ L_1 -aM&=45 -2 \times 20=5mH \\ a^2L_2-aM&=2^2 \times 30 -2 \times 20=80mH \\ aM&= 2 \times 20 =40 mH \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 104 The load shown in the figure absorbs 4 kW at a power factor of 0.89 lagging Assuming the transformer to be ideal, the value of the reactance X to improve
the input power factor to unity is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_2 &=\frac{4 \times 10^3}{110 \times 0.89}=40.86\angle -27.13^{\circ} \\ I_1 &=\frac{40.86}{2} \angle -27.13^{\circ} \\ &= 20.43\angle -27.13^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] For unity pf horizontal component of [latex](I_1)[/latex] should be cancelled with [latex](I_x)[/latex]. So,  [latex]20.43 \sin (27.13^{\circ})=\frac{220}{X} [/latex] [latex]X=23.61\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 105 A separately excited 300 V DC shunt motor under no load runs at 900 rpm
drawing an armature current of 2 A. The armature resistance is 0.5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and leakage inductance is 0.01 H. When loaded, the armature current is 15 A. Then, the speed in rpm is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}\;\; V &= 300 \text{volt, no load speed} \\ &=900 \text{rpm, no load current}\\ I_{a_0}&=2A \\ &\therefore \; \text{No load induced emf}\\ E_{a_0}&=V-I_{a_0}R\\ &=300-2 \times 0.5\\ &=299 \text{volt}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Also, full load armature current, [latex]I_{a_f}=15A [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] induced emf in armature at load, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{a_f}&=V-I_{a_f}R_a \\ &= 300-15 \times 0.5\\ &= 292.5 \text{volt} \end{aligned} [/latex] Let the speed of motor during loaded condition be N. We know that: [latex]\begin{aligned} E_a &\propto \phi N \\ \text{or} \;\; E_a&\propto N\;\;(\phi =\text{constant}) \\ \therefore \; \frac{N}{N_0} &=\frac{E_{a_f}}{E_{a_0}} \\ N&= \frac{E_{a_f}}{E_{a_0}} N_0\\ &= \frac{292.5}{299} \times 900\\ N&=880.43 \text{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 106 A non-salient pole synchronous generator having synchronous reactance of 0.8
pu is supplying 1 pu power to a unity power factor load at a terminal voltage of
1.1 pu. Neglecting the armature resistance, the angle of the voltage behind the
synchronous reactance with respect to the angle of the terminal voltage in degrees
is _______.
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} X_s &= 0.8 \;\text{pu} \\ \cos \phi &=1 \\ V&= 1.1\angle 0^{\circ}\; \text{pu(reference voltage)}\\ P&=1 \;\text{pu} \end{aligned} [/latex] Let,  [latex] E_f\angle \delta[/latex] be the excitation voltage Now, power supplied =1 pu [latex]\begin{aligned} VI_a\cos \phi &= 1\\ I_a &= \frac{1}{V \cos \phi }\\ &= \frac{1}{1.1 \times 1}=0.91 \;\text{pu}\\ \text{Now,}\;\;\vec{E_f} \angle \delta &=\vec{V}+j\vec{I_a}X_s \\ &=1.1\angle 0^{\circ}+j(0.91) \times 0.8\\ &=1.1+j0.728\\ &=1.319\angle 33.49^{\circ}\;\text{pu}\\ \therefore \;\; E_f\angle \delta &=1.319\angle 33.49^{\circ}\;\text{pu} \end{aligned} [/latex] Hence, the angle of the voltage behind the synchronous reactance =Power angle [latex](\delta ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\; \delta =33.49[/latex]
