Question 107 An open circuit test is performed on 50 Hz transformer, using variable frequency
source and keeping V/f ratio constant, to separate its eddy current and hysteresis
losses. The variation of core loss/frequency as function of frequency is shown in
the figure The hysteresis and eddy current losses of the transformer at 25 Hz respectively are
solution:
Let core loss at 25 Hz be [latex]P_0[/latex] per Hz: Then equating the two slopoes of figure, we have: [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{P_0-10}{25}&=\frac{5}{50}  \\ 
 P_0&= 2.5+10=12.5W/Hz 
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \;\; \text{Core loss at} \;\;  25 Hz [/latex]  [latex]= 12.5 \times 25=312.5 watt[/latex] Also, core loss at 50 Hz [latex]= 15 \times 50 =750 watt[/latex] Let at [latex](f_1)[/latex] 25 Hz, eddy current loss [latex]=P_{e1}[/latex] and hysteresis loss [latex]=P_{h1}[/latex]
we know that,[latex] P_{e}\propto  f^2[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \;\; \frac{P_{e2}}{P_{e1}} &=\left ( \frac{f_2}{f_1} \right )^2=\left ( \frac{50}{25} \right )^2=4 \\ 
\therefore \;\; P_{e2} &=4P_{e1} \;\;...(i)\\ 
\text{Also,}\;\; P_h\propto f & \\ 
 \therefore \;\; \frac{P_{h2}}{P_{h1}}&=\frac{f_2}{f_1}=\frac{50}{25}=2 \\ 
 P_{h2}&=2P_{h1}\;\;...(ii) \\ 
\text{Now, at} \;\; f_1&=25Hz,  \\ 
 P_{e1}+P_{h1}&= 312.5\\ \;\;...(iii)
 \text{and  at} \;\; f_2&=50Hz,  \\ 
 P_{e2}+P_{h2}&= 750\\ 
 4P_{e1}+2P_{h1}&=750W \\ 
 2P_{e1}+P_{h1}&=375 W\;\;...(iv) 
\end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equation (iii) and (iv), we get, [latex]
P_{e1}=62.5 W [/latex] and [latex] P_{h1}=250W[/latex] Thus, at 25 Hz, hysteresis loss = 250W and eddy current loss =62.5W

question:
Question 108 The torque speed characteristics of motor ([latex]T_M[/latex]) and load ([latex]T_L[/latex]) for two cases are
shown in the figures (a) and (b). The load torque is equal to motor torque at
points P, Q, R and S. The stable operating points are
solution: [latex]S=\frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s}[/latex] For given system, slip=(2-s)(speed =negative) Below point P, [latex]T_M-T_l \lt 0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] speed decreases [latex]\therefore[/latex] S increases [latex]\therefore[/latex] slip=(2-s) decreases Above point P, [latex]T_m-T_l \gt 0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] speed increases [latex]\therefore[/latex] S decreases and (2-s) increasaes. Thus, system is stable near point P. POINT R: Below point R: [latex]T_M-T_l \lt 0\;\Rightarrow \;[/latex] speed decreases Above point R: [latex]T_M-T_l \gt 0\;\Rightarrow \;[/latex] speed increases Thus, system can't regain stability at point R. Therefore, R is unstable point. POINT S: Below point S: [latex]T_M-T_l \gt 0\;\Rightarrow \;[/latex] speed increases Above point S: [latex]T_M-T_l \lt 0\;\Rightarrow \;[/latex] speed decreases Thus, system can regain stability near point S.

question:
Question 109 The no-load speed of a 230 V separately excited dc motor is 1400 rpm. The
armature resistance drop and the brush drop are neglected. The field current is
kept constant at rated value. The torque of the motor in Nm for an armature
current of 8 A is ________.
solution: Given, [latex]I_a=8A[/latex] No-load speed, [latex]N_0=1400 \; \text{rpm}, [/latex]  [latex]V=230\text{volt} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;\omega _0=\frac{2 \pi}{60}\times N_0 [/latex] [latex]\;\;= \frac{2 \pi}{60}\times 1400=146.6 \;red/s[/latex] Power developed in the motor, [latex]P=E_aI_a[/latex] Also Power, [latex]P=\text{Torque} \times \omega _0 [/latex] or,   [latex] \text{Torque} \;\; T=\frac{P}{\omega _0}=\frac{E_aI_a}{\omega _0} [/latex] Since, armature resistance drop and brush drop are neglected therefore. [latex]\begin{aligned} E_a & \simeq V=230 \text{volt} \\ \therefore \; \text{Torque} , \; T&= \frac{230 \times 8}{146.6}=12.55N-m\\ \therefore \; \text{Torque} , \; T&= 12.55N-m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 110 A single phase induction motor is provided with capacitor and centrifugal switch
in series with auxiliary winding. The switch is expected to operate at a speed of
0.7 Ns, but due to malfunctioning the switch fails to operate. The torque-speed
characteristic of the motor is represented by
solution: The centrifugal switch is used to snaps the load at 70% of synchronous speed. Therefore, the speed-torque characteristic will have kink in speed-torque characteristic at 70% of [latex]N_s[/latex] if the switch operates. When the switch fails to operate, [latex]1- \phi[/latex] induction motor will have torque-speed characteristic similar to a threephase induction motor.

question: Question 111 In a synchronous machine, hunting is predominantly damped by
solution: Hunting is a phenomenon occuring in case of synchronous generator and motor where the machine oscillates about the equilibrium point. To reduce this phenomenon, damper bars are used which are embedded in the rotor pole faces of the synchronous machines. Thus, these damper bars causes additional copper loss in the rotor for damping the undesirable phenomenon of hunting.

question: Question 112 For a single phase, two winding transformer, the supply frequency and voltage are both increased by 10%. The percentage changes in the hysteresis loss and eddy current loss, respectively, are
solution: Eddy current loss, [latex]P_a\propto B_m^2 f^2[/latex] and Hysteresis loss, [latex]\begin{aligned} P_h &\propto B_m^x f\propto B_m^{1.6}f \\ \text{when}\;\; \frac{V}{f} &= \text{constant}, \\ P_e&\propto V^2 \\ \text{and}\;\; P_h &\propto \frac{V^{1.6}}{f^{0.6}} \\ \text{Given} \;\; V_2&=1.1V_1 \\ \text{and}\;\; f_2&= 1.1f_1 \\ \frac{P_{e_2}}{P_{e_1}}=\left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )^2\\ &=(1.1)^2=1.21\\ \frac{P_{e_2}-P_{e_1}}{P_{e_1}}&=0.21 \end{aligned} [/latex] Therefore, % increase in eddy current loss [latex]\begin{aligned} &= \left [ \frac{P_{e_2}-P_{e_1}}{P_{e_1}}\right ] \times 100\%=21\%\\ \text{also}\;\; \frac{P_{h_2}}{P_{h_1}}&= \left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )^{1.6} \times \left ( \frac{f_1}{f_2} \right )^{0.6}\\ &=(1.1)^{1.6} \times \left ( \frac{1}{1.1} \right )^{0.6}=1.1\\ \text{or}\;\; \frac{P_{h_2}-P_{h_1}}{P_{h_1}}&= 0.1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, % increase in hysteresis loss [latex]=\left ( \frac{P_{h_2}-P_{h_1}}{P_{h_1}} \right ) \times 100\%=10\%[/latex] Thus, hysteresis loss increased by 10% and eddy current loss by 21%.

question: Question 113 A 20-pole alternators is having 180 identical stator slots with 6 conductors in each slot. All the coils of a phase are in series. If the coils are connected to realize single-phase winding, the generated voltage is [latex]V_1[/latex]. If the coils are reconnected to realize three phase star connected winding, the generated phase voltage is [latex]V_2[/latex]. Assuming full pitch, single-layer winding, the ratio [latex]V_1/V_2[/latex] is

Question 114 A three phase slip-ring induction motor, provided with a commutator winding, is shown in the figure. The motor rotates in clockwise direction when the rotor windings are closed. If the rotor winding is open circuited and the system is made to run at rotational speed [latex]f_r[/latex] with the help of prime-mover in anti-clockwise direction, then the
frequency of voltage across slip rings is [latex]f_1[/latex] and frequency of voltage across
commutator brushes is [latex]f_2[/latex]. The values of [latex]f_1 \; and \;  f_2[/latex]  respectively are
solution:
Frequency of voltage across slip ring = Frequency of voltage induced in the rotor winding. Let speed corresponding to stator frequency, [latex]f=N_s[/latex]. and speed corresponding to [latex]f_r=N_r[/latex] Then, frequency of rotor induced emf [latex]=f+f_r[/latex] [latex]=f_1\left ( \text{corresponding to} \; f_1 =\frac{(N_s+N_r)P}{120}\right )[/latex] Also, frequency of induced voltage across commutator = stator frequency [latex]=f.
[/latex]

question: Question 115 A 250 V dc shunt machine has armature circuit resistance of 0.6 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and field circuit resistance of 125 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The machine is connected to 250 V supply mains. The motor is operated as a generator and then as a motor separately. The line current of the machine in both the cases is 50 A. The ratio of the speed as a generator to the speed as a motor is _____.
solution: Given, [latex]V=250V, [/latex]  [latex]R_a=0.6\Omega , [/latex]  [latex]R_f=125\Omega , [/latex]  [latex]I_L=50A[/latex]  both for motor as well as generator action. Field current, [latex]I_f=\frac{V}{R_f}=\frac{250}{125}=2A [/latex] [latex]\text{For motor action:} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{a_m}&= V-I_aR_a\\ I_a&=I_l-I_f=50-2=48A \\ \therefore \; E_{a_m}&=250-48 \times 0.6 \\ &=221.2 V \\ \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\text{For generator action:} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{a_g} &=V+I_aR_a \\ I_a &= I_L+I_f=50+2=52A\\ \therefore \; E_{a_g} &=250+52 \times 0.6=281.2V \end{aligned} [/latex] For a DC shunt machine, [latex]E_a\propto \phi \omega _n [/latex] or   [latex] \;\; E_a\propto N  \;\text{(speed)}[/latex]    [latex] (\because \;\phi =constant)[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;\;\frac{E_{a_g}}{E_{a_m}}=\frac{N_g}{N_m} [/latex] [latex]\frac{N_g}{N_m}=\frac{281.2}{221.2}=1.271 [/latex] Therefore, ratio of the speed as a generator to the speed of motor=1.271

question:
Question 116 In a constant V/f control of induction motor, the ratio V/f is maintained
constant from 0 to base frequency, where V is the voltage applied to the motor
at fundamental frequency f . Which of the following statements relating to low
frequency operation of the motor is TRUE ?
solution: In a [latex]3-\phi[/latex] induction motor, induced emf equation per phase is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{{ph}_{1}} &=k_w \sqrt{2} \pi f \phi N_{ph}\approx V_1 \\ \text{where}\;\; \phi &=\text{flux per pole}=1.5\phi _m \\ \phi &\propto \frac{V}{f} \end{aligned} [/latex] Since V/f ratio is constant (to avoid over sluxing), therefore, [latex]\left ( \frac{V}{f} \right )_{\text{rated frequency}} \gt \left ( \frac{V}{f} \right )_{\text{reduced frequency}} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;\phi _{\text{rated}} \gt\phi _{\text{reduced}}[/latex]

options.A: At low frequency, the stator flux increases from its rated value.
options.B: At low frequency, the stator flux decreases from its rated value.
options.C: At low frequency, the motor saturates.
options.D: At low frequency, the stator flux remains unchanged at its rated value.

question: Question 117 A single phase induction motor draws 12 MW power at 0.6 lagging power.  Acapacitor is connected in parallel to the motor to improve the power factor of the combination of motor and capacitor to 0.8 lagging. Assuming that the real and reactive power drawn by the motor remains same as before, the reactive power delivered by the capacitor in MVAR is ______.
solution: Given , motor draws 12 MW at 0.6 pf lag i.e. [latex]\cos \phi =0.6 \;\;\therefore \;\; \sin \phi =0.8 [/latex] [latex]P=12MW Q=\frac{P}{\cos \phi }\times \sin \phi [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{12}{0.6} \times 0.8 =16MVAR[/latex] For improving the power factor to 0.8 lag, Q should be reduced i.e. [latex]\phi[/latex] reduces [latex]\phi '=(16-Q)MVAR[/latex] Where, Q is the reactive power delivered by the capacitor. Now, power factor, [latex]\cos \phi '=0.8[/latex] or   [latex] \phi '=\cos ^{-1}(0.8)=36.86^{\circ} [/latex] from power traingle, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan\phi &=\frac{Q'}{P}\\ Q'&=P \tan \phi ' \\ &=12 \tan 36.86^{\circ} \\ Q'&=8.99 MVAR \\ 16-Q&=8.99 \\ Q&= 16-8.99\\ &= 7.01 MVAR \end{aligned} [/latex] Reactive power delivered by the capacitor, Q=7.07 MVAR

question:
Question 118 A three-phase, 4-pole, self excited induction generator is feeding power to a load
at a frequency [latex]f_1[/latex]. If the load is partially removed, the frequency becomes [latex]f_2[/latex].  If the speed of the generator is maintained at 1500 rpm in both the cases, then
solution: An induction generator always operates at negative slip, i.e.  [latex]\frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s}=S \lt 0[/latex] or [latex]N_s \lt N_r[/latex] As the generator speed is maintained at a constant speed of 1500 rpm. Therefore, the synchronous speed will be less that 1500 rpm in both the cases (i.e. when at full load as well as reduced load). [latex] N_s=1500[/latex] rpm for P=4 and f=50Hz. Thus, for [latex]N_s \lt 1500 \; \text{rpm}, f_1, f_2 \lt 50Hz.[/latex] [latex] \left ( \because \;\; f=\frac{N_s P}{120} \right )[/latex] Also, when load decreases then, frequency increases. Hence, [latex]f_2 \gt f_1[/latex] Therefore, option (C) is correct.

question: Question 119 A single phase, 50 kVA, 1000 V/100 V two winding transformer is connected as an autotransformer as shown in the figure. The kVA rating of the autotransformer is ________.
solution: From the figure, autotransformation ratio, [latex]a_{auto}=\frac{1100}{1000}=\frac{11}{10}[/latex] we know that, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{S_{auto}}{S_{2\; winding}}&=\frac{a_{auto}}{a_{auto}-1}=\left (\frac{\frac{11}{10}}{\frac{11}{10}-1} \right )\\ &=\frac{11}{10} \times \frac{10}{1}=11\\ \therefore \;\;S_{auto}&=11 \times S_{2\; winding}\\ &=11 \times 50kVA=550kVA \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 120 A three phase synchronous generator is to be connected to the infinite bus. The lamps are connected as shown in the figure for the synchronization. The phase sequence of bus voltage is R-Y-B and that of incoming generator voltage is R' - Y' - B'. It was found that the lamps are becoming dark in the sequence [latex]L_a-L_b-L_c[/latex]. It means that the phase sequence of incoming generator is
solution: As, [latex]\begin{aligned} L_a \; \text{is connected between R-R'} & \\ L_b \; \text{is connected between Y-Y'} & \\ L_c \; \text{is connected between B-B'} & \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] therefore, the given method of synchronization is called "synchronization by dark lmap method". In this method of synchronization, correct phase sequence of the incoming generator is obtain when all the three lamps become dark together and bright together. Since lamps are becoming dark in the sequence [latex]L_a-L_b-L_c[/latex] therefore, the phase sequence of incoming generator is opposite to the infinite bus.

options.A: opposite to infinite bus and its frequency is more than infinite bus
options.B: opposite to infinite bus but its frequency is less than infinite bus
options.C: same as infinite bus and its frequency is more than infinite bus
options.D: same as infinite bus and its frequency is less than infinite bus

question: Question 121 A 3 phase, 50 Hz, six pole induction motor has a rotor resistance of 0.1[latex]\Omega[/latex] and reactance of 0.92[latex]\Omega[/latex] . Neglect the voltage drop in stator and assume that the rotor resistance is constant. Given that the full load slip is 3%, the ratio of maximum torque to full load torque is
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} R'_2 &=0.1\Omega \\ X'_2&= 0.92\Omega \\ S_{fl}&=3\%=0.03 \end{aligned}[/latex] Slip at maximum torque, [latex] S_m=\frac{R'_2}{X'_2}=\frac{0.1}{0.92}=0.1087 [/latex] We know that, [latex]\begin{aligned}\frac{T_{fl}}{T_{em}}&=\frac{2}{\left ( \frac{S_m}{S_{fl}}+\frac{S_{fl}}{S_m} \right )}\\ \therefore \;\; \frac{T_{fl}}{T_{em}}&=\frac{2}{\left ( \frac{0.1087}{0.03}+\frac{0.03}{0.1087} \right )}\\ &=\frac{2}{3.623+0.275}=\frac{2}{3.898}\\ \frac{T_{em}}{T_{fl}}&= 1.949 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, ratio of maximum torque to full-load torque [latex]=\frac{T_{em}}{T_{fl}}= 1.949[/latex]

question: Question 122 A 15 kW, 230 V dc shunt motor has armature circuit resistance of 0.4 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and field circuit resistance of 230 [latex]\Omega[/latex] . At no load and rated voltage, the motor runs at 1400 rpm and the line current drawn by the motor is 5 A. At full load, the motor draws a line current of 70 A. Neglect armature reaction. The full load speed of the motor in rpm is_____.
solution: Given, [latex]R_a=0.4\Omega , [/latex] [latex]R_f=230\Omega , [/latex]  [latex]V=230 \;\text{volt} [/latex] At no load, speed, [latex]N_0=1400 \;\text{rpm}, [/latex]  [latex]I_{L_0}=5A [/latex] Field current,  [latex]I_f=\frac{V}{R_f}=\frac{230}{230}=1A[/latex] No load armature current, [latex]I_{a_0}=5-1=4A[/latex] Induced emf at no-load, [latex]E_{a_0}=V-I_{a_0}R_a[/latex] [latex]\;\; \;\;=230-4 \times 0.4=228.4 V [/latex] Also, at full load, [latex]I_{L_{fl}}=70A [/latex] [latex]I_{a_{fl}}=I_{L_{fl}}-I_f=70-1=69A [/latex] Induced emf at full load, [latex]E_{a_{fl}}=V-I_{a{fl}}R_a [/latex] [latex]E_{a_{fl}}=230 -69 \times 0.4=202.4V [/latex] we know that, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_a&\propto \phi \omega _m \alpha \propto N \\ E_a &\propto N \\ (\text{as flux} \; \phi \; &\text{is constant in shunt motor}) \\ \therefore \; \frac{E_{a_{fl}}}{E_{a_{0}}} &=\frac{N_{fl}}{N_0} \\ N_{fl}&= \frac{E_{a_{fl}}}{E_{a_{0}}} \times N_0 \\ &=\left ( \frac{202.4}{228.4} \right ) \times 1400 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, full-load speed of motor = 1240.63 rpm

question: Question 123 The core loss of a single phase, 230/115 V, 50 Hz power transformer is measured from 230 V side by feeding the primary (230 V side) from a variable voltage variable frequency source while keeping the secondary open circuited. The core loss is measured to be 1050 W for 230 V, 50 Hz input. The core loss is again measured to be 500 W for 138 V, 30 Hz input. The hysteresis and eddy current losses of the transformer for 230 V, 50 Hz input are respectively,
solution: Given, at 230V, 50 Hz, core loss =1050 W and at 138 V, 30 Hz, core loss =500 W Let, [latex]V_1=230 V, \;f_1=50Hz[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Eddy current loss} &=P_{e1} \\ \text{Hysteresis loss}&=P_{h1} \\ V_2=138V &, f_230Hz \\ \text{Eddy current loss} &=P_{e2} \\ \text{Hysteresis loss}&=P_{h2} \\ \text{we know that, } & \\ \text{Eddy current loss,}\;& P_e \propto B_m^2f^2 \\ \text{and hysteresis loss,}&P_h \propto B_m^xf\propto B_m^1.6 f \\ &(\text{Typical value of x=1.6}) \end{aligned}[/latex] The transformer induced emf equation is: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_1 &=\sqrt{2} \pi \phi _m N \\ V_1&= \sqrt{2} \pi f B_m A N\\ \text{where,}\;\; \frac{V}{t} &=\text{constant} \end{aligned}[/latex] i.e. flux = constant ( to avoid over fluxing) [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Eddy current loss,} &P_e \propto V^2 \\ \text{and hysteresis loss,}&P_h \propto\frac{V^{1.6}}{f^{0.6}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_{e2}}{P_{e1}} &=\left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )^2=\left ( \frac{138}{230} \right )^2=0.36 \\ \text{or,} \;\; P_{e2} &= 0.36P_{e1}\;\;...(i)\\ \text{Also,} \;\;\frac{P_{h2}}{P_{e1}} &=\left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )^{1.6} \times \left ( \frac{f_1}{f_2} \right )^{0.6}\\ &=\left ( \frac{138}{230} \right )^{1.6} \times \left ( \frac{50}{30} \right )^{0.6} \\ &= (0.6)^{1.6} \times \frac{1}{(0.6)^{0.6}}=0.6\\ \therefore \;\; P_{h2} &=0.6P_{h1} \;\;...(ii) \end{aligned} [/latex] Given at 230V, 50Hz [latex]\text{Core loss}=P_{e1}+P_{h1}=1050W\;\;...(iii) [/latex] At 138V, 30Hz, [latex]\text{Core loss}=P_{e2}+P_{h2}=500W [/latex] or,   [latex]0.36P_{e1}+0.6P_{h1}=500W\;\;...(iv)[/latex] solving equation (iii) and (iv), we get [latex]P_{h1}=508W [/latex] and [latex] P_{e1}=542W[/latex] Therefore, hysteresis and eddy current losses at 230V, 50Hz are 508W and 542W respectively.

question:
Question 124 A star connected 400 V, 50 Hz, 4 pole synchronous machine gave the following
open circuit and short circuit test results : Open circuit test : [latex]V_{oc}[/latex] = 400 V (rms, line-to-line) at field current, [latex]I_{f}[/latex] = 2.3 A Short circuit test : [latex]I_{sc}[/latex]= 10 A (rms, phase) at field current,
[latex]I_{f}[/latex] = 1.5 A The value of per phase synchronous impedance in [latex]\Omega[/latex] at rated voltage is_____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given, for}\;\;V_{OC} &= 400V(rms)\\ &= \frac{400}{\sqrt{3}}\\ &= 230.94 \;\text{(Phase value),}\\ I_f&= 2.3A\\ \text{for}\;\; I_{sc}&=10A \;\text{(rms, phase)} \\ I_f&= 1.5A\\ & \therefore \;\;\text{Base impedance}\\ Z_{base}&=\frac{V_{OC}}{I_{sc}}\\ &=\frac{230.94}{10}=23.094\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] For finding the synchronous impedance at rated voltage, saturation effect of the machine has to be considered (i.e. the adjusted value of [latex]Z_s[/latex]) short circuit ratio, [latex]\begin{aligned} SCR &=\frac{I_f \;for \; V_{OC}}{I_f \;for \; I_{sc}} \\ &=\frac{1}{Z_{s_{(sat)pu}}} =\frac{2.3}{1.5}\\ Z_{s_{(sat)pu}} &= 0.65 pu \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, actual value of [latex]Z_s[/latex] at rated voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} &=Z_{s_{(sat)pu}} \times Z_{base} \\ &=0.65 \times 23.094=15.06\Omega \\ \therefore \;\;Z_s&= 15.06\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 125 For a specified input voltage and frequency, if the equivalent radius of the core of a transformer is reduced by half, the factor by which the number of turns in the primary should change to maintain the same no load current is
solution: Relucatance will be increased by two times. By considering flux density as constantflux should be reduced to 25% as area is reduced to 25% [latex]\begin{aligned} F&=\phi R\\ F' &= \frac{\phi }{4}\cdot 2R=\frac{R \phi }{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] For given current, number of turns should be reduced by half.

question: Question 126 An 8-pole, 3-phase, 50 Hz induction motor is operating at a speed of 700 rpm. The frequency of the rotor current of the motor in Hz is ______.
solution: Given, [latex]P=8,f=50Hz, N_r=700\; \text{rpm} [/latex] Synchronous speed, [latex]N_s=\frac{120f}{P}=\frac{120 \times 50}{8}=750 \text{rpm} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \;\;\text{Slip,}\;S&=\left ( \frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s} \right )\\ &= \left ( \frac{750-700}{750} \right )\\ &=\frac{50}{750}=\frac{1}{15} \end{aligned} [/latex] Therefore, frequency of rotor current, [latex]f_2=sf_1=\frac{1}{15} \times 50=3.33Hz [/latex] Hence, answer is 3.33Hz.

question:
Question 127 A 4-pole induction motor, supplied by a slightly unbalanced three-phase 50 Hz
source, is rotating at 1440 rpm. The electrical frequency in Hz of the induced
negative sequence current in the rotor is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_s &=\frac{120 \times 50}{14}=1500 \; \text{rpm} \\ s&= \frac{1500-1440}{1500}=0.04 \end{aligned} [/latex] For negative sequence component, [latex]\begin{aligned} s'&=2-s \\ &=2-0.04=1.96 \\ f'&=s'f \\ &= 1.96 \times 50=98.00Hz \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 128 Leakage flux in an induction motor is

options.A: flux that leaks through the machine
options.B: flux that links both stator and rotor windings
options.C: flux that links none of the windings
options.D: flux that links the stator winding or the rotor winding but not both

question: Question 129 The angle [latex]\delta[/latex] in the swing equation of a synchronous generator is the

options.A: angle between stator voltage and current
options.B: angular displacement of the rotor with respect to the stator
options.C:
angular displacement of the stator mmf with respect to a synchronously
rotating axis
options.D:
angular displacement of an axis fixed to the rotor with respect to a
synchronously rotating axis

question:
Question 130 A single-phase transformer has no-load loss of 64W, as obtained from an open
circuit test. When a short-circuit test is performed on it with 90% of the rated
currents flowing in its both LV and HV windings, he measured loss is 81 W. The
transformer has maximum efficiency when operated at
solution: For 90% current, [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{cu} &=(0.9)^2 P_{fl\;cu} \\ P_{fl\;cu} &= \frac{81}{0.81}=100W\\ x&=\sqrt{\frac{P_{core}}{P_{fl\;cu}}}=\sqrt{\frac{64}{100}}=0.8=80\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 131 A single phase 10 kVA, 50 Hz transformer with 1 kV primary winding draws
0.5 A and 55W, at rated voltage and frequency, on no load. A second transformer
has a core with all its linear dimensions [latex]\sqrt{2}[/latex] times the corresponding dimensions
of the first transformer. The core material and lamination thickness are the same
in both transformer. The primary winding of both the transformers have the save
number of turns. If a rate voltage of 2 kV at 50 Hz is applied to the primary of
the second transformer, then the no load current and power, respectively, are
solution:
We know,  [latex]E=\sqrt{2} \pi N f \phi _m[/latex], As N and f are constant, [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{E_1}{E_2} &=\frac{\phi _{m1}}{\phi _{m2}}=\frac{1}{2} \\ 
 \phi _{m2}&=2\phi _{m1} \\ 
\text{and also,}\;\; \phi _m &= \frac{\mu NiA}{d}\\ 
\Rightarrow \;  &= \\ 
\frac{\phi _{m1}}{\phi _{m2}} &=\frac{i_{e1} A_1d_2}{i_{e2}A_2d_1} \\ 
 &= \frac{\sqrt{2}i_{e1}}{2i_{e2}}=\frac{1}{2}\\ 
 \Rightarrow \;\;i_{e2}&=\sqrt{2} i_{e1} \\ 
\Rightarrow \;\;i_{e2} &= \sqrt{2} \frac{1}{2}=0.7A\\ 
 \text{Core loss}&\propto \text{Volume of core,} \\ 
\therefore \;\;\;P_{c2} &=\frac{V_2}{V_1} P_{c1}\\
&=2\sqrt{2} \times 55=155.6W
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 132 The locked rotor current in a 3-phase, star connected 15 kW, 4 pole, 230 V, 50 Hz
induction motor at rated conditions is 50 A. Neglecting losses and magnetizing
current, the approximate locked rotor line current drawn when the motor is
connected to a 236 V, 57 Hz supply is
solution: At standstill, the rotor current is [latex]I_2=\frac{E_2}{\sqrt{R^2+X^2}} [/latex] As losses are zero [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \;\;I_2 &=\frac{E_2}{X}=\frac{E_2}{j\omega L} \\ \therefore \;\; \frac{I_2}{I'_2} &=\frac{E_2}{E'_2} \times \frac{\omega '}{\omega } \\ \Rightarrow \;\; I'_2 &=\frac{236 \times 50}{230 \times 57} \times 50=45A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 133 A 220 V, 15 kW, 100 rpm shunt motor with armature resistance of 0.25 [latex]\Omega[/latex], has a
rated line current of 68 A and a rated field current of 2.2 A. The change in field
flux required to obtain a speed of 1600 rpm while drawing a line current of 52.8 A
and a field current of 1.8 A is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
r_a &= 0.25\Omega \\ 
 I_n&= 2.2A\\ 
I_{f2} &=1.8A \\ 
 I_{a1}&= 68-2.2=5.8A\\ 
I_{a2} &=52.8-1.8=51A \\ 
 E_a&= V_t-I_ar_a\\ 
E_{a1} &=220-65.8 \times 0.25 \\ 
 &= 203.55V\\ 
E_{a2} &=220-51 \times 0.25 \\ 
 &= 207.25V\\ 
 E_a &= k\phi \omega _m\\ 
 \frac{E_{a1}}{E_{a2}}&=\frac{\phi _1}{\phi _2} \frac{\omega _{m1}}{\omega _{m2}}\\ 
 \frac{20.55}{207.25}&= \frac{\phi _1}{\phi _2} \times \frac{1000}{1600}\\ 
\frac{\phi _1}{\phi _2}  &= 1.571
\end{aligned}[/latex] i.e. field flux reduces Therefore, % change in flux [latex]=\frac{\phi _2-\phi _1}{\phi _1}=-36.36\%[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Decrease in flux.

question: Question 134 The slip of an induction motor normally does not depend on
solution: [latex]\text{Slip}=\frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s}[/latex] From the above formula slip depends upon: (1) Synchronous speed [latex](N_s)[/latex] (2) Rotor speed [latex](N_r)[/latex] as the shaft torque depends upon rotor speed therefore the slip also depends on shaft torque. And core-losses are independent of slip.

question:
Question 135 The direct axis and quadrature axis reactance's of a salient pole alternator are
1.2 p.u and 1.0 p.u respectively. The armature resistance is negligible. If this
alternator is delivering rated kVA at upf and at rated voltage then its power
angle is
solution: Power angle is the angle between [latex]E_f[/latex] and [latex]V_t[/latex] but as the [latex]E'[/latex] and [latex]E_f[/latex] are in phase, angle between [latex]E'[/latex] and [latex]V_t[/latex] =power-angle=[latex]\delta[/latex] Rated power is delivered at upl, so [latex]I_a[/latex] and [latex]V_t[/latex] are in phase [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a &=1\angle 0^{\circ} \; pu\\ &\text{Quadratur-axis function,}\\ X_q &=1 \; pu \\ E' &= V_t+jI_aX_q\\ &=1+j1 \times 1 \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\angle 45^{\circ}\\ \delta &=45^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 136 A three-phase 440 V, 6 pole, 50 Hz, squirrel cage induction motor is running at
a slip of 5%. The speed of stator magnetic field to rotor magnetic field and speed
of rotor with respect of stator magnetic field are
solution: Stator and rotor magnetic field rotates at same speed. So difference in speed is zero. Speed of stator magnetic field is [latex]N_s[/latex] ( synchronous speed) [latex]N_s=\frac{120f}{P}=\frac{120 \times 50}{6}=1000 \; \text{rpm}[/latex] Rotor speed [latex]=N_s(1-s)=950 \; \text{rpm} [/latex] So, speed of rotor with respect to stator magnetic field [latex]= N_r-N_s [/latex] [latex]=950-1000=-50 \; \text{rpm}[/latex]

question:
Question 137 A 220 V, DC shunt motor is operating at a speed of 1440 rpm. The armature
resistance is 1.0 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and armature current is 10 A. of the excitation of the machine is reduced by 10%, the extra resistance to be put in the armature circuit to maintain the same speed and torque will be
solution: CASE-(i) [latex]\begin{aligned} R_a &= 1\Omega \\ I_{a1} &=10A \\ N_1&= 1440rpm\\ V_t&= 220V\\ E_{a1}&=V_t-I_{a1}R_a \;\;\;(R_{ext}=0)\\ E_{a1}&=210V \end{aligned}[/latex] CASE-(ii) Back emf, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_a &\propto \phi N\\ \phi _2&=0.9\phi _1 \\ \text{and} \; N_2&=N_1 \end{aligned}[/latex] As speed is constant [latex]\begin{aligned} E_a &\propto \phi \\ E_{a2}&=\frac{\phi _2}{\phi _1}E_{a1}\\ &=\frac{0.9\phi _1}{\phi _1} \times 210 \\ \Rightarrow \; E_{a2}&=189V\\ \text{Torque} &\propto \phi I_a \end{aligned}[/latex] as torque is constant [latex]\begin{aligned} T_1 &=T_2 \\ \phi I_{a1} &= \phi _2I_{a2}\\ \phi _1 \times 10&= 0.9 \phi _1I_{a2}\\ I_{a2} &= 11.11A\\ E_{a2}&= V_t-I_{a2}(R_a+R_{ext})\\ 189 &=220-11.11(1+R_{ext}) R_{ext}=1.79\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 138 A single phase air core transformer, fed from a rated sinusoidal supply, is operating at no load. The steady state magnetizing current drawn by the transformer from the supply will have the waveform
solution: The transformer is fed from sinusoidal supply, so flux [latex](\phi )[/latex] set up in the transformer is also sinusoidal. As the transformer is air cored, there will be no saturation and hysteresis effect in transformer. So B-H curve is linear, due to which magnetizing current is also sinusoidal.

question:
Question 139 A three phase, salient pole synchronous motor is connected to an infinite bus. It
is operated at no load a normal excitation. The field excitation of the motor is
first reduced to zero and then increased in reverse direction gradually. Then the
armature current
solution: As field current reduces, the flux will start reducing, to keep this flux constant, the armature draws high current from bus. Ar zero field current the motor acts as synchronous reluctance motor in this case the magnetizing current fully taken from bus. Ie we increase field current in reverse direction to keep flux constant, motor draws more current. During this process the load angle increases at one point the reversed field force dominates reluctance torque and rotor slip one pole pitch anf align to opposite pole. The instant align to opposite pole the flux will be very high, to reduce this flux current drops steeply t synchronous motor value. Here torque is reluctance + synchronous motor torque.

options.B: First increases and then decreases steeply
options.C: First decreases and then increases steeply

question: Question 140 A 4-point starter is used to start and control the speed of a
solution: 4-point starter is used to control the speed of shunt motor in field weakening region, i.e. above rates speeds. In field weakening region field current will reduce in 3-point starter holding coil unable to hold the plunger in ON position.

options.A: dc shunt motor with armature resistance control
options.B: dc shunt motor with field weakening control

question:
Question 141 A separately excited DC motor runs at 1500 rpm under no-load with 200 V applied
to the armature. The field voltage is maintained at its rated value. The speed of
the motor, when it delivers a torque of 5 Nm, is 1400 rpm as shown in the figure.
The rotational losses and armature reaction are neglected. For the motor to deliver a torque of 2.5 Nm at 1400 rpm, the armature voltage
to be applied is
solution: For, [latex]N=1400\; \text{rpm}, \; E_a=186.67V[/latex] Required [latex] V=E_a+I_aR_a [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=186.67+I_a(3.39)[/latex] where [latex]I_a[/latex] is function of torque, [/latex] To develope 5 N-m it requires 3.925A [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a &=3.9925\left ( \frac{2.5}{5} \right ) \\ I_a &=\frac{3.925}{2}=1.9625A \\ V_{applied}&=186.67+(1.9625)(3.39 )\\ &=193.3V \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 142 A separately excited DC motor runs at 1500 rpm under no-load with 200 V applied
to the armature. The field voltage is maintained at its rated value. The speed of
the motor, when it delivers a torque of 5 Nm, is 1400 rpm as shown in the figure.
The rotational losses and armature reaction are neglected. The armature resistance of the motor is
solution: At no load [latex]I_0=0, \; N_0=1500\text{rpm}[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\; E_a=V=200V [/latex] Assuming [latex]  N\propto E_a,[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text {at}\;\; N &= 1400 \;\text{rpm}\\ \Rightarrow \;E_a &=200 \times \frac{1400}{1500} \\ E_a&= 186.67V\\ I_a&=\frac{T\omega }{E_a} \\ &= \frac{5 \times 1400 \times \frac{2 \pi}{60}}{186.67}\\ &= 3.925A\\ I_aR_a&=V-E \\ &=200-186.67=13.33V\\ R_a&=\frac{13.33}{3.925}=3.39\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 143 A balanced star-connected and purely resistive load is connected at the secondary of a star-delta transformer as shown in figure. The line-to line voltage rating of the transformer is 110 V/200 V.
Neglecting the non-idealities of the transformer, the impedance Z of the equivalent star-connected load, referred to the primary side of the transformer, is
solution: Let VA rating of the transformer S. Rated voltage (line to line) on secondary side = 200V Rated current [latex]=\frac{S}{\sqrt{3}\;200}[/latex] Base impedance [latex]=\frac{\text{rated phase to neutral voltage}}{\text{rated current}} [/latex] [latex]Z_B=\frac{200\sqrt{3}}{S/200\sqrt{3}}=\frac{(200)^2}{S} [/latex] pu impedance on secondary side [latex]=\frac{4}{Z_B}=\frac{4}{(200)^2 S}=\frac{4S}{(200)^2} [/latex] pu impedance in primary side and secondary side are equal. Therefore pu impedance on primary side [latex]Z_{1\; pu}=\frac{4S}{(200)^2} [/latex] Rated phase to neutral voltage on primary side [latex]V_{p1}=\frac{100}{\sqrt{3}}[/latex] Rated primary current (phase) [latex]=\frac{S}{\sqrt{3}V_{l-l}}=\frac{S}{\sqrt{3}100} [/latex] Base impedance [latex]=\frac{\text{rated phase to neutral voltage}}{\text{rated current}} =\frac{100\sqrt{3}}{S/100\sqrt{3}}=\frac{(100)^2}{S} [/latex] Load impedance reffered to primary side [latex]Z_1=[/latex] base impedance (primary side) [latex]\times[/latex] pu impedance [latex]=\frac{(100)^2}{S} \times \frac{4S}{(200)^2}=(1+j0)\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 144 A separately excited dc machine is coupled to a 50 Hz, three-phase, 4-pole
induction machine as shown in figure. The dc machine is energized first and
the machines rotate at 1600 rpm. Subsequently the induction machine is also
connected to a 50 Hz, three-phase source, the phase sequence being consistent
with the direction of rotation. In steady state
solution: As both the machines are coupled, rotor of both the machines rotate at same speed. Rotor speed of DC machine = 1600 rpm Rotor spedd of induction machine = [latex]N_r[/latex] rotor speed of DC machine [latex]N_r[/latex]=1600 rpm Speed of stator field in induction machine [latex]=N_s[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} N_s &= \frac{120f}{P}\\ &= \frac{120 \times 50}{4}=1500 \; \text{rpm} \end{aligned} [/latex] Slip of rotor wrt stator field in induction machine [latex] s=\frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s}=\frac{1500-1600}{1500}=-0.067 [/latex] As slip is negative, induction machine acts as a generator and the dc machine acts as a motor.

options.B:
the dc machine acts as a generator, and the induction machine acts as a
motor
options.C:
the dc machine acts as a motor, and the induction machine acts as a
generator

question:
Question 145 A balanced three-phase voltage is applied to a star-connected induction motor,
the phase to neutral voltage being V. The stator resistance, rotor resistance
referred to the stator, stator leakage reactance, rotor leakage reactance referred
to the stator, and the magnetizing reactance are denoted by [latex]r_s,r_r,X_s,X_r \; and \; X_m[/latex], respectively. The magnitude of the starting current of the motor
solution: Starting current in induction motor can be as large as 5 to 6 times the full load current. As compared to starting current [latex](I_{st})[/latex], exciting current [latex](I_{m})[/latex] is very small [latex](I_m \lt lt I_{st})[/latex] Therefore, shunt branch can be neglected in the circuit model of the motor. [latex]I_{st}=\frac{V}{(r_s+r_r)+j(X_s+X_r)} [/latex] [latex]|I_{st}|=\frac{V}{\sqrt{(r_s+r_r)^2+(X_s+X_r)^2}}A[/latex]

question:
Question 146 A Single-phase transformer has a turns ratio 1:2, and is connected to a purely
resistive load as shown in the figure. The magnetizing current drawn is 1 A, and
the secondary current is 1 A. If core losses and leakage reactance's are neglected,
the primary current is
solution: Secondary current [latex]I_2=1\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] A Secondary current referred to primary side [latex]\begin{aligned} I'_2 &=\left ( \frac{N_2}{N_1} \right )I_2 \\ &= \frac{2}{1} \times 1\angle 0^{\circ}=2\angle 0^{\circ}A \end{aligned} [/latex] As the core losses are neglected, magnetizing current [latex](I_m)[/latex] will be in phase with flux [latex](\phi )[/latex]. Therefore [latex]I_m[/latex] lags the induced emf by [latex]90^{\circ} I_m=1\angle -90^{\circ}A [/latex] Primary current, [latex] \begin{aligned} I_1 &=I_m+I'_2 \\ &=1\angle -90^{\circ} + 2\angle 0^{\circ} \\ &\approx 2.24\angle -26.56^{\circ}A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 147 The figure below shows coils-1 and 2, with dot markings as shown, having 4000
and 6000 turns respectively. Both the coils have a rated current of 25 A. Coil-1 is
excited with single phase, 400 V, 50 Hz supply. The current in each coil is
solution: Load connecetd [latex]=S=10kVA [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} I_L &= \text{Load current}\\ &= \frac{S}{V_{out}}=\frac{10 \times 10^3}{1000}\\ &= 10A \end{aligned} [/latex] Current through coil 2 [latex]I_{DC}=I_L=10A [/latex] Input current of autotransformer [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{in} &=\frac{S}{V_{in}}=\frac{10 \times 10^3}{400} \\ I_{in} &=25A \\ \text{Using KCL,}\;\; I_{in}&=I_{DC}+I_{AB} \\ 25&=10+I_{AB} \end{aligned} [/latex] Current through coil 1 [latex]= I_{AB}=15A[/latex]

question:
Question 148 The figure below shows coils-1 and 2, with dot markings as shown, having 4000
and 6000 turns respectively. Both the coils have a rated current of 25 A. Coil-1 is
excited with single phase, 400 V, 50 Hz supply. The coils are to be connected to obtain a single-phase, [latex]\frac{400}{1000}[/latex]
 V, auto-transformer to drive a load of 10 kVA. Which of the options given should be

solution: No. of turns [latex]N_1=4000[/latex] and [latex]N_2=6000[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{E_1}{E_2} &= \frac{N_1}{N_2}\\ \Rightarrow \;\; E_2 &= \frac{N_2}{N_1}E_1 \\ &=\frac{6000}{4000} \times 400 \\ &= 600V \end{aligned}[/latex] The two coils are connected to obatin step up auto transformer [latex]\frac{400}{1000}V[/latex]. [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{in} &= 400V\\ V_{out} &= V_{AB}+V_{CD} \\ &= 400+600 \\ &= 1000V \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 149 The circuit diagram shows a two-winding, lossless transformer with
no leakage flux, excited from a current source, i(t),  whose waveform
is also shown. The transformer has a magnetizing inductance of
400/[latex]\pi[/latex] mH. If the wave form of i(t) is changed to i(t)=10 sin(100[latex]\pi[/latex]t) A, the peak voltage across A and B with S closed is
solution:
When s is closed the equivalnet circuit, [latex]\begin{aligned}
\text{Here,}\;\;R'_L &= \left ( \frac{N_1}{N_2} \right )^2 R_L\\ 
 &= \left (\frac{1}{1}  \right )^2 \times 30\\ 
 &= 30\Omega 
\end{aligned}[/latex] Load current referred to primary side, [latex]
i'_2(t)=\frac{j\omega L_m}{j\omega L_m+R'_L} \times i(t)[/latex] Load voltage referred to primary side, [latex]
V'_2=i'_2(t)R'_L[/latex] [latex]
\rightarrow \;\; V'_2(t)=\frac{j\omega L_m R'_L}{j\omega L_m+R'_L} \times i(t)[/latex] so, secondary voltage across A and B [latex]
\begin{aligned}
V_2(t) &=\frac{N_2}{N_1}V'_2(t) \\ 
V_2(t) &=\frac{1}{1} \times V'_2(t) \\ 
\Rightarrow \; V_2(t) &= \frac{j\omega L_m R'_L}{j\omega L_m+R'_L} \times i'(t)
\end{aligned}[/latex] Given, [latex]i(t)=10 \cos 100\pi t[/latex] [latex]
\therefore \;[/latex]  frequency , [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\omega  &= 100\pi\\ 
V_2(t) &=\frac{j100 \pi \times \frac{400}{\pi} \times 10^{-3} \times 30}{30+j100\pi \times \frac{400}{\pi} \times  10^{-3}} \times 10 \sin 100 \pi t \\ 
 &= V_m \cos (100 \pi t +\phi )
\end{aligned}[/latex] Peak value of secondary voltage, [latex]
V_m=\left | \frac{j12000}{30+j40} \right |V=240V[/latex]

question:
Question 150 The circuit diagram shows a two-winding, lossless transformer with
no leakage flux, excited from a current source, i(t),  whose waveform
is also shown. The transformer has a magnetizing inductance of
400/[latex]\pi[/latex] mH. The peak voltage across A and B, with S open is
solution: No leakage flux [latex]\;\Rightarrow \; X_{l1} \;\text{and}\; X'_{l2}[/latex] are neglected. Transformer is lossless [latex]\;\Rightarrow \; R_1, R'_2 \; \text{and}\; R_c[/latex] are neglected. [latex]L_{\phi }=[/latex] magnetizing inductances [latex]=\frac{400}{\pi}mH[/latex] Therefore, the above equivalent circuit can be redrawn with S open. [latex]V_{AB}=L_{\phi }\frac{di(t)}{dt}[/latex] (i) During [latex]0 \lt t \leq 5 \; ms , i(t)[/latex] increases linearly with time [latex] \begin{aligned} i(t) &=\frac{10}{5 \times 10^{-3}}t=2000t \\ V_{AB}&=L_{\phi } \frac{di(t)}{dt}\\ &= \frac{400}{\pi} \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{d(2000t)}{dt}\\ &= \frac{800 }{\pi}V \end{aligned} [/latex] (ii) during [latex]5 \; ms \lt t \leq 15 \; ms [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} i(t) &=-2000t+20 \\ V_{AB}&=L_{\phi } \frac{di(t)}{dt}\\ &= \frac{400}{\pi} \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{d}{dt}(-2000t+20)\\ &= -\frac{800 }{\pi}V \end{aligned} [/latex] (iii) During [latex]150\; ms \lt t \leq 25 \; ms [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} i(t) &=2000t-40 \\ V_{AB}&=L_{\phi } \frac{di(t)}{dt}\\ &= \frac{400}{\pi} \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{d}{dt}(2000t-40)\\ &= \frac{800 }{\pi}V \end{aligned}[/latex]. Therefore, peak voltage across A nad B [latex]\frac{800 }{\pi}V[/latex]

question:
Question 151 The star-delta transformer shown above is excited on the star side with balanced,
4-wire, 3-phase, sinusoidal voltage supply of rated magnitude. The transformer is
under no load condition. With S2 closed and S1 open, the current waveform in the delta winding will be
solution: As [latex]S_1[/latex] is open, third-harmonic current can not flow in star side, but [latex]S_2[/latex] is closed, therefore delta winding provides path for third harmonic current to flow.

question:
Question 152 The star-delta transformer shown above is excited on the star side with balanced,
4-wire, 3-phase, sinusoidal voltage supply of rated magnitude. The transformer is
under no load condition. With both S1 and S2 open, the core flux waveform will be
solution: As [latex]S_2[/latex] is open, third harmonic current can not flow in delta winding. [latex]S_1[/latex] is open, neutral gets isolated, therefore no third harmonic current in star side. Since third harmonic current cannot flow in either side, the magnetizing current [latex]I_m[/latex] is almost sinusoidal. [latex]T_0[/latex] satisfy B-H curve, the core, the core flux must then be non-sinusoidal, it is a flat-topped wave. This can be verified by assuming a sinusoidal [latex]i_m[/latex]  and then finding out the [latex]\phi[/latex]  wave shape from [latex]\phi- i_m[/latex] relationship.

question: Question 153 Figure shows the extended view of a 2-pole dc machine with 10 armature conductors. Normal brush positions are shown by A and B, placed at the interpolar axis. If the brushes are now shifted, in the direction of rotation, to A' and B' as shown, the voltage waveform [latex]V_{A'B'}[/latex] will resemble
solution: DC machine is acting as DC motor. When the brush is shifted in the direction of rotation in DC motor, field gets magnetized. Due to armature reaction, leading tip of N-pole and S-pole gets more magnetized and trailing tip of N-pole and S-pole gets demagnetized. Butincrease in flux density is more than the decreases in flux density. Due to magetizing effect of armature reaction waveform of [latex]V_{A'B'}[/latex] will be as given option (A).

question:
Question 154 A 200 V, 50 Hz, single-phase induction motor has the following connection
diagram and winding orientations as shown. MM' is the axis of the main stator
winding([latex]M_1M_2[/latex]) and AA' is that of the auxiliary winding([latex]A_1A_2[/latex]). Directions of the
winding axis indicate direction of flux when currents in the windings are in the
directions shown. Parameters of each winding are indicated. When switch S is
closed, the motor
solution: [latex]f=50Hz[/latex] Impedance of main winding [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_m &= r_m+j2 \pi f L_m\\ &=0.1+ j 2 \pi \times 20 \times \frac{0.1}{\pi} \\ Z_m&=0.1+j10\Omega \end{aligned} [/latex] Impedance of auxiliary winding, [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_a &=r_a+j2 \pi fL_a \\ &= 1+j 2 \pi \times 50 \times \frac{10}{\pi}\\ Z_a&= 1+j1000\Omega \end{aligned} [/latex] Current through main winding, [latex]I_m=\frac{V_s}{Z_m}=\frac{220}{0.1+j10} [/latex] [latex]I_m=200\angle -89.427^{\circ}A[/latex] Current through auxiliary winding [latex]I_a=\frac{V_s}{Z_a}[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{220}{1+j1000}=0.22\angle -89.942[/latex] Thaing [latex]V_s[/latex] as the reference [latex]I_m[/latex] leads [latex]I_a[/latex] the field crreated by the two current also have same difference thereby constituting an unbalanced field system, The result is the production of the starting torque. Space orientation of the field The motor rotates in the direction of leading phase to lagging phase.In this case, the motor rotates anti-clockwise.

options.D: rotates momentarily and comes to a halt

question:
Question 155 The single phase, 50 Hz iron core transformer in the circuit has both the vertical
arms of cross sectional area 20 [latex]cm^2[/latex] and both the horizontal arms of cross sectional
area 10 [latex]cm^2[/latex]. If the two windings shown were wound instead on opposite horizontal
arms, the mutual inductance will
solution: Mutual inductance is where the flux of two or more coils are linked so that voltage is induced in one coil proportional to the rate of change of current in another. The mutual inductance that exist between the coils can be greatly increased by positioning them on a common soft iron core or by increasing the number of turns of either coil. Consider: The changing flux on coil 1 is proportional to changing current in coil 2. [latex]\begin{aligned} N_1 \frac{d\phi _{12}}{dt}&=M_{12}\frac{dI_2}{dt} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;M_{12} &=N_1 \frac{\phi _{12}}{I_2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Similarly time rate of change of magnetic flux [latex]\phi _{21}[/latex] in coil 2 is proportional to time rate of change of current in coil 1 [latex]\begin{aligned} N_2 \frac{d\phi _{21}}{dt}&=M_{21}\frac{dI_1}{dt} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;M_{21} &=N_2 \frac{\phi _{21}}{I_1}\\ \text{Also} \;\; M_{12}&=M_{21}=M \end{aligned} [/latex] We can observe that none of the parameters changes due to placing of coils on horizontal arms. Hence, mutual inductance will remain unchanged.

question:
Question 156 A field excitation of 20 A in a certain alternator results in an armature current
of 400 A in short circuit and a terminal voltage of 2000 V on open circuit. The
magnitude of the internal voltage drop within the machine at a load current of 200 A is
solution: If [latex]R_a[/latex] is neglected, [latex]\vec{E_f}=\vec{V_t}+j\vec{I_a}X_s [/latex] For a given field current under short-circuit condition, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a &=I_{sc} \\ V_t&= 0\\ X_s &=\frac{E_f}{I_{sc}} \\ \text{But,}\;\; E_f &=V_{oc} \end{aligned} [/latex] (open circuit voltage i.e. [latex]I_a=0[/latex] with the same field current). Then with the linearity assumption [latex]\begin{aligned} X_s&=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{V_{oc}}{I_{sc}} \end{matrix}\right|_{I_f=\text{constant}} \\ &= \frac{2000}{400}=5\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] Internal voltage drop [latex]I_aX_s=200 \times 5=1000V[/latex]

question:
Question 157 A synchronous motor is connected to an infinite bus at 1.0 pu voltage and draws
0.6 pu current at unity power factor. Its synchronous reactance is 1.0 pu resistance
is negligible. Keeping the excitation voltage same, the load on the motor is increased such that
the motor current increases by 20%. The operating power factor will become
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Let power factor} &= \cos \phi \; \text{lagging} \\ I_a &=0.6 \times 12=0.72pu \\ E\angle \delta &=V_t-jI_a\angle -\phi \times X_s \\ E(\cos \delta +j\sin \delta ) &= \\ &=1\angle 0^{\circ}-jI_aX_s(\cos \phi -j\sin\phi ) \\ &=1-j0.72 \times 1(\cos \phi -j \sin \phi ) \\ &= (1-0.72 \sin \phi )-j0.72 \cos \phi \\ E^2&=(1-0.72 \sin \phi )^2 +(0.72 \cos \phi )^2 \\ &= 1+0.72^2 \sin ^2 \phi -1.44 \sin \phi \\ &+0.72^2 \cos ^2 \phi \\ 1.17^2 &=1+0.72^2-1.44 \sin \phi \\ \sin \phi &= 0.1038\\ \phi &= 5.96^{\circ}\\ \cos \phi &=0.995 \; \text{lagging} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 158 A synchronous motor is connected to an infinite bus at 1.0 pu voltage and draws
0.6 pu current at unity power factor. Its synchronous reactance is 1.0 pu resistance
is negligible. The excitation voltage (E) and load angle ([latex]\delta[/latex]) will respectively be
solution: Motor draws 0.6 pu current at upf [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a &=0.6\angle 0^{\circ} \\ E\angle \delta &=V_t-jI_aX_s \\ &=1\angle 0^{\circ}-j0.6 \times 1 \\ &\approx 1.17 \angle -30.96^{\circ} \\ \text{so}\;\;|E| &=1.17 pu \\ \text{and}\;\; \delta &=30.96^{\circ} \; \text{lag} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 159 A 240 V, dc shunt motor draws 15 A while supplying the rated load at a speed
of 80 rad/s. The armature resistance is 0.5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and the field winding resistance is
80 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The external resistance to be added in the armature circuit to limit the armature
current to 125% of its rated value is
solution: Rated armature current= 12A Armature current during braking [latex]I_b=1.25 \times 12=15A[/latex] Total armature resistance including external resistance during braking [latex]\begin{aligned} R_b &=R_a+R_{ext} \\ R_b &= \frac{E+V}{I_b}\\ &= \frac{474}{15}=31.6\Omega \\ &= R_a+R_{ext}\\ &= 31.6\Omega \\ 0.5+R_{ext} &=31.6\Omega \\ R_{ext}&= 31.1\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 160 A 240 V, dc shunt motor draws 15 A while supplying the rated load at a speed
of 80 rad/s. The armature resistance is 0.5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and the field winding resistance is
80 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The net voltage across the armature resistance at the time of plugging will be
solution: Before plugging Current through field winding, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_f &=\frac{V_t}{R_f} =\frac{240}{80}=3A\\ I_L &=I_f+I_a \end{aligned}[/latex] Current through armature [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a &=I_L-I_f\\ &= 15-3=12A\\ \text{Back emf}&=E_a=V_t-I_aR_a\\ &=240-12 \times 0.5\\ &=234V \end{aligned}[/latex]In plugging, the connection of armature winding is reversed. A strong baking torque is achieved by maintaining the supply voltage to the armature with connections reversed. So, the net voltage across the armature resistance at the time of plugging [latex]E_a+V=240+234=474V[/latex]

question:
Question 161 A 3-phase, 440 V, 50 Hz, 4-pole slip ring induction motor is feed from the rotor side
through an auto-transformer and the stator is connected to a variable resistance
as shown in the figure. The motor is coupled to a 220 V, separately excited d.c generator feeding power
to fixed resistance of 10 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. Two-wattmeter method is used to measure the input
power to induction motor. The variable resistance is adjusted such the motor runs
at 1410 rpm and the following readings were recorded [latex]W_1=1800 W , W_2=-200 W[/latex]. Neglecting all losses of both the machines, the dc generator power output and the
current through resistance ([latex]R_{ex}[/latex]) will respectively be
solution: [latex]\text{Slip}=\frac{90}{1500}=0.06 [/latex] Total power input to induction motor within [latex]=1800-200=1600W[/latex] Power output of induction motor [latex] P_0=(1-s)P_{in}[/latex] [latex] \;\;=1600(1-0.06)=1504 W[/latex] Since all the losses are neglected. Induction motor power output = d.c. generator input = d.c. generator output = 1504 W [latex]\therefore \;\;I^2R_{ex}=1504 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;I=\sqrt{\frac{1504}{10}}=12.26A[/latex]

question:
Question 162 A 3-phase, 440 V, 50 Hz, 4-pole slip ring induction motor is feed from the rotor side
through an auto-transformer and the stator is connected to a variable resistance
as shown in the figure. The motor is coupled to a 220 V, separately excited d.c generator feeding power
to fixed resistance of 10 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. Two-wattmeter method is used to measure the input
power to induction motor. The variable resistance is adjusted such the motor runs
at 1410 rpm and the following readings were recorded [latex]W_1=1800 W , W_2=-200 W[/latex]. The speed of rotation of stator magnetic field with respect to rotor structure will
be
solution: If the three phase supply is given to the rotor winding through an autotransformer, the three phase rotor current will generate a rotating field in the air-gap, rotating at the synchronous speed woth respect to rotor. If the rotor is kept stationary, this rotating field will also rotate in the gap at the synchronous speed voltage and current will be induced in the stator winding and a torque will be developed. If rotor is allowed to move, it will rotate as per the Lenz's law, opposing the rotation of the rotating field decreasing the induced voltage in the stator winding. Thus at a particular speed, the frequency of the stator circuit will correspond to the slip speed. Synchronous speed, [latex]N_s=\frac{120f}{P}=\frac{120 \times 50}{4}=1500 \; \text{rpm} [/latex] Rotor speed, [latex]N_r=1410 \; \text{rpm} [/latex] [latex]\text{Slip}=\frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1500-1410}{1500}=0.06 [/latex] Slip frequency induced in stator [latex]sf=0.06 \times 50=3 Hz[/latex] Slip speed [latex]= \frac{120 \times 3}{4}=90\; \text{rpm}[/latex] As stator magnetic field rotates 90 rpm in the opposite direction of the rotation of rotor, therefore, speed of the stator field with respect to rotor [latex]=1410+90=1500 rpm[/latex]

options.A: 90 rpm in the direction of rotation
options.B: 90 rpm in the opposite direction of rotation
options.C: 1500 rpm in the direction of rotation
options.D: 1500 rpm in the opposite direction of rotation

question:
Question 163 A 400 V, 50 Hz, 4-pole, 1400 rpm, star connected squirrel cage induction motor
has the following parameters referred to the stator: [latex]R'_{r}=1.0\Omega , X_{s}=X'_{r}=1.5\Omega[/latex] Neglect stator resistance and core and rotational losses of the motor. The motor
is controlled from a 3-phase voltage source inverter with constant V/f control.
The stator line-to-line voltage(rms) and frequency to obtain the maximum torque
at starting will be :
solution: For max. torque slip [latex]=s_m=\frac{R'_r}{x_{sm}+s'_{rm}}[/latex] For starting torque, [latex]s_m=1 [/latex] [latex]x_{sm}+x'_{rm}=R'_r [/latex] [latex]2 \pi f_mL_s+0.2 \pi f_mL'_r=1[/latex] (frequency at maximum torque) [latex]f_m[/latex] [latex] =\frac{1}{2 \pi (L_s+L_r)} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} L_s &= \frac{x_s}{2 \pi \times 50}=\frac{1.5}{2\pi \times 50}\\ L'_r &= \frac{1.5}{2\pi \times 50}\\ \therefore \;\; f_m &=\frac{1}{1.5/50+1.5/50}=\frac{50}{3}=16.7Hz \end{aligned}[/latex] In const V/f control method, [latex]\frac{V_1}{f_1}=\frac{400}{50}=8 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_2/f_2=8 [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; V_2=f_2 \times 8 [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\;\;=16.7 \times 8=133.3 [/latex] volts

50 A current at 0.8 power factor lagging. The stator and rotor copper losses are
1.5 kW and 900 W respectively. The friction and windage losses are 1050 W and
the core losses are 1200 W. The air-gap power of the motor will be
solution: Line to line supply voltage [latex]=V_{l-l}=400V[/latex] Current drawn by the motor, [latex]I_L=50A[/latex] at 0.8 pf Input power, [latex]\begin{aligned} P &=\sqrt{3} V_{l-l}I_L \cos \phi \\ &= \sqrt{3} \times 400 \times 50 \times 0.8\\ &=27.71kW \end{aligned}[/latex] Air-gap power [latex](P_g)[/latex] in the power that is transferred from the stator to the rotor via the air-gap magnetic field. question:
Question 168 A 230 V, 50 Hz, 4-pole, single-phase induction motor is rotating in the clockwise
(forward) direction at a speed of 1425 rpm. If the rotor resistance at standstill is
7.8 [latex]\Omega[/latex], then the effective rotor resistance in the backward branch of the equivalent circuit will be
solution: Rotor resistance at stand still, [latex]R=7.8\Omega [/latex] Synchronous speed, [latex]N_s=\frac{120f}{P} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{120 \times 50}{4}=1500 \text{rpm} [/latex] The slip(s) of rotor with respect to forward field [latex]s=\frac{N_s-N_r}{N_s} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{1500-1425}{1500}=0.05[/latex] The slip of rotor with respect to backward field [latex]=2-s=2-0.05=1.95 [/latex] Effective rotor resistance [latex]\;\;=\frac{R_2}{2(2-s)}=7.8[/latex] [latex] \;\;=\frac{7.8}{2 \times 1.95}=2\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 169 It is desired to measure parameters of 230 V/115 V, 2 kVA,
single-phase transformer. The following wattmeters are available in a laboratory: W1 : 250 V, 10 A, Low Power Factor W2 : 250 V, 5 A, Low Power Factor W3 : 150 V, 10 A, High Power Factor W4 : 150 V, 5 A, High Power Factor The Wattmeters used in open circuit test and short circuit test of the transformer
will respectively be
solution: Open-circuit Test: In open-circuit test, no-load current [latex]I_0[/latex] is very small (it is usually 2-6% of the rated current). No-load current [latex]I_0[/latex] lags E by slightly less than [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex], so power factor is very low. Therefore, wattmeter [latex]W_2[/latex] is suitable for the open-circuit test. Short-circuit Test: In short-circuit test [latex]V_{sc}[/latex] needed to circulate the full-load current is very low. Under these conditions, [latex]I_0[/latex] is only about 0.1 to 0.5% of full load current . As [latex]I_0[/latex] is highly lagging but it is very small as compared to sull load current, therefore the power factor is high. So, wattmeter [latex]W_3[/latex] is suitable for the short-circuit test.

question: Question 172 Distributed winding and short chording employed in AC machines will result in
solution: Distribution factor in distributed winding  [latex]k_d(n^{th} \; \text{harmonic})=\frac{\sin \left ( \frac{mn\gamma }{2} \right )}{m \sin \left ( \frac{n\gamma }{2} \right )} [/latex] [latex]k_d[/latex] is always less than 1, so emf reduces. If, [latex]mn\gamma /2[/latex] is chosen in such a way that [latex]\sin (mn\gamma /2)=0, n^{th}[/latex] harmonic gets eliminated. Similarly, pitch factor [latex]=k_p(n^{th} \;\text{harmonic}) = \cos \frac{n\alpha }{2} [/latex] [latex]k_p[/latex] is always less than 1, so emf reduces. If [latex]n\alpha /2[/latex] is chosen in such a way that [latex]\cos \frac{n\alpha }{2}=0, n^{th}[/latex] harmonic gets eliminated.

options.A: increase in emf and reduction in harmonics
options.B: reduction in emf and increase in harmonics
options.C: increase in both emf and harmonics
options.D: reduction in both emf and harmonics

question:
Question 173 A three phase squirrel cage induction motor has a starting current of seven times
the full load current and full load slip of 5% If a starting torque of 0.5 per unit is required then the per unit starting current
should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_s &=0.5T_{fl} \\ \text{and}\;\; s_{fl}&=0.05 \;\text{(given)} \end{aligned} [/latex] In the case of direction line starting, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{T_s}{T_{fl}} &=\left ( \frac{I_{sc}}{I_{fl}} \right )^2 \times s_{fl} \\ \frac{0.5T_{fl}}{T_{fl}}&= \left ( \frac{I_{sc}}{I_{fl}} \right )^2 \times 0.05\\ I_{sc}&=3.16I_{fl} \end{aligned} [/latex] Per unit starting current [latex] I_{sc}=3.16 pu[/latex]

question:
Question 174 A three phase squirrel cage induction motor has a starting current of seven times
the full load current and full load slip of 5% If a star-delta starter is used to start this induction motor, the per unit starting
torque will be
solution: In case of star-delta starter, the ratio of starting torque to full load torque [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{T_s}{T_{fl}} &= \frac{1}{3} \left ( \frac{I_{sc}}{I_{fl}} \right )^2 \times s_{fl}\\ \frac{T_s}{T_{fl}} &= \frac{1}{3} \left ( \frac{7I_{fl}}{I_{fl}} \right )^2 \times 0.05\\ T_s&= 0.816T_{fl} \end{aligned} [/latex] Per unit starting torque, [latex] T_s=0.816pu[/latex]

question:
Question 175 A three phase squirrel cage induction motor has a starting current of seven times
the full load current and full load slip of 5% If an auto transformer is used for reduced voltage starting to provide 1.5 per unit
starting torque, the auto transformer ratio(%) should be
solution: In case of auto transformer, the starting torque can be expressed as ratio of full load [latex]\frac{T_s}{T_{fl}}=x^2\left ( \frac{I_{sc}}{I_{fl}} \right )^2 s_{fl}\;\;...(i) [/latex] where, [latex]x=[/latex] auto transformer ratio [latex]T_s= 1.5 T_{fl}[/latex] (given) [latex]I_{sc}=7I_{fl}[/latex] (given) [latex]s_{fl}=0.05[/latex] Substituting the above values in equation (i) [latex]\frac{1.5 T_{fl}}{T_{fl}}=x^2\left (\frac{7I_{fl}}{I_{fl}} \right )^2 \times 0.05 [/latex] [latex]x^2=0.6122 [/latex] Transformer ratio [latex]x=0.7825[/latex] or [latex]78.25%[/latex]

question:
Question 176 A three-phase squirrel cage induction motor has a starting torque of 150% and a maximum torque of 300% with respect to rated torque at rated voltage and rated
frequency. Neglect the stator resistance and rotational losses. The value of slip
for maximum torque is
solution: Assuming rated torque [latex]=T_{rated}[/latex] Starting torque [latex]T_s=150\% \; \text{of} \; T_{rated}=1.5T_{rated}[/latex] Maximum torque, [latex]T_m=300\% \; \text{of} \; T_{rated}=3.0T_{rated}[/latex] as we know, [latex]\begin{aligned} T_s &=\frac{3}{\omega _s} \frac{V^2R'_2}{{R'_2}^2+{X'_2}^2}\\ T_m &=\frac{3}{\omega _s} \frac{0.5V^2}{X'_2} \\ \frac{T_m}{T_s}&= \frac{0.5}{X'_2} \frac{{R'_2}^2 \times {X'_2}^2}{R'_2}\\ &= 0.5\left [ \frac{(R_2/X'_2)^2 +1}{(R'_2/X'_2)} \right ] \end{aligned} [/latex] as we know, maximum torque occurs at [latex]\begin{aligned} s_m &=\frac{R'_2}{X'_2} \\ \frac{T_m}{T_s} &= 0.5\left ( \frac{{s_m}^2 +1}{s_m} \right )\\ \frac{3T_{rated}}{1.5T_{rated}}&=0.5 \left ( \frac{{s_m}^2 +1}{s_m} \right ) \\ {s_m}^2 -4s_m +1&=0 \\ s_m&= 3.73 \; \text{or} \; 0.2679 \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]s_m=3.73[/latex] is rejected, as for this value of slip motor works in braking mode. Therefore, for motoring mode [latex]s_m=0.2679[/latex] or [latex]26.79\%[/latex]

question:
Question 177 A single-phase, 50-kVA, 250 V/500 V two winding transformer has an efficiency
of 95% at full load, unity power factor. If it is re-configured as a 500 V/750 V
auto-transformer, its efficiency at its new rated load at unity power factor will be
solution: In two winding transformer [latex]\begin{aligned} V_1 &=500V \\ V_2&= 250V\\ I_1 &=\frac{50 \times 10^3}{500}=100A \\ I_2&= \frac{50 \times 10^3}{250}=200A\\ \eta &= \frac{x S \cos \phi }{xS \cos \phi + \text{losses}}\\ \text{Full load}& \\ x&=1,\; \text{upf}, \; \cos \phi =1, \; S=50 \\ 0.95&= \frac{1 \times 50 \times 1}{1 \times 50 \times 1+ \text{losses}}\\ \text{losses} &= 2.63\\ \text{losses}&= \text{Iron loss}+ \text{Copper loss} \end{aligned}[/latex] When two winding transformer is connected as step up autotransformer [latex]I_2=200,\;\; V_2=750 [/latex] kVA rating of auto transformer [latex]\begin{aligned} S_{auto} &=V_2I_2 \\ &=750 \times 200 \\ &= 150kVA \end{aligned} [/latex] As current through windings and voltage across winding are equal in two-winding transformer and autotransformer. Losses remain same at full load efficiency at upf and full load [latex]\begin{aligned} \%\eta &=\frac{xS_{auto} \cos \phi }{xS_{auto} \cos \phi +\text{ losses }}\times 100 \\ &= \frac{1 \times 150 \times 1}{1 \times 150 \times 1 +2.63} \times 100\\ &= 98.276\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 178 A three-phase, three-stack, variable reluctance step motor has 20 poles on each
rotor and stator stack. The step angle of this step motor is
solution: No. of teeth = No. of poles =20 Step angle, [latex]\alpha =\frac{360^{\circ}}{\text{(No. of stacks)} \times \text{(No. of teeth)}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=\frac{360^{\circ}}{3 \times 20}=6^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 179 A 100 kVA, 415 V(line), star-connected synchronous machine generates rated open circuit voltage of 415 V at a field current of 15 A. The short circuit armature current at a field current of 10 A is equal to the rated armature current. The per unit saturated synchronous reactance is
solution: Rated open circuit voltage is obatined at [latex]of''=15A[/latex] Rated armature current [latex]=\frac{100}{\sqrt{3} \times 415}=139.12A[/latex] Short-circuit characteristics is linear. Short-circuit armature current at field current 15A [latex]I_{a1}=I_a \times \frac{of''}{of'}[/latex] [latex]=139.12 \times \frac{15}{10}=208.68A[/latex] Phase voltage, [latex]V_p=\frac{V_{oc(line)}}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{415}{\sqrt{3}}[/latex] Saturated synchronous reactance [latex] \begin{aligned} &=X_s =\frac{V_p}{I_{a1}}\\ &= \frac{415/\sqrt{3}}{208.68}=1.148\Omega \\ &\text{Base impedance,} Z_B&= \frac{415^2}{100 \times 10^3}=1.722\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] Per unit saturated synchronous reactance [latex]=\frac{X_s}{Z_B}=\frac{1.148}{1.722}=0.666pu[/latex]

question:
Question 180 A three-phase synchronous motor connected to ac mains is running at full load
and unity power factor. If its shaft load is reduced by half, with field current held
constant, its new power factor will be
solution: Neglecting armature resistance [latex]R_a [/latex] [latex]V_t=E_f+jI_aX_s[/latex] It can be seen from the phasor diagram that, when load is reduced at shaft keeping field current constant the new power factor becomes leading.

question:
Question 181 The electromagnetic torque [latex]T_e[/latex] of a drive and its connected load torque [latex]T_L[/latex] are as
shown below. Out of the operating points A, B, C and D, the stable ones are
solution: Accelerating torque [latex]=T_a=T_e-T_L[/latex] At point A, C, D [latex]T_L=T_e [/latex] [latex]T_a=T_e-T_L=0 [/latex] if due to some disturbance speed decreases [latex]T_e \gt T_L [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;T_a=T_e-T_L \gt 0 [/latex] So, rotor accelerates and speed increases. If speed increases due to some disturbances [latex]T_e \lt T_L[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\; T_a=T_e-T_L \lt 0 [/latex] So, rotor decelerates and speed decreases. So, point A, C, D are still stable At point B, [latex]T_e=T_L [/latex] [latex]T_a=T_e-T_L=0 [/latex] If speed decreases due to some disturbance [latex]T_e \lt T_L [/latex] [latex]T_a=T_e-T_L \lt 0 [/latex] So rotor decelerates, and rotor speed keeps on decreasing. If speed increases, [latex]T_e \gt T_L[/latex] [latex] T_a=T_e-T_l \gt 0[/latex] Rotor accelerates, and rotor speed keeps on increasing. So, point B is unstable.

question:
Question 182 The dc motor, which can provide zero speed regulation at full load without any
controller is
solution: Speed-current characteristics of DC motors It can seen from the characteristics, speed regulation can be zero at full load in the case of differential compound dc motor.

question: Question 183 In a transformer, zero voltage regulation at full load is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Voltage regulation} &=I(R \cos \phi +X \sin \phi ) \\ &\text{(for lagging power factor)} \\ \text{Voltage regulation} &=I(R \cos \phi -X \sin \phi ) \\ &\text{(for leading power factor)} \\ \text{Voltage regulation} &=I(R \cos \phi -X \sin \phi ) =0\\ \tan \phi &=\frac{R}{X} \end{aligned} [/latex] So, zero voltage regulation is possible for leading power factor. When, [latex] \tan \phi =\frac{R}{X}[/latex]

options.B: possible at unity power factor load
options.C: possible at leading power factor load
options.D: possible at lagging power factor load

question: Question 184 A 300 kVA transformer has 95% efficiency at full load 0.8 pf lagging and 96% efficiency at half load, unity pf. What is maximum efficiency(in %) at unity pf load?
solution: For maximum efficiency at upf [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{ Iron loss} &= \text{Copper loss }\\ P_i&= x^2P_{c.fl}\\ 4.12&= x^2 8.51\\ x&=0.696 \\ \eta _{max}&=\frac{xS \cos \phi }{xS \cos \phi +2P_i} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{0.696 \times 300 \times 1}{0.696 \times 300 \times 1 +2 \times 4.12}\times 100 \\ &= 96.2\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 185 A 300 kVA transformer has 95% efficiency at full load 0.8 pf lagging and 96% efficiency at half load, unity pf. The iron loss [latex]\left ( P_{i} \right )[/latex] and copper loss[latex]\left ( P_{c} \right )[/latex] in kW, under full load operation are
solution: Iron loss [latex]=P_i,[/latex] it does not depends on the load. Full load copper loass [latex]=P_{c,fl},[/latex] it depends on the load [latex]P_{cu}=x^2 P_{c,fl}[/latex] where, [latex]x=[/latex] Fraction of the full load Rated kVA = S = 300kVA [latex]\eta =[/latex]% efficeincy of a transformer [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=\frac{xS \cos \phi }{x S\cos \phi + P_i+P_{cu}} \\ &= \frac{xS \cos \phi}{x S\cos \phi + P_i+x^2P_{c,fl}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] (i)\; \;  \eta =95\%,\; x=1,\; \cos \phi =0.8[/latex] [latex] 0.95=\frac{1 \times 300 \times 0.8}{1 \times 300 \times 0.8+P_i+1^2 P_{c,fl}} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;P_i+P_{c,fl}=12.63kW\;\;...(i) [/latex] [latex](ii)\; \;  \eta =96\%,\; x=0.5,\; \cos \phi =1 [/latex] [latex]0.96=\frac{0.5 \times 300 \times 1}{0.5 \times 300 \times 1+P_i+(0.5)^2 P_{c,fl}} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;P_i+P_{c,fl}=6.25kW\;\;...(ii)[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex]P_i=4.12kW [/latex] and [latex] P_{c,fl}=8.51kW[/latex]

question:
Question 186 A 4 pole, 50 Hz, synchronous generator has 48 slots in which a double layer winding is housed. Each coil has 10 turns and is short pitched by an angle to 36[latex]^\circ[/latex] electrical. The fundamental flux per pole is 0.025 Wb. The fifth harmonic component of phase emf(in volts), for a three phase star
connection is
solution: Pitch factor due to [latex]5^{th}[/latex] harmonic component, [latex](k_p)_5=\cos \left ( \frac{5 \times 36}{2} \right )=\cos 90=0[/latex] [as pitch factor is zero, induced emf due to [latex]5^{th}[/latex] harmonic component is zero]

question: Question 187 A 4 pole, 50 Hz, synchronous generator has 48 slots in which a double layer winding is housed. Each coil has 10 turns and is short pitched by an angle to 36[latex]^\circ[/latex] electrical. The fundamental flux per pole is 0.025 Wb. The line-to-line induced emf(in volts), for a three phase connection is approximately

Question 188 A 4 pole, 50 Hz, synchronous generator has 48 slots in which a double layer winding is housed. Each coil has 10 turns and is short pitched by an angle to 36[latex]^\circ[/latex] electrical. The fundamental flux per pole is 0.025 Wb. The line-to-line induced emf(in volts), for a three phase star connection is
approximately
solution: In double layer winding No. of coil = No. of slots =48 Each coil has 10 turns Total no. of turns [latex]=48 \times 10=480[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{ph} &=\text{No. of turns/phase} \\ &= \frac{480}{3}=160 \end{aligned} [/latex] Slots/pole/phase [latex]=m=\frac{48}{4 \times 3}=4 [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \gamma &= \text{slot angle}\\ &=\frac{180 \times \text{poles}}{\text{slots}} \\ &= \frac{180 \times 4}{48}=15^{\circ}\\ &\text{Distribution factor,}\\ k_d&=\frac{\sin \frac{m\gamma }{2}}{m \sin \frac{\gamma }{2}} \\ &= \frac{\sin \left ( \frac{4 \times 15}{2} \right )}{2 \sin \left ( \frac{15}{2} \right )}\\ &= 0.957\\ & \text{Short-pitching angle,}\\ \alpha &=36^{\circ} \end{aligned} [/latex] For the [latex]n^{th}[/latex] harmonic, pitch factor, [latex]k_p=\cos \frac{n\alpha }{2}[/latex] pitch factor due to fundamental component [latex]\begin{aligned} k_p&=\cos \frac{\alpha }{2}=\cos 18^{\circ}=0.951 \\ &\text{Winding factor,} \\ k_w&=k_dk_p \\ &=0.957 \times 0.951=0.910 \\ &\text{Induced emf per phase,} \\ E_{ph}&= 4.44 k_w f T_{ph}\phi \\ &=4.44 \times 0.91 \times 50 \times 160 \times 0.025 \\ &\approx 808\\ \Rightarrow \;\; E_{line} &=\sqrt{3} E_{ph}=1400V \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 189 A 3-phase, 400 V, 5 kW, star connected synchronous motor having an internal
reactance of 10 [latex]\Omega[/latex] is operating at 50% load, unity p.f. Now, the excitation is increased by 1%. What will be the new load in percent, if the power factor is to be kept same? Neglect all losses and consider linear magnetic circuit.
solution: [latex]I_{fl}=\frac{5 \times 10^{3}}{\sqrt{3} \times 400 \times 1}=7.21A[/latex] For synchronous motor, [latex]\begin{aligned} E^2 &=(V \cos \theta -I_aR_a)^2 +(V\sin \theta -I_aX_s)^2 \\ E&= \sqrt{(400/\sqrt{3})^2+(10 \times 3.6)^2}\\ &= 233.729V \end{aligned} [/latex] If there is 1% increase in [latex]E_2[/latex], then [latex]E_2[/latex] becomes, [latex]\begin{aligned} E_2 &=233.729 \times 1.01=236V \\ \therefore \;\; I_aX &=\sqrt{E_2^2-V^2} \\ &= \sqrt{(236)^2-(400/\sqrt{3})^2}\\ &= 48.93\\ \therefore \;\; I_a&=4.893A \\ \therefore \;\;\% \;\text{load} &= \frac{4.893}{7.21}=67.86\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 190 A 3-phase, 10 kW, 400 V, 4-pole, 50Hz, star connected induction motor draws 20
A on full load. Its no load and blocked rotor test data are given below. Neglecting copper loss in no load test and core loss in blocked rotor test, estimate
motor's full load efficiency
solution: No-load losses, [latex]P_1=1002W=1.002kW[/latex] (does not depends on load) Copper loss at 15A [latex]P_{cu}=762W[/latex] Full load current =20A So, copper loss on full load [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{cu,fl} &= (P_{cu}) \left ( \frac{20}{15} \right )^2\\ P_{cu,fl} &= 762 \times \left ( \frac{20}{15} \right )^2=1.354 kW \\ & \text{Total losses,}\\ P-1 +P_{cu,fl} &=1.002+1.354 \\ &= 2.356kW \end{aligned} [/latex] Power available at shaft or output power on full load [latex]P_0=10kW [/latex] Input power=Output power +losses [latex]=10+2.356=12.356kW[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \% \text{efficiency} &=\frac{\text{Output power}}{Input Power}\times 100 \\ &= \frac{10}{12.356}\times 100\approx 81\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 191 A 3-phase, 4-pole, 400 V, 50 Hz, star connected induction motor has following
circuit parameters [latex]r_{1}=1.0\Omega ,r'_{2}=0.5 \Omega ,x_{1}=x'_{2}=1.2 \Omega, x_{m}=35 \Omega[/latex] The starting torque when the motor is started direct-on-line is (use approximate equivalent circuit model)
solution: rated line to line voltage, [latex]V_{l-l}=400V[/latex] Phase to neutral voltage, [latex]V_{p}=\frac{V_{l-l}}{\sqrt{3}}= \frac{400}{\sqrt{3}}V[/latex] Synchronous speed at 50 Hz [latex]\begin{aligned} N_s &=\frac{120f}{P}=\frac{120 \times 50}{4} \\ &=1500 \;\text{rpm} \\ \omega _s &=\frac{2 \pi N_s}{60}=\frac{2 \pi \times 1500}{50} \\ &= 157.08 \; \text{rad/sec} \\ s&= 1\, \; \text{at starting}\ \\ &\text{Starting torque} \\ T_s&= \frac{3}{\omega _s}\frac{V_P^2r'_2}{(r_1+r'_2)^2+(x_1+x'_2)^2}\\ T_s &= \frac{3}{157.08} \times \frac{(400\sqrt{3})^2 \times 0.5}{(1+0.5)^2+(1.2+1.2)^2}\\ &\approx 63.6 \; N-m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 192 The speed of a 4-pole induction motor is controlled by varying the supply
frequency while maintaining the ratio of supply voltage to supply frequency (V/f) constant. At rated frequency of 50 Hz and rated voltage of 400 V its speed is
1440 rpm. Find the speed at 30 Hz, if the load torque is constant
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_{s_1} &=\frac{120f_1}{P} \\ &= \frac{120 \times 50}{4}=1500\; \text{rpm}\\ s_1 &=\frac{N_{s_1}-N_{R_1}}{N_{s_1}} \\ &= \frac{1500-1440}{1500}=0.04\\ \text{as}\;\;\frac{V}{f} &=\text{Constant} \\ \frac{V_1}{f_1}&=\frac{V_2}{f_2} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; V_2&=V_1\left ( \frac{f_2}{f_1} \right ) \\ &= 400 \times \frac{30}{50}=240V \end{aligned}[/latex] Torque developed in induction motor [latex]T=\frac{3}{\omega _s}\frac{V^2R'_2/s}{(R'_2/s)^2 +{X'_2}^2} [/latex] In stable region, slip is very low, so  [latex]\frac{R'_2}{s} \gt \gt X'_2[/latex] So, T can be approximated as [latex]\begin{aligned} T &=\frac{3}{\omega _s}\frac{V^2R'_2/s}{(R'_2/s)^2} \\ &=\frac{3}{\omega _s} \frac{8V^2}{R'_2} \\ T&\propto \frac{sV^2}{f} \\ \frac{T_1}{T_2}&= \frac{s_1}{s_2}\left ( \frac{V_1}{V_2} \right )^2 \times \frac{f_2}{f_1} \end{aligned} [/latex] as load torque is constant, [latex]T_1=T_2[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} s_2 &=s_1 \left ( \frac{V_1}{V_2} \right )^2 \times \frac{f_2}{f_1}\\ &= 0.04 \times \left ( \frac{400}{240} \right )^2 \times \left ( \frac{30}{50} \right )\\ &= 0.067\\ N_{s2} &=\frac{120f_2}{P} \\ &= \frac{120 \times 30}{4}=900 \; \text{rpm}\\ &\text {Rotor speed,}\\ N_{r2}&=N_{s2(1-s_2)} \\ &= 900(1-0.067)\\ &\approx 840 \; \text{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

current. The armature reaction is

question:
Question 195 A 220 V DC machine supplies 20 A at 200 V as a generator. The armature
resistance is 0.2 ohm. If the machine is now operated as a motor at same terminal
voltage and current but with the flux increased by 10%, the ratio of motor speed
to generator speed is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{For generator,} \\ E&=V+I_aR_a \\ &= 200+20 \times 0.2\\ &=204 \\ &\text{For motor,} \\ V&=E +I_aR_a \\ E&= 200-20 \times 0.2\\ &= 196\\ \frac{E_1}{E_2} &=\frac{N_1}{N_2} \times \frac{\phi _1}{\phi _2}\\ \frac{204}{196}&= \frac{N_1}{N_2} \times\frac{1}{1.1}\\ \therefore \;\;\frac{N_2}{N_1} &=\frac{196}{204 \times 1.1}\\ &=0.87 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 198 In transformers, which of the following statements is valid ?
solution: Circuit model in open-circuit test: In open-circuit test, the transformer draws only exciting current. The exciting current is only magnetizing in nature and is proportional to the sinusoidal flux and in phase with it. This is represnted by [latex]I_m[/latex] lagging the induced emf by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]. However, the presence of eddy-current, and hysteresis, both demad the flow of active power into the system and as a consequence the exciting current [latex]I_0[/latex] has another component [latex]I_i[/latex] in phase with [latex]E_1[/latex]. Thus the exciting current lags the induced emf by an angle slightly less than [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] making power factor very low.

options.A:
In an open circuit test, copper losses are obtained while in short circuit
test, core losses are obtained
options.B: In an open circuit test, current is drawn at high power factor
options.C: In a short circuit test, current is drawn at zero power factor
options.D: In an open circuit test, current is drawn at low power factor
