Question 200 A 1000 kVA , 6.6 kV, 3-phase star connected cylindrical pole synchronous generator has a synchronous reactance of 20[latex]\Omega[/latex]. Neglect the armature resistance and consider operation at full load and unity power factor. The power (or torque) angle is close to
solution: From previous solution, [latex]\delta =24.6^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 201 A 1000 kVA , 6.6 kV, 3-phase star connected cylindrical pole synchronous generator has a synchronous reactance of 20[latex]\Omega[/latex]. Neglect the armature resistance and consider operation at full load and unity power factor. The induced emf (line-to-line) is close to
solution: Rated output power [latex]=S = 1000kVA[/latex] Rated line to line voltage [latex]=V_{l-l} = 6.6kV[/latex] Rated current, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a &=\frac{S}{\sqrt{3}V_{l-l}} \\ &= \frac{1000}{\sqrt{3} \times 6.6}\\ &=87.477A \end{aligned}[/latex] As generator is star connected. Phase to neutral voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} V_t &=\frac{V_{l-l}}{\sqrt{3}} \\ &= \frac{6.6}{\sqrt{3} }\\ &=3.81kV \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking [latex]V_t[/latex] as the reference [latex]\begin{aligned} V_t &=3.81 \angle 0^{\circ}kV\\ I_a&= 87.477\angle 0^{\circ}A\\ E_f &=V_t+I_a X_s \\ &= 3.81 \angle 0^{\circ}+ 87.477 \angle 0^{\circ} \\ &\times (j20) \times 10^{-3} \\ &= 4.19\angle 24.6^{\circ}kV \end{aligned}[/latex] Induced emf(line to line) [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\sqrt{3}E_f \\ &= \sqrt{3} \times 4.19\\ &=7.2 kV \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 202 Determine the correctness or otherwise of the following assertion[A] and the
reason[R]. Assertion [A] : Under V/f control of induction motor, the maximum value of
the developed torque remains constant over a wide range of speed in the subsynchronous region. Reason [R] : The magnetic flux is maintained almost constant at the rated value
by keeping the ration V/f constant over the considered speed range.
solution: The resultant air-gap flux per pole is given by [latex]\phi _r=\frac{1}{4.44k_{\omega _1}N_{pn_1}}\left ( \frac{V}{f} \right ) [/latex] [latex]\phi _r\propto \left ( \frac{V}{f} \right )[/latex] Therefore, in order to avoid saturation in stator and rotor cores which would cause sharp increase in magnetization current, the flux [latex]f_p[/latex] must be kept constant. To achieve this, [latex]\frac{V}{f}[/latex] ratio must be kept constant. Let, [latex]V_0=[/latex] Nominal voltage [latex]f_0=[/latex] Nominal frequency [latex]X'_{20}=[/latex] Nominal rotor standstill reactance reffered to stator then at any frequency f. Then at any frequency f, [latex]\begin{aligned} V &=\left ( \frac{f}{f_0} \right ) V_0\\ X'_2 &=\left ( \frac{f}{f_0} \right ) X'_{20} \\ \omega _s &=\left ( \frac{f}{f_0} \right )\omega _{20} \\ T_{max}&= \frac{3}{\left ( \frac{f}{f_0} \right )\omega _{s_0}}\left [ \frac{0.5 \left ( \frac{f}{f_0} \right )^2 V_0^2}{\left ( \frac{f}{f_0} \right )X'_{20}} \right ]\\ &= \frac{3}{\omega _{s_0}}\frac{0.5V_0^2}{X'_{20}}\\ &=\text{constant, independent of f} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: Both [A] and [R] are true and [R] is the correct reason for [A]
options.B: Both [A] and [R] are true and but [R] is not the correct reason for [A]

question:
Question 203 In a single phase induction motor driving a fan load, the reason for having a
high resistance rotor is to achieve
solution: In [latex]1-\phi[/latex] induction motor, total torque developed is given by [latex]T_{total}=T_f-T_b [/latex] where, [latex]T_f=[/latex] Torque developed due ot forward field. [latex]T_b=[/latex] Torque developed due to backward field [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{toal} &=T_f-T_b \\ &=\frac{I_m^2R_2}{2\omega _s} \left ( \frac{1}{s} -\frac{1}{2-s}\right )\\ T_{toal}&\propto R_2 \end{aligned}[/latex] Higher is the rotor resistance [latex](R_2)[/latex], more is the total torque developed [latex](T_{total})[/latex] which results in quick acceleration.

question:
Question 204 A three-phase cage induction motor is started by direct-on-line (DOL) switching
at the rated voltage. If the starting current drawn is 6 times the full load
current, and the full load slip is 4%, then ratio of the starting developed torque
to the full load torque is approximately equal to
solution: Torque in induction motor is given by, [latex]\begin{aligned} T &=\frac{3}{\omega _s}(I'_2)\frac{R'_2}{s} \\ & \text{Full load torque}\\ T_{fl} &= \frac{2}{\omega _s}(I'_{2fl})^2 \frac{R'_2}{S_{fl}}\\ & \text{At starting,}\\ s &= 1\\ & \text{Starting torque}\\ T_{st}&= \frac{3}{\omega _s}(I'_{2st})^2 R'_2\\ \frac{T_{st}}{T_{fl}}&=\left ( \frac{I'_{2st}}{I'_{2fl}} \right )^2 S_{fl} \\ &= 6^2 \times 0.04=1.44 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 205 Under no load condition, if the applied voltage to an induction motor is reduced from the rated voltage to half the rated value,

[latex]\text{As}\;\;P_d \gt P_q [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\; X_d \gt X_q[/latex] (ii) Damper bars not only minimize hunting to a tolerable level but also help the synchronous motor self-start. question:
Question 207 In relation to DC machines, match the following and choose the correct
combination.
solution: As we know, (i) Armature emf, [latex]E=k_a\phi \omega[/latex] where [latex]k_a[/latex] is constant so, E depends on [latex]\phi [/latex] and [latex] \omega[/latex] only. (ii) Developed torque, [latex]T=k_a\phi I_a[/latex] T depends on [latex]\phi [/latex] and [latex]I_a[/latex] only. (ii) Developed power, [latex]P=E I_a=(k_a\phi \omega )I_a [/latex] or,  [latex] \; P=T\omega = (k_a\phi I_a)\omega[/latex] So, P depends on [latex]\phi ,\omega [/latex] and [latex]I_a[/latex].

question:
Question 208 A 50 kW dc shunt is loaded to draw rated armature current at any given speed.
When driven
(i) at half the rated speed by armature voltage control and
(ii) at 1.5 times the rated speed by field control, the respective output powers
delivered by the motor are approximately.
solution: Armature control provides constant torque drive.In the shunt motor case by keeping the filed current at maximum value full load torque can be obtaineda at full load armaturecurrent at all speeds [latex]\begin{aligned} T &= \text{constant}\\ T\omega &= \text{output power}(P_o)\\ \Rightarrow \;\frac{P_o}{\omega }&= constant\\ (P_0)_1 &= 50kW\\ \omega _2&= \frac{\omega _1}{2}\\ \frac{(P_o)_1}{\omega _1} &= \frac{(P_o)_2}{\omega _2}\\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{50}{\omega _1} &=\frac{(P_o)_2}{\omega _1/2} \\ (P_o)_2 &= 25kW \end{aligned}[/latex] (output power delivered at half the rated speed by armature control). Filed control provides constant-power drive. Since the speed is inversely proportional to the flux/pole [latex]\left ( \omega \propto \frac{1}{\phi } \right )[/latex] while the torque is direclty proportional to flux/pole [latex](T\propto \phi )[/latex] for a given armature current. Output power [latex]=T\omega =\left ( \frac{k_1}{\phi } \right )(k_2\phi ) [/latex] [latex]\;\;=k_1k_2=constant[/latex] Output power delivered by the motor remains constant i.e. 50kW

question:
Question 209 Two magnetic poles revolve around a stationary armature carrying two coil
([latex]c_1- c'_1,c_2- c'_2[/latex]) as shown in the figure. Consider the instant when the poles are
in a position as shown. Identify the correct statement regarding the polarity of
the induced emf at this instant in coil sides [latex]c_1\; and \; c_2[/latex].
solution: Magnetic poles revolves around stationary coils in clockwise direction. As the motion is relative, it can be assumed that, magnetic poles are stationary and coils are rotating in counter-clockwise. The direction of magnetic flux is from N-pole to S-pole. Now consider coils [latex]C_1[/latex] and [latex]C_i[/latex] The dynamically induced emf in conductor [latex]C_1[/latex] can be given by flamig's right hand rule [latex]e=|\vec{V}|\times |\vec{B}|l=B/V \sin \theta[/latex] The direction of emf [latex]\vec{V}\times \vec{B}[/latex] Therefore, [latex]\odot \text { in } C_1[/latex] Now, consider, coils [latex]C_2[/latex] and [latex]C'_2[/latex] At this instant, B and V are antiparallel i.e. [latex]\theta =180^{\circ} [/latex] So,  [latex]\sin 180^{\circ}=0[/latex] Hence,no emf is induced in  [latex]C_2[/latex].

question:
Question 210 For an induction motor, operation at a slip [latex]s[/latex], the ration of gross power output
to air gap power is equal to
solution: Let, [latex]P_g=[/latex] Air gap power [latex]P_{cu}=[/latex] Rotor copper loss [latex]=sP_g[/latex] [latex]P_m=[/latex] Gross power output =Air gap power - Rotor copper loss [latex]P_m=P_g-sP_g=P_g(1-s)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\;\frac{P_m}{P_g}=(1-s)[/latex]

question:
Question 211 On the torque/speed curve of the induction motor shown in the figure, four points of operation are marked as W, X, Y and Z. Which one of them
represents the operation at a slip greater than 1 ?
solution: In braking mode, the motor runs in opposite direction to rotating field i.e. [latex]N_f[/latex] (rotor speed) is negative, [latex]s=\frac{N_s -(-N_r)}{N_s}=\frac{N_s +N_r}{N_s} \gt 1[/latex]

question:
Question 213 The equivalent circuit of a transformer has leakage reactance [latex]X_{1},{X}'_{2}[/latex] and
magnetizing reactance [latex]X_{M}[/latex]. Their magnitudes satisfy
solution: A major part of the total flux is confined to the core as mutual flux [latex]\phi _m[/latex] linking both primary and secondary, a small amount of flux does leak through paths which lie mostly in aor and link separating the individual windings. Since reactance [latex]\propto[/latex] amount of the flux linkage [latex]\therefore \;\; X_M \gt \gt X_1\approx X'_2[/latex]

question:
Question 214 A hydraulic turbine having rated speed of 250 rpm is connected to a
synchronous generator. In order to produce power at 50 Hz, the number of poles
required in the generator are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P &=\frac{120f}{N} \\ \text{where}\; P &=\text{Number of poles} \\ N&=\text{Rated speed}\\ N&=250\; \text{rpm} \\ f&= 50Hz\\ P&=\frac{120 \times 50}{250}=24 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 215 A 500 MW, 3-phase, Y-connected synchronous generator has a rated voltage
of 21.5 kV at 0.85 p.f. The line current when operating at full load rated
conditions will be
solution: [latex]3-\phi[/latex] power [latex]=\sqrt{3}V_LI_L \cos \phi[/latex] Rated [latex]3-\phi[/latex] power [latex]=P=500MW[/latex] Power factor [latex]=\cos \phi =0.85[/latex] Rated line voltage [latex]=V_L=21.5kV[/latex] Rated line current [latex]=I_L=\frac{P}{\sqrt{3}V_L \cos \phi }[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_L=\frac{500 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3} \times 21.5 \times 10^3 \times 0.85}[/latex] = 15.79 kA

question:
Question 216 A 400 V, 50 kVA, 0.8 p.f. leading [latex]\triangle[/latex]-connected, 50 Hz synchronous machine has
a synchronous reactance of 2 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and negligible armature resistance. The friction
and windage losses are 2 kW and the core loss is 0.8 kW. The shaft is supplying
9 kW load at a power factor of 0.8 leading. The line current drawn is
solution: Power available at shaft [latex]=P_{shaft}=9kW[/latex] Losses = Core loss + Friction and windage loss + Copper loss Core loss = 0.8 kW Friction and windage loss = 2kW Armature resistance is negligibl, so copper loss is neglected. [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; \text{Losses} &= 0.8+2=2.8 kW \\ \text{Input power(P)}&=P_{shaft}+Losses \\ &=9+2.8=11.8kW \\ &\text{Line current drawn}\\ &= \frac{P}{\sqrt{3}V_L \cos \phi }\\ &= \frac{11.8 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times 400 \times 0.8}\\ &= 21.29A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 217 A 8-pole, DC generator has a simplex wave-wound armature containing 32 coils
of 6 turns each. Its flux per pole is 0.06 Wb. The machine is running at 250
rpm. The induced armature voltage is
solution: No of coil =32 Each coil has 6 turns Total no. of turns [latex]=32 \times6=192[/latex] Each turn has 2 conductors So, total no. of conductors [latex]=Z=192 \times 2=384[/latex] For wave would armature no of parallel path=A=2 Expression of induced emf, [latex]E=\frac{PZ}{60A}\phi N \;\;\;=\frac{8 \times 384}{60 \times 2}\times 0.06 \times 250[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=384V[/latex]

question:
Question 218 For a [latex]1.8^{\circ}[/latex], 2-phase bipolar stepper motor, the stepping rate is 100 steps/second.
The rotational speed of the motor in rpm is
solution: Stepping rate is 100 steps/sec. Step required for one revolution [latex]=\frac{360^{\circ}}{1.8}=200[/latex]steps. Therefore, time required for one revolution= 2 seconds rev/sec=0.5 rps rev/minute =30rpm

question:
Question 219 A 400 V, 15 kW, 4-pole, 50Hz, Y-connected induction motor has full load slip
of 4%. The output torque of the machine at full load is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_s(\text{Syn. speed}) &= \frac{120f}{P}\\ &= \frac{120 \times 50}{4}=1500\; \text{rpm}\\ \text{Torque developed} &= T=\frac{P}{\omega _s(1-s)}\\ &= \frac{15 \times 10^3 \times 60}{2 \pi \times 1440}\\ &= 99.47Nm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 220 Two 3-phase, Y-connected alternators are to be paralleled to a set of common
bus bars. The armature has a per phase synchronous reactance of 1.7[latex]\Omega[/latex] and
negligible armature resistance. The line voltage of the first machine is adjusted
to 3300 V and that of the second machine is adjusted to 3200 V. The machine
voltages are in phase at the instant they are paralleled. Under this condition,
the synchronizing current per phase will be
solution: Per phase synchronizing current [latex]=\frac{|E_1-E_2|}{Z_{s_1}-Z_{s_2}} [/latex] We have [latex]Z_{s_1}=Z_{s_2}[/latex] [latex] E_1 [/latex] and  [latex] E_2[/latex] must be phase quantities [latex]\therefore \;\;I_{sy}=\frac{\left [ \frac{3300}{\sqrt{3}}-\frac{3200}{\sqrt{3}} \right ]}{2 \times 1.7}=16.98A[/latex]

question:
Question 221 A single-phase, 230 V, 50 Hz, 4-pole, capacitor-start induction motor had the
following stand-still impedances. Main winding [latex]Z_{m} = 6.0 + j4.0 \Omega[/latex] Auxiliary winding [latex]Z_{a} = 8.0 + j6.0 \Omega[/latex] The value of the starting capacitor required to produce [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] phase difference between the currents in the main and auxiliary windings will be
solution: Supply voltage V is taken as reference. Current in main winding [latex]I_m=\frac{V}{Z_m} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; I_m=\frac{230\angle 0^{\circ}}{6+j4}=31.89\angle -33.7^{\circ}[/latex] Staring capacitor (C) wil be connected in series with the auxilary winding, so modified auxiliary winding impedance. [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_m &= 8+j6-\frac{j}{\omega C}\\ &= 8+j\left ( 6-\frac{1}{\omega C} \right )\\ &= 8-j\left ( \frac{1}{\omega C}-6 \right ) \end{aligned} [/latex] Current in auxiliary winding, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a &=\frac{V}{Z_a} \\ &= \frac{230\angle 0^{\circ}}{8-j\left ( \frac{1}{\omega C}-6 \right )}\\ &=|I_a|\angle \tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{\frac{1}{\omega C}-6 }{8} \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex] Capacitor is provided to make angle between [latex]I_a[/latex] and [latex]I_m90^{\circ}.[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{So,}\;\; \angle I_m+\angle I_a&=90^{\circ} \\ \angle I_a&= 90^{\circ}-33.7^{\circ}=56.3^{\circ}\\ \tan^{-1}\left ( \frac{\frac{1}{\omega C}-6 }{8} \right )&= 56.3^{\circ}\\ \frac{1}{\omega C} &= 18\\ \omega &= 2 \pi f=2 \pi \times 50 \text{rad/sec} \\ C&=176.84\mu F \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 222 The resistance and reactance of a 100 kVA, 11000/400 V, [latex]\triangle[/latex]-Y distribution
transformer are 0.02 and 0.07 pu respectively. The phase impedance of the
transformer referred to the primary is
solution: Rated kVA = 100kVA Rated primary line to line coltage [latex] V_{l-l}=11000V[/latex] Rated primary phase voltage [latex]V_p=V_{l-l}=11000V[/latex] Rated primary side line current [latex]\begin{aligned} I_1 &=\frac{\text{Rated kVA} \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3}V_{l-l}} \\ &= \frac{100 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3}\times 11000}A \end{aligned} [/latex] Rated primary phase current, [latex]I_p=\frac{I_1}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{100 \times 10^3}{3 \times 11000} [/latex] Base phase impedance, [latex]Z_B=\frac{V_p}{I_p}=\frac{11000}{\left (\frac{100 \times 10^3}{3 \times 11000} \right )}=3630\Omega [/latex] p.u. phase impedance [latex]=0.02+j0.07 pu[/latex] Phase impedance = Base phase impedance [latex]\times  (0.02+j0.07) [/latex] [latex]=3630 \times (0.02+j0.07) [/latex] [latex]=(72.6+j254.1)\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 223 A 50 kVA, 3300/230 V single-phase transformer is connected as an autotransformer
shown in figure. The nominal rating of the auto- transformer will be
solution: Consider two winding transformer [latex]\begin{aligned} I_1 &=\frac{50 \times 10^3}{3300}=15.15A \\ I_2&= \frac{50 \times 10^3}{230}=217.34A \end{aligned} [/latex] When this transformer is connected as step-up auto transformer [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{in} &=3300 \\ V_{out} &=3300+230=3530V \\ I_{out} &= I_2=217.34A\\ I_{in}&=I_{out}+15.15=232.49A \end{aligned} [/latex] KVA rating of the auto transformer [latex]S_{auto}=V_{in}I_{in} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\;=3300 \times 232.49 \times 10^{-3}\approx 767.4kVA[/latex]

question:
Question 224 The armature resistance of a permanent magnet dc motor is 0.8 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. At no load,
the motor draws 1.5 A from a supply voltage of 25 V and runs at 1500 rpm.
The efficiency of the motor while it is operating on load at 1500 rpm drawing a
current of 3.5 A from the same source will be
solution: At no load, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{a0} &= 1.5A\\ \text{supply voltage} &= V_t=250V\\ &\text{Back emf at no load,}\\ E_{b0}&=V_t-I_{a0}R_a \\ &= 25-1.5 \times 0.8\\ &= 23.8V\\ &\text{Power developed by the motor} \\ P_0=E_{b0}I_{a0} &=23.8 \times 1.5 \\ &= 35.7 W \end{aligned}[/latex] As the motor is working at no load, power [latex]P_0[/latex] supplies no load losses. When the motor is on load, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{a1} &= 3.5A\\ E_{a1}&=V_t-I_{a1}R_a \\ &= 25-3.5 \times 0.8\\ &= 22.2V\\ &\text{Power developed by the motor} \\ P_1=E_{a1}I_{a1} &=22.2 \times 3.5 \\ &= 77.7 W\\ &\text{Power available at shaft}\\ P_s&=P_1-\text{no load losses}\\ &=77.7-35.7=42W\\ \text{Efficiency}&=\frac{\text{Output power}}{input power} \times 100\\ &=\frac{P_0}{V_tT_{a_1}} \times 100\\ &=\frac{42}{25 \times 3.5} \times 100=48\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 225 A rotating electrical machine having its self-inductances of both the stator and the
rotor windings, independent of the rotor position will be definitely not develop
solution: [latex]L_s=\frac{N_s^2}{Rl_s} [/latex] and [latex] L_r=\frac{N_r^2}{Rl_r} [/latex] where, [latex]L_s[/latex] and [latex]L_r[/latex] are self inductances of stator and rotor. [latex]N_s[/latex] and [latex]N_r[/latex] are no. of turns energized in stator and rotor. [latex]Rl_s=[/latex] Reluctance seen by the stator flux. [latex]Rl_r=[/latex] Reluctance seen by the rotor flux. As [latex]L_s[/latex] and [latex]L_r[/latex] are independent of the rotor position, the reluctances [latex]Rl_s[/latex] and [latex]Rl_r[/latex] does not vary with the rotor movement. Therefore, reluctance torque terms. [latex]\frac{1}{2}I_s^2\frac{dls}{d\theta }[/latex] and [latex]\frac{1}{2}I_r^2\frac{dL_r}{d\theta }[/latex] become zero.

question:
Question 226 The synchronous speed for the seventh space harmonic mmf wave of a 3-phase,
8-pole, 50 Hz induction machine is
solution: Synchronous speed [latex]N_s=\frac{120f}{P}=\frac{120 \times 50}{8}[/latex]  [latex]=750 \; \text{rpm}[/latex] mmf wave contain space harmonics e.g. fifth and seventh harmonics which correspond to poles five and seven time that of the fundamental. Since the space-phase difference between fundamental poles of the winding phase is [latex](0^{\circ},120^{\circ},240^{\circ})[/latex], this difference is [latex](0^{\circ},240^{\circ},120^{\circ})[/latex] for fifth harmonic poles and [latex](0^{\circ},120^{\circ},240^{\circ})[/latex] for the seventh. Hence, the fifth harmonic poles rotate backwards with synchronous speed [latex]N_s/5[/latex] and the seventh harmonic poles rotate forward at [latex]\frac{N_s}{7}=\frac{750}{7}=107.14 \; \text{rpm}[/latex]

question:
Question 228 The direction of rotation of a 3-phase induction motor is clockwise when it is
supplied with 3-phase sinusoidal voltage having phase sequence A-B-C. For
counter clockwise rotation of the motor, the phase sequence of the power supply
should be
solution: To reverse the direction of rotation, phase sequence of the supply has to be reversed. For clockwise direction, the phase sequence was A-B-C. For counter-clockwise direction, the phase sequence has to be A-C-B.

question:
Question 229 The type of single-phase induction motor having the highest power factor at full
load is
solution: Capacitor start type motor has high staring torque and therefore is used for hard starting loads such as compressor, conveyors, pumps et. Capacitor-run type motor has better running power factor and efficiency and a quiter and smoother operation. It is used for both easy and hard to start loads. Moder applications of such motors are ceiling fans, blower etc.

question: Question 230 The following motor definitely has a permanent magnet rotor
solution: Brushless dc motor definitely has a permanent magnet.

question: Question 231 For a given stepper motor, the following torque has the highest numerical value
solution: Detent torque: It is amount of torque that the motor produces when it is not energized. No current is slowing through the winding. Holding Torque: It is amount of torque that the motor produces when it has rated current flowing through  the winding but motor is at rest.. Pull-in Torque: Shows the maximum value of torque at given speeds that the motor can start, stop, or reverse in synchronism with the input pulses. Pull-out Torque: Shows the maximum value of torque at given speeds that the motor can generate while running in synchronism. If the motor is run outside of this curve, it will stall.

question:
Question 232 A 500 kVA, 3-phase transformer has iron losses of 300 W and full load copper
losses of 600 W. The percentage load at which the transformer is expected to
have maximum efficiency is
solution: Copper loass at any load [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{cu} &=x^2 \times [\text{Full load copper loss}] \\ &= x^2 \times P_{fl,cu}\\ \text{where,}\;\; x&= \text{fraction of laod} \end{aligned} [/latex] Maximum occurs when Copper loss-Iron loss [latex]x^2 \times P_{fl,cu}=P_i [/latex] [latex]x^2 \times 600=300 x=0.707 =70.7\%[/latex]

question:
Question 233 An ac induction motor is used for a speed control application. It is driven from
an inverter with a constant V/f control. The motor name-plate details are as
follows (no. of poles = 2) V:415 V Ph:3 f:50 Hz N:2850 rpm The motor runs with the inverter output frequency set at 40 Hz, and with half
the rated slip. The running speed of the motor is
solution: [latex]N_{S1}=3000 \; \text{rpm} [/latex] [latex]N_1=2850 \; \text{rpm} [/latex] [latex]S_{FL}=\frac{3000-2850}{3000}=0.05 [/latex] where, by (V/f) control, [latex] N_{S2}=3000\left ( \frac{40}{50} \right )=2400 \; \text{rpm} [/latex] (synchronous speed at 40 Hz) [latex]N_2=[/latex] New running speed of motor [latex]N_{S2}\left ( 1-\frac{S_{FL}}{2} \right )=2400\left ( 1-\frac{0.05}{2} \right )[/latex]  [latex] =2340 \; \text{rpm}[/latex]

question:
Question 234 A dc series motor driving an electric train faces a constant power load. It is
running at rated speed and rated voltage. If the speed has to be brought down
to 0.25 p.u. the supply voltage has to be approximately brought down to
solution: In series motor, Back emf, [latex]E=v-I(R_a+R_{se}) [/latex] [latex]\text{If},\;\;(R_a+R_{se})=R [/latex] [latex]\text{them,}\;\; E=V-IR [/latex] [latex]\text{where,}\;\; E=K_n \phi N [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\;\;N=\frac{V-IR}{K_n \phi }[/latex] In series motor, [latex]\phi \propto I [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  At constant power load [latex]E \times I=T \times w=const [/latex] [latex]\text{where,} \;\; T=K_a\phi I=K_a I^2[/latex] If '[latex]w_n[/latex]' decrease by (1/4) of its rated value, then torque will increase 4 times to maintain power contant. [latex] \therefore \;\; T\propto I^2 [/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]  current increase 2 times so that supply voltage approximately brought down to 0.5pu.

question:

question:
Question 236 A 3-phase induction motor is driving a constant torque load at rated voltage
and frequency. If both voltage and frequency are halved, following statements
relate to the new condition if stator resistance, leakage reactance and core loss
are ignored 1. The difference between synchronous speed and actual speed remains same 2. The airgap flux remains same 3. The stator current remains same 4. The p.u. slip remains same Among the above, correct statements are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V &\propto f\phi \\ &\text{in induction machine}\\ V_2&= \frac{V_1}{2}\\ \text{and}\;\; f_2 &=\frac{f_1}{2} \\ \frac{V_1}{V_2} &=\frac{f_1\phi _1}{f_2\phi _2} \\ \phi _2&= \left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )\left ( \frac{f_1}{f_2} \right )\phi _1\\ &= \left ( \frac{V_1/2}{V_1} \right )\left ( \frac{f_1}{f_1/2} \right )\phi _1\\ &= \phi _1 \end{aligned} [/latex] So, air-gap flux remains same. [latex](X_2')_1=[/latex] nominal rotor stanstill reactance referred to stator (at frequency [latex]f_1[/latex]) [latex] \begin{aligned} (X_2')_2 &= \left ( \frac{f_2}{f_1} \right )(X_2')_1\\ &= \left ( \frac{f_1/2}{f_1} \right )(X_2')_1\\ &= \frac{(X_2')_1}{2}\\ (\omega _s)_2 &= \left ( \frac{f_2}{f_1} \right ) (\omega _s)_1\\ &= \left ( \frac{f_1/2}{f_1} \right ) (\omega _s)_1\\ &=\frac{(\omega _s)_1}{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] Torque developed in induction motor [latex]T=\frac{3}{\omega _s} \frac{V^2R'_2/s}{(R'_2/s)^2 +{X'_2}^2}[/latex] For normal steady state oprating region, slip is very low [latex]\frac{R'_2}{s} \gt \gt X'_2[/latex] [latex] T=\frac{3}{\omega _s} \frac{V^2R'_2/s}{(R'_2/s)^2}=\frac{3}{\omega _s} \frac{sV^2}{R'_2} [/latex] As the load torque is constant [latex] \begin{aligned} T_1 &=T_2 \\ \frac{s_1V_1^2}{(\omega _s)_1R'_2}&= \frac{s_2V_2^2}{(\omega _s)_2R'_2}\\ \Rightarrow \;\; s_2 &=\frac{(\omega _s)_2}{(\omega _s)_1} \times \left ( \frac{V_1}{V_2} \right )^2 s_1\\ &=\frac{(\omega _s)_1/2}{(\omega _s)_1} \times \left ( \frac{V_1}{V_1/2} \right )^2 s_1 \\ s_2 &= \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times s_1=2s_1 \end{aligned} [/latex] Difference between synchronous speed and actual speed [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega _s -\omega _r &= s\omega _s\\ (\omega _s)_1 -(\omega _r)_2 &= s_2(\omega _s)_2\\ &=(2s_1) \times \frac{(\omega _s)_1}{2} =s_1(\omega _s)_1 \end{aligned} [/latex] Therefore, the difference between synchronous speed and actual speed remain same. Stator current [latex]\begin{aligned} |I_s| &= \frac{V}{\sqrt{(R'_2/s)^2+{X'}_2^2}} \\ \text{as}\;\; R'_2/s & \gt \gt X'_2 \\ |I_s|&=\frac{sV}{R'_2} \\ |I_{s1}|&= s_1\frac{V_1}{R'_2}\\ |I_{s2}|&=s_2\frac{V_2}{R'_2} \\ ||I_{s2}&=(2s_1)\times \frac{V_1/2}{R'_2}=\frac{s_1V_1}{R'_2} \\ ||I_{s1}&=|I_{s2}| \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, stator current remains same.

question:
Question 237 A 4-pole, 3-phase, double-layer winding is housed in a 36-slot stator for an ac
machine with 60c phase spread. Coil span is 7 short pitches. Number of slots in
which top and bottom layers belong to different phases is
solution: Pole pitch [latex]=\frac{36}{4}=9[/latex] slots Coil span = 7 slots, Slot/pole/ph = 3 So that 3 slots in one phase, if it is chorded by 2 slot, then Out of 3[latex]\rightarrow[/latex]2 have different phase Therefore out of 36[latex]\rightarrow[/latex]24 have diffferent phase.

question:
Question 238 When stator and rotor windings of a 2-pole rotating electrical machine are
excited, each would produce a sinusoidal mmf distribution in the airgap with
peal values [latex]F_s[/latex] and [latex]F_r[/latex] respectively. The rotor mmf lags stator mmf by a space
angle [latex]\delta[/latex] at any instant as shown in figure. Thus, half of stator and rotor surfaces will form one pole with the other half forming the second pole. Further, the direction of torque acting on the rotor can be clockwise or counter-clockwise. The following table gives four set of statement as regards poles and torque. Select
the correct set corresponding to the mmf axes as shown in figure.
solution: Inside a magnetic material, flux flows from S-pole to N-pole. Outside a magnetic material flux flow from N-pole to S-pole When stator winding is excited, it produces flux. If ABC is assumed to N-pole flux will link rotor. As we know, flux flows from N-pole to S-pole externally, abc from S-pole. Inside rotor, flux flows from surface abc to cda So, surface cda forms N-poles. To identify direction of torque The torque acts in a direction to reduce [latex]\delta[/latex] i.e. to align the two fields. So, torque on the rotor acrs in counter-clockwise direction to reduce [latex]\delta[/latex].

question:
Question 239 Following are some of the properties of rotating electrical machines P. Stator winding current is dc, rotor winding current is ac. Q. Stator winding current is ac, rotor winding current is dc. R. Stator winding current is ac, rotor winding current is ac. S. Stator has salient poles and rotor has commutator. T. Rotor has salient poles and sliprings and stator is cylindrical. U. Both stator and rotor have poly-phase windings. DC machines, Synchronous machines and Induction machines exhibit some of
the above properties as given in the following table. Indicate the correct combination from this table
solution: In DC machine, field is provided at stator and armature is provided at rotor. Because of commutator and slip-rings, AC rotor winding current is converted inot dc. IN synchronous machine, it is difficult to provide armature in rotor because of many factor like insulation no of slip rings, rating of slip rings, high rating of armature. Therefore, armature is provided in stator and field in rotor Induction machines are singlyfed machine i.e. they draw excitation from the same supply. So no external field supply is required.

question:
Question 240 Figure shows an ideal three-winding transformer. The three windings 1, 2,
3 of the transformer are wound on the same core as shown. The turns ratio [latex]N_{1}:N_{2}:N_{3}[/latex] is 4:2:1. A resistor of 10 [latex]\Omega[/latex] is connected across winding-2. A capacitor of reactance 2.5 [latex]\Omega[/latex] is connected across winding-3. Winding-1 is connected across a 400 V, ac supply. If the supply voltage phasor [latex]V_{1}=400\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex], the supply current phasor [latex]I_1[/latex] is given by
solution: Turn ratio, [latex]N_1:N_2: N_3 is 4:2:1 [/latex] Induced emf in winding 1 [latex]=E_1\approx V_1=400\angle 0^{\circ}V[/latex] As we know, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{E_1}{E_2} &=\frac{N_1}{N_2} \\ E_2&=\frac{N_2}{N_1}E_1=\left ( \frac{2}{4} \right ) 400\angle 0^{\circ}\\ &=200\angle 0^{\circ} \\ \text{and}\;\;\frac{E_1}{E_3} &=\frac{N_1}{N_3} \\ \Rightarrow \; E_3 &=\frac{N_3}{N_1}E_1 \\ &=\left ( \frac{1}{4} \right ) 400\angle 0^{\circ}= 100\angle 0^{\circ}V \end{aligned}[/latex] Current in secondary winding [latex]I_2=\frac{E_2}{R}=\frac{200\angle 0^{\circ}}{10}=20\angle 0^{\circ}A [/latex] Current in tertiary winding [latex]I_3=\frac{E_3}{-j \times C}=\frac{100\angle 0^{\circ}}{-j2.5}=40\angle 90^{\circ}A[/latex] [latex] I_2[/latex] referred to primary side [latex]\begin{aligned} I'_2 &=\left ( \frac{N_2}{N_1} \right )I_2 \\ &= \left ( \frac{2}{4} \right ) \times (20\angle 0^{\circ})=0\angle 10^{\circ}A \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] I_3[/latex] reffered to primary side [latex]\begin{aligned} I'_3 &=\left ( \frac{N_3}{N_1} \right )I_3 \\ &= \left ( \frac{1}{4} \right ) \times (40\angle 90^{\circ})=10\angle 90^{\circ}A \end{aligned}[/latex] The suuply currrent [latex]\begin{aligned} I_1 &=I'_2+I'_3 \\ &= 10\angle 0^{\circ}+10\angle 90^{\circ}=(10+j10)A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 241 Figure shows a [latex]\Delta[/latex]-Y connected, 3-phase distribution transformer used to step down the voltage from 11000 V to 415 V line-to-line. It has two switches [latex]S_{1}[/latex] and [latex]S_{2}[/latex]. Under normal conditions [latex]S_{1}[/latex] is closed and [latex]S_{2}[/latex] is open. Under certain special conditions [latex]S_{1}[/latex] is open and [latex]S_{2}[/latex] is closed. In such a case the magnitude of the voltage across the LV terminals a and c is
solution: As the transformer is [latex]\Delta -Y[/latex] connected, it means line-to-line voltage on primary side induces line to neutral for phase voltage on secondary side due to transformer. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Turn ratio} &=\frac{N_1}{N_2}=a \\ &= \frac{11kV}{415\sqrt{3}}=\frac{11\sqrt{3}}{415} \times 10^3\\ V_{AB}&=aV_a \\ V_{BC}&=aV_b\\ V_{AC}&=aV_c \end{aligned} [/latex] When [latex]S_2[/latex] is closed, B and C are at same potential. So,  [latex]V_{BC}=V_B-V_C=0[/latex] Applying KVL in, [latex]\Delta[/latex] connection [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{AB}+V_{BC}+V_{AC} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; V_{AC} &=-V_{AB} \\ V_{AB}&= 11 \times 10^3 \angle 0^{\circ}\\ V_{AC}&= - 11 \times 10^3 \angle 0^{\circ}\\ &= 11 \times 10^3 \angle 180^{\circ} \end{aligned} [/latex] Voltage across terminals a and c, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{ac} &=V_a-V_c \\ &=\frac{V_{AB}}{a}-\frac{V_{AC}}{a} \\ &= \frac{1}{a}[V_{AB}-V_{AC}]\\ &=\frac{415}{11\sqrt{3} \times 10^3} \\ &[11 \times 10^3 \angle 0^{\circ} - 11 \times 10^3 \angle 180^{\circ} ]\\ &=\frac{415}{11\sqrt{3} \times 10^3} [11 \times 10^3 \times 2]\\ &\approx 480 V \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 242 To conduct load test on a dc shunt motor, it is coupled to a generator which
is identical to the motor. The field of the generator is also connected to the
same supply source as the motor. The armature of generator is connected
to a load resistance. The armature resistance is 0.02 p.u. Armature reaction
and mechanical losses can be neglected. With rated voltage across the motor,
the load resistance across the generator is adjusted to obtain rated armature
current in both motor and generator. The p.u value of this load resistance is
solution: All calculation are done in p.u. system. Motor is connected across rated voltage V= 1 pu. Rated armature current flows in both motor and generator [latex]I_g=I_m=1 pu[/latex] Armature resistance of both motor and generator [latex]R_m=R_g=0.02 pu[/latex] Back iemf in motor [latex]=E_b=V-I_mR_m [/latex] [latex]=1-1 \times 0.02 =0.98 pu[/latex] Mechanical power output of the motor [latex]=E_bI_m=0.98 \times 1=0.98 pu[/latex] This power is given to the generator and armation reaction and mechanical losses are negligible. Input power of generator = Output power of motor [latex]E_bI_g=E_bI_m E_g=E_b=0.98pu [/latex] Terminal voltage of the generator [latex]V_g=E_g-I_gR_g  =0.98-1 \times 0.02=0.96pu [/latex] [latex]R_L=\frac{V_g}{I_g}=\frac{0.96}{1}=0.96\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 243 Figure shows an ideal single-phase transformer. The primary and secondary
coils are wound on the core as shown. Turns ratio [latex](\frac{N_{1}}{N_{2}}) = 2[/latex]. The correct
phasors of voltages [latex]E_{1}[/latex], [latex]E_{2}[/latex], currents [latex]I_{1}[/latex], [latex]I_{2}[/latex] and core flux [latex]\phi[/latex] are as shown in
solution: As per lenz's law, [latex]E_1=N_1\frac{d\phi }{dt} [/latex] The positive direction of this emf opposes the positive current direction.] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{If,}\;\; \phi &=\phi _m\sin \omega t \\ E_1&= N_1 \frac{d}{dt}(\phi _m\sin \omega t )\\ &= N_1\phi _m \omega \cos \omega t \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] E_1[/latex] leads the flux by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] Similarly,  [latex]E_2= N_2 \frac{d\phi }{dt}(\phi _m\sin \omega t ) [/latex] and  [latex] E_2[/latex]  leads the flux by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] So [latex]E_1[/latex and [latex]E_2[/latex] are in phase. question:
Question 244 The speed/torque regimes in a dc motor and the control methods suitable for
the same are given respectively in Group-II and Group-I
solution: Field Control: Fieldcontrol provides constant power drive. Since the speed is inversely proportional to flux/pole [latex]\left ( \omega \propto \frac{1}{\phi } \right )[/latex] field can not be increased; It can only be weakended. So this control is suitable for speed control above base speed as torque is directly proportional to flux/pole [latex](T \propto \alpha )[/latex] for a given armature current. So, this control provides torque below base torque. Armature Control: It provides constant-torque drive. By keeping th field current at maximumvalue full load torque can be obtained at full load armature current at all speeds. This control provides speed below base speed.

question: Question 245 A round rotor generator with internal voltage [latex]E_{1}[/latex] = 2.0 p.u. and X = 1.1 p.u. is connected to a round rotor synchronous motor with internal voltage [latex]E_{2}[/latex] = 1.3 p.u. and X = 1.2 p.u. The reactance of the line connecting the generator to the motor is 0.5 p.u. When the generator supplies 0.5 p.u. power, the rotor angle difference between the machines will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x_{eq} &=x_1+x_{line} +x_2\\ &= 1.1+0.5+1.2\\ &= 2.8\;p.u.\\ E_1&=2.0 \;p.u. \\ E_2&= 1.3 \; p.u. \end{aligned} [/latex] Rotor angle difference [latex]=\delta _1-\delta _2 [/latex] Power transferred from generator to motor [latex]\begin{aligned} P &=\frac{E_1E_2}{x_{eq}}\sin (\delta _1-\delta _2) \\ 0.5 &= \frac{2 \times 1.3}{2.8} \sin (\delta _1-\delta _2)\\ \delta _1-\delta _2 &= 32.58^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 246 No-load test on a 3-phase induction motor was conducted at different supply
voltage and a plot of input power versus voltage was drawn. This curve was
extrapolated to intersect the y-axis. The intersection point yields
solution: Power input at no-load [latex](P_0)[/latex] provided losses only as the shaft output is zero. These losses comprise [latex]P_i[/latex](Iron/core loss) and [latex]P_{wf}[/latex](windage and friction loss). As the voltage is reduced below the rated value, the core-loss decreases as the square of voltage. Since the slip does not increase significantly, the windage and friction loss remains almost constant. The plot of [latex]P_0[/latex] versus V is extrapolated at V=0 which gives, [latex]P_{wf}[/latex] as [latex]P_{i}=0[/latex] art zero voltage.

question:
Question 248 A stand alone engine driven synchronous generator is feeding a partly inductive
load. A capacitor is now connected across the load to completely nullify the
inductive current. For this operating condition.
solution: Assuming resistance of the armature to be zero. In first case, the generator is feeding a partly inductive load. It means that generator is supplying lagging power. The generator supplies a lagging power factor current when it is overexcited which is represented by [latex]E_{f_1}[/latex]. In second case, a capacitor is connected across the load to completely nullifythe inductive current. It means the generator supplies no reactive power and unity power factor current is drawn from the generator. The excitation ([latex]E_{f_2}[/latex]) corresponding to unity power factor is known as normal excitation. From the phasor diagram [latex]E_{f_1} \gt E_{f_2}[/latex] and as the field current approximately directly proportional to excitation, the field current has to be reduced. From phasor diagram [latex]E_{f_1} \sin \delta _1=E_{f_2} \sin \delta _2=\text{constant}[/latex] [latex]P_e(\text{ power delivered})=\frac{E_fV_t}{X_s}\sin \delta[/latex] Fuel input remains unaltered.

options.A: the field current and fuel input have to be reduced
options.B: the field current and fuel input have to be increased
options.C: the field current has to be increased and fuel input left unaltered
options.D: the field current has to be reduced and fuel input left unaltered

solution: Universal motors are used where light weight is important., as in vacuum cleaners and portable tools e.g. food mixer which usually operate at high speed (1500-15000 rpm). Question 250 A sinple phase transformer has a maximum efficiency of 90% at full load and
unity power factor. Efficiency at half load at the same power factor is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\text{Efficiency} &=\frac{\text{Output}}{\text{Input}} \\ 
 &= \frac{\text{Output}}{\text{Output}+\text{Losses}}\\ 
 \text{Output}&= x S \cos \phi  \\ 
\text{Where,}\;\;S &=\text{Rating of the machine} \\ 
 x&= \% \text{of the full load}\\ 
 \cos \phi &= \text{Power factor} \\ 
 P_i &= \text{Iron or core loss}\\ 
 P_{cu} &=\text{Full load copper loss} \\ 
&\text{For maximum frequency}\\
P_i &=x^2P_{cu} \\ 
\text{Efficiency} =\eta &= \frac{xS \cos \phi }{xS \cos \phi +P_i+x^2 P_{cu}} \\
\text{Max efficiency}=\eta _{max}&=\frac{xS \cos \phi }{xS \cos \phi +2P_i}\\
\Rightarrow \;\;0.9&=\frac{1 \times S \times 1}{1 \times S \times 1+2P_i}\\
P_i&=0.055S
\end{aligned}[/latex] Full load copper loss [latex]= 1^2 P_{cu}=P_i[/latex] [latex]
P_{cu}=0.055S[/latex] Efficiency of halh load, upf [latex]
x=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] [latex]
\eta =\frac{\frac{1}{2} \times S \times 1 }{\frac{1}{2} \times S \times 1 +0.055S+\left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )^2 \times 0.055S} \times 100
[/latex] [latex]\;\;\;\approx 87.8\%[/latex]

of [latex]2\Omega[/latex]. Rated dc voltage is applied to both the armature and field winding of the motor. If the armature drawn 5A from the source, the torque developed by the
motor is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} (E_b)_{rated} &=200 -2 \times 10=180V \\ \text{Rated power}&= 180 \times 10=1800W\\ \text {Rated torque}&= \frac{1800 \times 60}{2 \pi \times 2000}=8.598Nm \\ \text{Torque at} 5A, & \\ \frac{T_2}{T_1}&=\frac{I_{a_2}}{I_{a_1}} \\ T_2&= \frac{5}{10} \times 8.598=4.299Nm \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 259 A star-connected 440 V, 50 Hz alternators has per phase synchronous reactance
of 10[latex]\Omega[/latex]. It supplies a balanced capacitive load current of 20 A, as shown in the
per phase equivalent circuit of figure. It is desirable to have zero voltage
regulation. The load power factor should be
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
E_f\angle \delta &= V\angle 0+I_a\angle \phi \cdot Z_s\angle \theta  \\ 
 &= V\angle 0+I_aZ_s\angle \phi + \theta\;\;...(i)
\end{aligned}[/latex] Squaring both side, we get, [latex]|E_f|=|V|^2+|I_a|^2|Z_s|^2+2 |V||I_a||Z_s| \cos (\theta +\phi )[/latex] For zero regulation, [latex]|E_f|=|V|[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \; \cos (\theta +\phi ) &= -\frac{|I_a||Z_s|}{2|V|}\\ 
 &= -\frac{20 \times 10}{2 \times \frac{440}{\sqrt{3}}}\\ 
 &= -0.3936\\ 
 \theta +\phi &= 113.178^{\circ}\\ 
\phi  &= 113.178^{\circ}-90^{\circ} \\ 
 &= 23.178^{\circ}\\ 
 \cos \phi &= 0.9192
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 260 A 3-phase transformer has rating of 20 MVA, 220 kV (star) - 33 kV (delta) with
leakage reactance of 12%. The transformer reactance (in ohms) referred to each
phase of the L.V. delta-connected side is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} [(Z)_{base}]_{per\; phase}&=\frac{(V_{phase})^2}{(S_{base})_{phase}} \\ &=\frac{(33kV)^2}{\frac{20}{3}MVA} \\ Z_{actual}&=Z_{base} \times Z_{pu} \\ &= \frac{3 \times (33)^2}{20} \times \frac{12}{100}\\ &= 19.6\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]
